questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isograft

 

An isograft is a type of graft where the donor and the recipient are genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of graft has the lowest risk of rejection because the donor and recipient have the same genetic makeup, which means their tissues are immunologically compatible.

 

Types of Grafts:

 

Option A. Allograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of the same species but have different genotypes.
  • Examples: Organ transplants between two different individuals (e.g., kidney transplant from one person to another non-twin individual).

 

Option B. Autograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are the same person.
  • Examples: Skin grafts taken from one part of the body and transplanted to another part of the same individual's body.

 

Option C. Isograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft between two individuals who are genetically identical, such as identical twins.
  • Examples: Organ or tissue transplants between identical twins.

 

Option D. Xenograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of different species.
  • Examples: Transplantation of animal tissues or organs into humans, such as pig heart valves used in human heart surgery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Autografts are grafts in which both the donor and the recipient are the same person.
  • Isografts are grafts that occur between donors and recipients who share the same genotype. An isograft is a graft from an identical twin
  • Allografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of the same species but of a different genotype.
  • Xenografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of different species.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enterogastric

 

Explanation

 

Enterogastric reflex is the reflex that inhibits gastric emptying. It is elicited by the presence of chyme in the duodenum, which prevents further emptying of stomach.

 

Mechanism of enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying.
  2. Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying.
  3. Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrocolic Reflex: Incorrect. The gastrocolic reflex triggers increased colonic motility in response to food entering the stomach. It does not directly affect gastric emptying.

 

Option B. Enterocolic Reflex: Incorrect. This is not a widely recognized reflex within standard physiological texts; it does not pertain specifically to the control of gastric emptying.

 

Option C. Gastroileal Reflex: Incorrect. The gastroileal reflex stimulates the movement of chyme from the ileum into the large intestine following food intake, which is unrelated to the initial inhibition of gastric emptying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterogastric reflex plays a critical role in regulating the rate at which the stomach empties its contents into the duodenum, particularly under conditions where the chyme is highly acidic. This regulation ensures that the duodenum can adequately process the chyme without being overwhelmed, which is crucial for maintaining digestive health and preventing duodenal irritation or damage.

 

Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Duodenal distension
  2. Irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  3. Acidity of the chyme
  4. Osmolality of the chyme
  5. Breakdown products of proteins and fats

questions.text: Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

 

Glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate back to glucose. It is activated when the insulin-to-glucagon ratio decreases. This enzyme plays a crucial role in gluconeogenesis, the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources when blood glucose levels are low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucokinase: Glucokinase is an enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is primarily found in the liver and pancreatic beta cells. Glucokinase's activity is influenced by glucose levels, not the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Option B. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is another enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is present in various tissues, but its activity is not directly regulated by changes in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio's

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that converts glucose to pyruvate. It plays a role in glucose metabolism but is not activated by a decrease in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, which occurs during fasting.
  • Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state.
  • Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin.
  • Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 137-138

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented with hypertension and chest pain. A chest radiograph was taken as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and the chest X-ray depicting the figure of 3 sign are suggestive of coarctation of aorta to be the cause of hypertension in this patient.

 

Typical C/F: Brachio-femoral delay – Upper limb pulsations/BP is high; Lower limb pulsation/BP is feeble.

 

Radiological investigation:

 

  • Figure of 3 signs on CXR
  • Inferior rib notching – Roesler's sign 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential hypertension: More common in older adults and usually doesn't show specific findings on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Associated with high calcium levels and bone resorption signs, not directly causing visible changes on a chest X-ray linked with hypertension.

 

Option D. Takayasu arteritis: A vasculitis that might show narrowing or dilation of the aorta or its branches, but it typically affects younger women and would likely show different patterns on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta can be identified on a chest X-ray by the "figure of 3" sign, and it should be suspected in young patients presenting with hypertension and signs of upper body hypertension contrasted with lower limb hypotension.

choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

 

Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

 

The autosomal dominant condition known as Huntington disease (HD) is characterized histologically by the destruction of striatal neurons and clinically by increasing mobility abnormalities and dementia. All portions of the body move jerkily, hyperkinetically, and occasionally in a dystonic manner (chorea); affected people may eventually develop parkinsonism with bradykinesia and stiffness. The average course of the illness is around 15 years before death because of its persistent progression.

 

The polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat expansion illnesses have their origins in Huntington disease. The HD gene, which is found on chromosome 4p16.3, produces the 348-kD huntingtin protein.

 

A section of CAG repeats in the gene's first exon encodes a polyglutamine region near the protein's N terminus. The repeat is present in 6 to 35 copies in normal HD genes; when the number of repeats is increased beyond this level it is associated with disease.

 

There is an inverse relationship between repeat number and age of onset, such that longer repeats are associated with earlier onset.

 

The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is loss of function type of mutation: This is incorrect. Huntington's disease is caused by a gain-of-function mutation due to the expansion of the CAG repeat in the huntingtin gene, not by a loss-of-function mutation.

 

Option C. There are abnormal repeats of CUG: This is incorrect. The trinucleotide repeat involved in Huntington's disease is CAG, not CUG. CUG repeats are associated with other genetic disorders, such as myotonic dystrophy.

 

Option D. Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6: This is incorrect. The genetic mutation causing Huntington's disease is located on chromosome 4p16.3, not chromosome 6.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery would most likely compromise the blood supply to which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e., right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

 

 

  • The common hepatic artery typically divides into the hepatic proper artery and the gastroduodenal artery.
  • The hepatic proper artery, in turn, gives rise to the right gastric artery (which supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach) and continues as the left and right hepatic arteries for the liver.
  • The gastroduodenal artery gives off the right gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Thus, if the common hepatic artery is ligated, blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries would be impaired.

 

Branches of hepatic artery (Mnemonic – Girls R So Cute)

 

  • Gastroduodenal artery > divides into right gastroepiploic and superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
  • Right gastric artery
  • Supra duodenal artery (inconstant)
  • Cystic artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right gastric and left gastric artery: While the right gastric artery does arise from the hepatic proper artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery), the left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the left gastric artery's blood supply.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery). The short gastric arteries, however, typically arise from the splenic artery, another direct branch of the celiac trunk. Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the blood supply of the short gastric vessels.

 

Option D. Right gastric and short gastric vessels: As mentioned earlier, the right gastric artery arises from the hepatic proper artery. The short gastric arteries arise from the splenic artery. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would only affect the right gastric artery's blood supply, not the short gastric vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery affects the blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries due to their derivation from the hepatic proper and gastroduodenal arteries respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ranolazine

 

  • Ranolazine is an anti-anginal drug, that is a Fatty acid oxidation inhibitor (Another one being Trimetazidine), that acts by decreasing the oxygen demand of the heart by making it utilize glucose as the source of ATP.
  • Ranolazine also acts on the late Na+ channel in the heart, which helps in reducing the intracellular calcium concentration, thereby reducing the diastolic tension and the cardiac contractility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ivabradine: Ivabradine acts by selectively inhibiting the funny current (If) in the sinoatrial node, which reduces the heart rate. It does not inhibit the late sodium current.

 

Option C. Trimetazidine: Trimetazidine is also a metabolic modulator that shifts the heart's energy substrate preference from fatty acid oxidation to glucose oxidation, improving myocardial efficiency. However, it does not inhibit the late sodium current.

 

Option D. Fasudil: Fasudil is a Rho-kinase inhibitor that causes vasodilation, primarily used for conditions such as cerebral vasospasm and pulmonary hypertension. It does not affect the late sodium current.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ranolazine acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart, which reduces intracellular calcium overload, decreases diastolic tension, and lowers myocardial oxygen demand, making it effective in the management of chronic angina.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CS sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci.

 

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili.

 

From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteraemia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.

 

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and haemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in immunocompromised hosts and those with chronic wounds but not typically presenting with purpuric rash and meningitis.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia: A common cause of bacterial meningitis but gram-positive and usually does not present with a purpuric rash.

 

Option D. E.coli: While it can cause meningitis in newborns and the elderly, it is not commonly associated with purpuric rash and gram-negative diplococci presentation in young adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a critical pathogen to consider in young adults presenting with symptoms of high-grade fever and a purpuric rash, especially when gram-negative diplococci are identified in the CSF. Rapid diagnosis and immediate treatment with appropriate antibiotics are crucial to prevent serious complications and mortality. This highlights the importance of vigilance for meningococcal disease in acute care settings.

questions.text: What type of joint is demonstrated in the highlighted region of the vertebral articulation shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synovial

 

The joint marked in the above image is a synovial joint called the costotransverse and costovertebral joint.

 

These are the most common type of joints in the body. The articulating ends of the bones in these joints are covered with articular cartilage. These bones are enclosed within an articular capsule which has an outer fibrous layer (giving it strength) and an inner synovial membrane which secretes synovial fluid (providing lubrication and nutrients to the joint). Examples include the knee joint, elbow joint, and many others.

 

They are diarthrotic, meaning they are freely movable. The exact range of movement and type of movement (e.g., hinge, pivot, ball-and-socket) varies depending on the specific joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a type of fibrous joint where the bones are joined by a ligament or a membrane. The most commonly referred syndesmosis is the one between the tibia and fibula in the leg, held together by the interosseous membrane and the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments.

 

  • It allows for a slight movement (making it amphiarthrotic), particularly when the foot is dorsiflexed or plantarflexed.

 

Option B. Synarthrosis: This term describes a joint that allows very minimal or no movement. It encompasses several types of joints including sutures (between skull bones), gomphoses (between a tooth and its socket), and synchondroses (which we'll discuss next).

 

  • These are largely immovable joints. They serve to provide stability in certain areas of the body, like the skull, where movement is not desired.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: This is a subtype of synarthrosis, and it's a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined together by hyaline cartilage. A classic example is the joint between the first rib and the sternum, or the epiphyseal plates in growing bones.

 

  • They are immovable (synarthrotic). The primary purpose of these joints is to allow growth of the bone while providing stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Description of the joint present in the thoracic region are as follows:

questions.text: A patient is given a nicotinic receptor antagonist as a muscle relaxant. Which drug is given postoperatively to recover from muscle weakness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neostigmine

 

For reversal of neuromuscular blockade from non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, the reversal agent of choice is Neostigmine.

 

  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that boosts the concentration of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, thus enhancing muscle contraction.
  • Neostigmine is the drug of choice for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively. By preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine, it counteracts the muscle-relaxing effects of these drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine:

 

  • Physostigmine is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor. It increases the concentration of acetylcholine at nerve endings.
  • Physostigmine is primarily used to treat anticholinergic (atropine-like) drug overdoses. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and is used for central anticholinergic syndromes. It is not typically used for reversing neuromuscular blockade from muscle relaxants.

 

Option C. Carbachol:

 

  • Carbachol is a cholinergic drug that acts as an agonist at both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.
  • Carbachol is primarily used in ophthalmology to induce miosis or to reduce intraocular pressure. It is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine:

 

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It binds to nicotinic receptors and causes prolonged depolarization, which initially causes muscle fasciculation followed by paralysis.
  • Succinylcholine itself causes muscle paralysis and is used to facilitate intubation during anesthesia induction. It would not be used to reverse muscle relaxation; in fact, it would exacerbate it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the preferred agent for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polio

 

While infants can acquire polio antibodies from their mothers, this immunity is not consistent and can fade during infancy. Therefore, newborns are given a 0 dose of polio drops to ensure protection against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Maternal antibodies against tetanus can provide significant immunity to the newborn. Pregnant women are advised to receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, ideally between 27-36 weeks of gestation. Maternal antibodies produced from the vaccine can protect the newborn against tetanus.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Maternal antibodies provide some protection, but it's less reliable than tetanus


Protection duration is shorter (1-2 months)

 

Option D. Measles: Maternal antibodies help protect the baby from measles until about 9 months of age. After that, the efficacy of maternal antibodies decreases, which is why the measles vaccine is given at 9 months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which embryonic pharyngeal arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 6th arch

 

The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

 

  • During embryonic development, the aortic arches give rise to several structures in the neck and chest.
  • The 6th arch artery, which is present on both the right and left sides, gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus.
  • As the arch arteries regress and are replaced by the adult structures, the recurrent laryngeal nerves, which innervate the muscles of the larynx, become trapped behind the great vessels.
  • The distal 6th arch artery vanishes on the right side. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery, which becomes the future right subclavian artery, because there is no 5th arch artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on its way to the larynx.
  • In the case of the long left recurrent laryngeal nerve, the nerve passes inferior to the ligamentum arteriosum, which is a remnant of the ductus arteriosus that is derived from the 6th arch artery.
  •  This can lead to an increased risk of injury to the nerve during surgical procedures involving the thorax or neck.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 3rd pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and the proximal part of the internal carotid arteries.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: It is not directly related to the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, its persistence or anomalies don't affect the recurrent laryngeal nerve's course.

 

Option B. 4th arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 4th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the left side into the arch of the aorta and on the right side into the right subclavian artery.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which arises from the vagus nerve, initially descends and then ascends around the 4th arch artery. However, this is not responsible for the long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. 5th arch:

 

  • Derivative: Interestingly, in many cases, the 5th pharyngeal arch artery is rudimentary or even absent in humans. When present, it doesn't form any significant structures in the mature circulatory system.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Given its rudimentary nature, the 5th arch artery doesn't have a defined relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.

 

Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

 

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

 

Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.

 

Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.

questions.text: Identify the drug used to treat the condition shown below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anti-tubercular therapy

 

  • The image showing a plaque with one margin extending & other margin healing with scarring (Asymmetrical lesion), this favors to the diagnosis of lupus vulgaris, which is treated using anti-tubercular drugs.
  • It is the most common cutaneous tuberculosis in adults in India.
  • It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity.
  • Granulomas with little to no caseation can be seen on histology.

 

Lupus Vulgaris

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of skin TB seen in patients with moderate immunity to TB bacilli
  • It is seen more common in females.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • It occurs due to hematogenous, lymphatic, or contiguous spread from elsewhere in the body, or from exogenous inoculation. It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity, hence Paucibacillary.

 

Clinical features

 

  • It presents as single or few lesions which are well demarcated, annular plaques which extend centrifugally. Periphery show erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules as seen in the image below.

 

 

  •  They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face. Center is depigmented with paper-thin scar with nodules.
  • Papules may recur on the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Histologic examination & a positive culture for M. tuberculosis/ bovis confirm the diagnosis
  • Most prominent histopathologic feature: Typical granulomas with scanty or absent caseation.

 

Complication

 

  • Secondary scarring & squamous cell carcinomas may develop rarely.

 

Treatment:

Anti-tubercular drugs.

 

CLASSIFICATION OF CUTANEOUS TUBERCULOSIS IS BASED ON THE MODE OF ACQUISITION:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical steroids therapy:

  • This is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris.
  • Topical steroids are used for inflammatory conditions, and while they may reduce inflammation and symptoms temporarily, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection that causes lupus vulgaris.

 

Option B. Anti-leprosy treatment:

  • Although leprosy is also caused by a mycobacterium (Mycobacterium leprae) and anti-leprosy drugs are used to treat it, the clinical features described do not match leprosy.
  • Moreover, the treatment regimens for leprosy and tuberculosis are different.

 

Option C. Anti-fungal therapy:

  • Fungal infections can present with skin lesions, but the description of the lesion as characteristic of lupus vulgaris does not fit a fungal infection.
  • Anti-fungal therapy would not be effective against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by irregular plaques that show progression at one margin and healing with scarring at another, and to understand that the appropriate treatment is a multi-drug anti-tubercular therapy regimen.

 

References:

 

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 27.21-27.23, 32.35-32.36, 33.44-33.45

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

 

  • This is an echocardiogram that is performed while the heart is under the stress of increased workload. If a patient cannot exercise, a drug called dobutamine is administered to simulate the effects of exercise on the heart.
  • The test helps identify areas of the heart that may not be receiving enough blood due to blockages in the coronary arteries. A significant change in the motion of the heart wall during the test is a strong predictor of perioperative cardiac complications, making this test highly valuable in the mentioned context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exercise ECG testing: Exercise ECG testing, also known as exercise stress testing or treadmill testing, involves the patient exercising on a treadmill or stationary bicycle while their heart rate, blood pressure, and electrocardiogram (ECG) are monitored. The purpose is to determine how the heart responds to the stress of exercise. Abnormal changes in the ECG during or after exercise may suggest coronary artery disease (CAD). While this test can indicate the presence of CAD, it does not specifically predict perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option C. Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy: Also known as a nuclear stress test, this investigation involves injecting a small amount of radioactive substance into the patient and using a special camera to visualize how blood flows through the heart muscle, both at rest and during stress (either exercise or with a medication). This test can identify areas of the heart that aren't getting enough blood, indicative of CAD. While it can detect and evaluate the severity of CAD, it's less specific than dobutamine stress echocardiography in predicting perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option D. Coronary angiography: This is a procedure in which a contrast dye is injected into the coronary arteries, and X-rays are taken to visualize the flow of blood through these arteries. It is used to directly visualize blockages in the coronary arteries. As the "gold standard" for diagnosing CAD, coronary angiography can provide detailed information about the location and severity of blockages. However, it's an invasive procedure, involving threading a catheter through the blood vessels to the heart, and carries risks such as bleeding, allergic reactions, or kidney damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dobutamine stress echocardiography is the most accurate non-invasive investigation for predicting perioperative cardiac complications due to its ability to simulate exercise and identify areas of the heart with reduced blood flow.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 935

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in treatment of the above condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IV digoxin

 

The condition described in the scenario is likely High-Altitude Headache (HAH) and High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), which can occur due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

 

Digoxin is a medication primarily used for the treatment of heart conditions, such as heart failure and certain irregular heart rhythms like atrial fibrillation therefore, digoxin is not used for the above condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate Descent: This is the most effective treatment for HAPE and other altitude sickness symptoms. Descending to lower altitudes where the air pressure is higher can alleviate symptoms by increasing the available oxygen.

 

Option C. Administration of Oxygen: Providing supplemental oxygen can help alleviate the symptoms of hypoxia experienced at high altitudes, directly addressing the oxygen deficit caused by the thin air.

 

Option D. Tablet Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that helps prevent and reduce the symptoms of altitude sickness. It works by acidifying the blood, which stimulates breathing, increasing oxygen intake and helping the body adjust to changes in altitude.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barometric pressure, partial pressure of oxygen and common effects at different altitudes

 

 

Treatment

 

  1. Oxygen supplementation
  2. Move to a lower altitude
  3. Acetazolamide – stimulates respiration and reduced intracranial pressure
  4. Portable hyperbaric bags (E.g., Gamow bag) simulate descent to a lower altitude.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to morpholines? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amorolfine

 

  • Amorolfine is a morpholine that is available as a 5% nail lacquer. Amorolfine inhibits two separate stages in the synthesis of ergosterol and is fungicidal.
  • It is used in the treatment of onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxiconazole:

  • This is an azole antifungal drug.
  • Azoles work by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial in converting lanosterol to ergosterol.

 

Option C. Ciclopirox olamine:

  • Ciclopirox is a hydroxypyridone antifungal agent, not a morpholine.

 

 

  • It acts by chelating polyvalent cations, resulting in the inhibition of the metal-dependent enzymes responsible for the degradation of peroxides within fungal cells.

 

Option D. Tioconazole:

 

Tioconazole is another azole antifungal agent and, like oxiconazole, works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amorolfine is the only morpholine derivative, used as a nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections.

 

Reference - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 18 Page no 18.12

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20737634/

https://ijdvl.com/onychomycosis-diagnosis-and-management/

questions.text: A 56-year-old male recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, with imaging indicating a tumor size less than 4 cm, what would be the most suitable initial treatment approach for this patient's condition among the following options? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial nephrectomy

 

For tumors less than 4 cm, the recommended procedure is a partial nephrectomy, also known as nephron-sparing surgery.

 

  • This procedure involves removing the tumor and a small margin of healthy tissue surrounding it while leaving the remainder of the kidney intact. It is the recommended treatment for smaller renal tumors, typically less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a tumors). For the 56-year-old patient with a renal tumor less than 4 cm, partial nephrectomy is the preferred initial treatment approach as it aims to treat the cancer while preserving as much kidney function as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Partial nephrectomy + neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is generally resistant to chemotherapy, making this option less relevant for the patient's situation given the size of the tumor.

 

Option C. Radical nephrectomy: This procedure involves the removal of the entire affected kidney, the adrenal gland above the kidney, surrounding fatty tissue, and sometimes nearby lymph nodes. It is the preferred treatment for larger tumors or those that have started to spread outside the kidney. For a tumor less than 4 cm, and with no indication of it having spread, a radical nephrectomy may be more aggressive than necessary.

 

Option D. Radical nephrectomy + postoperative radiotherapy: Renal cell carcinomas are resistant to radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial nephrectomy is the recommended initial treatment for renal cell carcinoma tumors less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a), as it aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much kidney function as possible. This approach balances oncological control with the preservation of renal function.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

choices.text: Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
Defective peristalsis
Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus 

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

 

The LES relaxes during swallowing due to the release of nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide from inhibitory neurons, as well as the interruption of normal cholinergic signaling. These inhibitory neurons degenerate in achalasia cardia, resulting in decreased NO and VIP release. This results in increased LES tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, there is incomplete relaxation of the LES, not relaxation.

 

Option B. Defective peristalsis: While this statement is related to achalasia cardia, it is not the most accurate or complete description of the pathology. The correct answer focuses specifically on the decreased release of NO and VIP, which directly explains the increased LES tone and subsequent symptoms.

 

Option D. Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, the tone of the LES is increased, not decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:

 

  1. Incomplete relaxation of LES
  2. Increased tone of LES
  3. Absent peristalsis (aperistalsis)

questions.text: All of the following are contraceptive methods used post-coitus except? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Danazol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post coitus contraception means emergency contraception
  • Danazol is an androgen similar to testosterone and is used in endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B CuT200: CUT200 is an intrauterine contraceptive device which can be used in emergency contraception (up to 120 h/ 5 days post coitus)

 

Option C. RU486: RU486 is Mifepristone. This is an anti-progesterone and can be used for emergency contraception)

 

Option D. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: Combined high dose OCPs – used as Yuzpe’s regime, is a method of post-coital/ emergency contraception 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of migration of neural crest cells

 

Hirschsprung disease is caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall.

 

Hirschsprung disease, also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon, occurs when the normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum is interrupted or the ganglion cells die prematurely. This results in a distal intestinal segment with neither the Meissner submucosal nor the Auerbach myenteric plexus ("aganglionosis"). Coordinated peristaltic contractions are absent, and functional obstruction occurs, resulting in proximal dilation.

 

The absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel leads to an inability to coordinate peristaltic contractions, resulting in functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation. This can lead to symptoms such as abdominal distension, constipation, and failure to pass meconium shortly after birth.

 

The diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is made based on a combination of clinical presentation, radiographic findings, and histologic examination of rectal biopsy specimens. Treatment typically involves surgical resection of the aganglionic segment of the bowel, followed by re-anastomosis or creation of a colostomy.

 

Complications of Hirschsprung disease include enterocolitis, fecal impaction, and even sepsis, so early diagnosis and prompt treatment are important to prevent these complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of ganglion cells: While the result of the disease is a bowel segment lacking ganglion cells, the primary cause is the failure of migration of neural crest cells rather than a secondary loss of ganglion cells.

 

Option C. Visceral myopathy: Visceral myopathy involves primary muscle pathology of the bowel, which is not the cause of Hirschsprung disease.

 

Option D. Obstruction by inflammatory stricture: Inflammatory strictures are not related to the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease, which is due to congenital aganglionosis rather than inflammation or stricture formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung disease is primarily caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall during embryonic development, resulting in aganglionosis in the distal bowel and leading to functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

 

Explanation:

 

Leaves of broad ligament:

 

  • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include:
    • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni: Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
    • Koblet’s tubules: Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
    • Epoophoron: Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
    • Para-oophoron: Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
    • Gartner’s duct: Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.

 

Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A patient presented with biliary colic. The intern has administered an analgesic, following which the pain got aggravated. Which of the following could be responsible for the aggravation of the patient's symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Morphine

 

  • Morphine can cause the contraction of the sphincter of Oddi, which is a muscular valve that controls the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the small intestine.
  • In patients with biliary colic, the contraction of the sphincter of Oddi can exacerbate the pain and lead to complications such as pancreatitis.
  • Therefore, in patients with suspected biliary colic, it is important to use caution when administering morphine and to consider alternative analgesic medications such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or pethidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that does not cause sphincter of Oddi contraction and is unlikely to aggravate biliary colic.

 

Option C. Nefopam: Nefopam is a non-opioid analgesic that does not affect the sphincter of Oddi and is not likely to aggravate biliary colic.

 

Option D. Etoricoxib: Etoricoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor, another type of NSAID, which does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi and is not likely to aggravate biliary colic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Morphine can exacerbate pain in biliary colic by causing contraction of the sphincter of Oddi. In patients with suspected biliary colic, alternative analgesic medications such as NSAIDs or pethidine should be considered to avoid worsening the condition.

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi Square test

 

The Chi Square test can be used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. In this case, the two variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban), both of which are Qualitative characters.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired T test:  is used when comparing the means of two related samples, such as before and after measurements for the same group.

 

Option C. Standard error of the mean:  is a measure of the variability of sample means.

 

Option D.  ANOVA:  is used to compare the means of three or more groups.

These tests are not appropriate for analyzing the relationship between two categorical variables as in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calymmatobacterium granulomatis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacterium granulomatis.
  • It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Option C. Ureaplasma urealyticum: Causes urethritis

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: Causes syphilis

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: During an ocular examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of the shifting fluid sign in the patient. This finding suggests that the patient might have which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exudative RD

 

  • Shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.
  • In serous retinal detachment, there is subretinal accumulation of serous fluid mostly due to breakdown in blood-retinal barrier.
  • Fluid shifts to the dependent portion when head position is altered.
  • Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration and lacks a retinal tear or preretinal traction.
  • Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells, and retinal breaks.
  • Traction RD has a concave configuration, absent breaks, and severely reduced retinal mobility.
  • Shifting fluid is absent in traction RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction RD: Tractional retinal detachment is caused by fibrovascular proliferation and contraction of epiretinal membranes, leading to mechanical traction on the retina. It has a concave configuration and lacks shifting fluid due to the tethering of the retina by fibrous tissue. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and retinal breaks are usually absent.

 

Option C. Rhegmatogenous RD: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal tear or hole that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. It presents with signs such as tobacco dust (Shafer's sign) in the anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood, inflammatory cells, and visible retinal breaks. Shifting fluid is not a characteristic feature of rhegmatogenous RD.

 

Option D. Retinal Dialysis: Retinal dialysis is a type of retinal tear that typically occurs at the ora serrata, where the retina is particularly thin and prone to tearing. It is most often seen in younger patients or those who have experienced trauma. Shifting fluid is not a specific feature of retinal dialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

The clinical presentation described suggests lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by filarial worms. Lymphatic filariasis commonly leads to lymphedema, especially of the extremities, due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels by the parasites. The characteristic finding of limb swelling that is more pronounced proximally than distally is typical for lymphatic involvement.

 

Night Blood Test for Worms: This is the appropriate diagnostic test as filarial worms are nocturnally periodic, meaning that the microfilariae (larval stage of the filarial worm) are present in peripheral blood predominantly during the night (between 10 pm and 4 am). This periodicity aligns with the feeding patterns of the mosquito vectors that transmit the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: This would typically be used to assess heart function and structure, especially relevant given her history of coronary artery disease, but it would not be useful for diagnosing conditions affecting the lymphatic system like filariasis.

 

Option C. Duplex venous scan of limbs: This test assesses venous circulation and could help rule out venous thrombosis or other venous insufficiencies but would not be the first choice when filariasis is suspected.

 

Option D. ECG: While important for monitoring heart conditions, an ECG would not provide information relevant to diagnosing or managing lymphatic swelling due to filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. What is the ideal agent for distention? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal saline

 

 Explanation:

 

  • In bipolar cautery, electricity has to be conducted from one electrode to the other. So normal saline is preferably used.
  • If a monopolar resectoscope is used, then a non-electrolyte solution like glycine is required.

 

Fluid media in Hysteroscopy:

 

The following distension media can be used in hysteroscopy

 

  • CO2: Good for diagnostic procedures but not for operative hysteroscopy
  • Normal Saline
    • Not to be used with monopolar electrocoagulation
    • Good for minor procedures using bipolar instruments/ office procedures as there is very less risk of electrolyte imbalance
  • Dextran 70
    • Useful in patients with bleeding as it does not mix with blood
    • Can cause anaphylaxis, electrolyte imbalance ans fluid overload
  • Low viscosity, nonconductive fluids like: 1.5% Glycine, 3% sorbitol and 5% mannitol
    • Used in operative hysteroscopy using monopolar resectoscopes
    • Safe as there is no electrolytes to disperse the current and impede the electrosurgical effect
    • Associated with electrolyte disturbances and fluid overload

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal saline is the ideal distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery due to its suitability in conducting electricity between electrodes without causing significant electrolyte imbalance.

 

Ref: Page no 793, Novaks Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated her by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her forearm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulled elbow

 

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years of age group.
    • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
    • X-rays are normal.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia. 
    • Immobilization is not necessary.
    • Supination is a gravity-assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of elbow. Elbow Dislocations in the pediatric population usually occur in older children (10-15 years) and can be associated with elbow fractures such as medial epicondyle fractures. Male: female = 3:1. Very rare in younger children < 3 years old. Mechanism of injury is fall on an outstretched hand. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow, attempts at motion are painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiographs shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship. Treatment is usually closed reduction and brief immobilization for 1-2 weeks. 

 

 

Option C. Fracture head of radius. Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow. In children, radial neck fractures are more common than radial head fractures. Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity. It may lead to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint, weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radioulnar joint with heavy activities, and may produce cubitus valgus deformity.

 

 

Option D. Fracture coronoid process. Coronoid Fractures are traumatic elbow fractures that are generally pathognomonic for an episode of elbow instability. The patient presents with elbow deformity & swelling, elbow/forearm/wrist pain. On inspection & palpation, there is varus or valgus deformity, ecchymosis & swelling, and diffuse tenderness. The treatment involves brief immobilization, followed by early range of motion. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of traction on elbow with forearm in pronation in a child < 4 years of age is a classical feature of pulled elbow.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

  • Intense vaginal itching and foul-smelling greenish discharge are suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.
  • Strawberry like appearance of the cervix helps in establishing the diagnosis.
  • On vaginal smear, flagellated organism (T. vaginalis is seen)

 

Other Options:

 

Best understood by this table given below

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling, frothy yellowish-green discharge and a strawberry-like appearance of the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hair growth

 

  • Hair growth (Pubarche): The development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.
  • Estrogen effects: Estrogen plays a crucial role in various aspects of puberty, including:
    • Breast development (thelarche)
    • Development of internal genitalia
    • Menarche
    • Regulation of growth spurt
    • Epiphyseal closure
    • Cervical mucus plug formation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical mucus secretion: Estrogen is responsible for the secretion of cervical mucus.

 

Option C. Vaginal cornification: Estrogen promotes the cornification (maturation) of the vaginal epithelium.

 

Option D. Menstruation: Estrogen is critical in regulating the menstrual cycle and the onset of menarche.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hair growth during puberty is mediated by testosterone, not estrogen. Estrogen is responsible for breast development, internal genitalia development, menarche, growth spurt regulation, epiphyseal closure, and cervical mucus secretion.

 

Ref: Page no 531, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pre-gestational diabetes

 

Explanation

 

The image shows a condition known as mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia, which is a rare congenital deformity characterized by the fusion of the lower limbs. This condition is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is strongly linked to maternal pre-gestational diabetes.
  • Overt diabetes mellitus during pregnancy is known to cause various congenital anomalies, with cardiac anomalies being the most common, specifically ventricular septal defects (VSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes typically occurs later in pregnancy and does not usually cause congenital anomalies, as organogenesis is largely complete by the time gestational diabetes is diagnosed.

 

Option C. Effect of valproate: Valproate exposure during pregnancy is associated with neural tube defects, facial anomalies (such as cleft lip and palate), and cardiac anomalies, but not sirenomelia.

 

Option D. Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers reduce fetal renal perfusion, leading to conditions such as oligohydramnios and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia, but they do not cause sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-gestational diabetes is associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies, including mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia), characterized by the fusion of lower limbs.

 

Ref: Page 384, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Superior cerebellar

 

  • Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.
  • The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) is a branch of the basilar artery and supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, the roof nuclei, and parts of the midbrain.
  • When there is a thrombosis (formation of a blood clot) in the SCA, the blood supply to these areas is disrupted, which can cause various neurological symptoms such as ataxia, incoordination, and dizziness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cerebral artery (PCA): It supplies blood to the occipital lobe, parts of the temporal lobe, and the inferomedial portion of the thalamus.

 

  • Thrombosis of the PCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of half of the field of vision in both eyes)
    • Memory impairment (if it affects the hippocampus)
    • Alexia without agraphia (an inability to read without an inability to write) if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

 

Option B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It supplies blood to the majority of the outer convex brain surface, including the frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes.

 

  • Thrombosis of the MCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss (mainly of the face and upper limb)
    • If the dominant hemisphere (typically the left in right-handed individuals) is affected, expressive aphasia can occur.
    • If the non-dominant hemisphere is involved, spatial neglect might be observed.

 

Option C. Internal carotid artery (ICA): It does not give off any significant branches in its cervical or petrous portions. Its terminal branches in the brain are the MCA and ACA (anterior cerebral artery). Thrombosis of the ICA can compromise blood flow to both the ACA and MCA territories, leading to a combination of the symptoms associated with obstruction of those arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of cerebellum:

 

  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Common symptoms of cerebellar lesions:

choices.text: Cannot comment without d-dimer values

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High

 

The Well's Score is a clinical tool used to estimate the probability of a pulmonary embolism (PE). The score is calculated based on various risk factors and clinical features. In this patient's case:

 

Modified wells criteria: 3 + 3 + 1.5 = 7.5 (>4) suggestive of high risk.

 

 

Inference:

 

  • 4: PE Likely
  • < 4: PE unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When assessing the risk of pulmonary embolism, especially in postoperative patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of DVT, it is essential to consider both the clinical presentation and the surgical history. The Wells score is a valuable tool in stratifying the risk and guiding further diagnostic testing and management. In this scenario, the patient falls into a high-risk category, indicating that further immediate investigation, typically with imaging like a CT pulmonary angiogram, is warranted.

 

Reference - UpToDate/Wells score

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Caesarean section

 

  •  The patient is a case of 
    • Preeclampsia 
    • Twin pregnancy (1st twin breech)
  • She is 38 weeks
  • As she is preeclamptic and has crossed 37 weeks, treatment would be to deliver her immediately. 
  • As the 1st twin is non cephalic, the mode of delivery is a cesarean delivery. 
  • Indications of cesarean delivery in multiple pregnancy:        
    • 1st twin non cephalic
    • Monoamniotic monochorionic twins
    • Conjoined twins
    • Triplets and above

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitor BP and terminate if BP rises: There is no indication to wait any longer as even in mild pre-eclampsia, delivery is done at 37 weeks. Waiting any longer is simply subjecting both mother and fetus to risks.

 

Option C. Terminate at 40 weeks: Again, this should not be done as in pre-eclampsia, delivery is planned at 37 weeks (mild) and 34 weeks (severe). This patient is already 38 weeks gestation

 

Option D. Induce labor with PGE2 gel: This patient should be delivered by cesarean section as she has twin babies, the 1st of twin is breech (non-cephalic). This becomes an indication for an elective LSCS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of preeclampsia with twin pregnancies where the first twin is in a breech position at 38 weeks, immediate cesarean section is the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:
