Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes and COPD developed post-operative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short-term treatment of the condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bethanechol

 

Bethanechol is a muscarinic agonist that stimulates the bladder's detrusor muscle to contract, thereby promoting urination. It is specifically used in the treatment of post-operative urinary retention. However, caution is required when prescribing bethanechol to patients with COPD or asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction through its action on M3 receptors in the bronchus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tamsulosin: Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker primarily used to treat urinary symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It is not used for post-operative urinary retention.

 

Option C. Terazosin: Terazosin is another alpha-1 adrenergic blocker used for BPH and hypertension. It does not have a role in treating post-operative urinary retention.

 

Option D. Methacholine: Methacholine is a muscarinic receptor agonist used in the diagnosis of asthma by performing the bronchial challenge test. It is not used for treating post-operative urinary retention and can precipitate bronchoconstriction, making it unsuitable for patients with COPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bethanechol is used for the short-term treatment of post-operative urinary retention by stimulating the bladder's detrusor muscle. Despite its potential to cause bronchoconstriction in patients with COPD, it is the only suitable drug among the given options for this condition.

questions.text: An individual seeks to explore the correlation between smoking and lung cancer. To do so, they gather information on individuals diagnosed with lung cancer from government hospitals, along with data on the quantity of cigarette packets sold during the corresponding timeframe. What category of study does this represent? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ecological

 

In the given study, the unit of study is the population, and the data collected by the investigator is secondary in nature. Therefore, this type of study is an ecological study, also known as a correlational study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-Sectional Study: Involves collecting data at a single point in time from individuals to assess the prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

  • The unit of analysis is the individual, not the population.

 

Option C. Experimental Study: Involves the researcher manipulating one or more variables to observe the effect on an outcome.

 

  • There is no experimental intervention in the given study scenario.

 

Option D. Quasi-Experimental Study: Involves an intervention but lacks random assignment of participants to treatment or control groups.

 

  • Similar to experimental studies, quasi-experimental studies involve individuals, not population-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECOLOGICAL STUDY / CO-RELATIONAL STUDY

 

  • Done at a point of time [E.g. in 2023]
  • Used in Nutritional surveys, e.g. à Avg. fat intake = 20gm/day
  • Can’t calculate strength of Association or Prevalence
  • Based on secondary data [collected by someone else, studied by investigator]

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

 

History is suggestive of chronic diarrhea with malabsorption occurring at the proximal small intestine (duodenum+ jejunum) causing protein loss (ascites, weight loss diarrhea), Osteoporosis (calcium, magnesium), and Iron deficiency (anemia).

 

All above in a young patient should hint towards the possibility of celiac disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TSH levels: While important for evaluating thyroid function, symptoms of hypothyroidism can overlap with some celiac disease symptoms (like fatigue), but the gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies strongly point towards a primary gastrointestinal cause.

 

Option B. C-peptide levels: C-peptide tests are used to evaluate insulin production levels and are more relevant in the context of diabetes management, not indicated here.

 

Option C. Urine sugar and ketone: This test is used to diagnose and manage diabetes by detecting sugar and ketones in urine, not related to the suspected diagnosis of celiac disease based on the provided symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient presenting with symptoms consistent with malabsorption, including gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies like iron and calcium, testing for celiac disease with an IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody test should be considered as a critical diagnostic step. This helps in confirming the diagnosis and facilitating appropriate dietary and medical management.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Celiac disease/Chapter 325

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) APL and EPB

 

  • Finkelstein test has been shown which helps to diagnose de Quervain’s tenosynovitis (Inflammation of Abductor Pollicis Longus and Extensor Pollicis brevis).

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic.
  • The examiner places patients’ thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction.
  • In positive test, this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the thumb left free is relatively painless.

 

 

  • Differential diagnosis includes scaphoid non-union, arthritis at the base of thumb and intersection syndrome.
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis.
  • The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.

choices.text: Pre- invasive diagnostic test

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue pregnancy

 

Explanation

 

  • The risks for malformations, growth restriction, or abortion are not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).
  • Since diagnostic X-rays seldom exceed 0.1 Gy (10 rads), the risk is negligible. A 0.1 Gy exposure is equivalent to more than 1000 chest X-rays.
  • Hence, continuing pregnancy is the most appropriate advice to this woman.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Terminate pregnancy: Termination is not necessary as the radiation dose from a single chest X-ray is significantly lower than the threshold for increased risks.

 

Option C. Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This is not required in this scenario as the radiation dose is too low to justify invasive diagnostics.

 

Option D. Chromosome screening: Chromosome screening is unnecessary because the radiation dose from a chest X-ray does not significantly increase the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective

 

The risk for fetal malformations, growth restriction, or abortion is not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).

 

Ref: Page 2265, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: 5HT4 agonist
Dopamine antagonist

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diphenylmethane

 

Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug. It is a type of organic compound that is not used for the treatment of gastrointestinal motility disorders.

 

A prokinetic drug is a medication that increases gastrointestinal motility and promotes the movement of food through the digestive system. 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides are all types of prokinetic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5HT4 agonists stimulate the release of serotonin in the gut, which enhances gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option B. Dopamine antagonists block the action of dopamine in the gut, which can increase gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option C. Macrolides have antimicrobial properties and also act as motilin receptor agonists, which promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug and is not used to treat gastrointestinal motility disorders. Prokinetic drugs include 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides, which all act to enhance gastrointestinal motility.

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is disposed in the yellow bag? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood bag

 

Blood bag is disposed in the yellow bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gloves: Red bag.

 


Option C.  Sharps: White container.

 

Option D. Urine bags: Red bag.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers

 

Explanation  

 

The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

 

 

Pressure on a nerve due to sleeping with arms under the head leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. B fibers, which are generally involved in autonomic functions, are not the primary concern in this scenario involving motor and sensory disturbances.

 

Option C. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. It's the opposite; A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers, making them more likely to be compromised under mechanical compression.

 

Option D. Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves: Incorrect. The loss of function is not due to sleep per se but due to mechanical pressure affecting nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situations where pressure is applied to nerves, such as sleeping with an arm in a compromising position, the larger, myelinated A fibers (including motor fibers) are more susceptible to disruption compared to the smaller, unmyelinated C fibers. This leads to a loss of motor function and normal touch sensation, while pain sensation remains relatively intact due to the resilience of C fibers to mechanical pressure.

 

Relative susceptibility of nerve fibres –

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

 

The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.

 

It is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meats help easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

 

It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricle. Sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing.

 

Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

 

Option D: A cosmetic or reconstructive procedure aimed at correcting deformities or defects of the external part of the ear (pinna).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463

questions.text: If percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. what is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 22%

 

Explanation:

 

  • By Chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine. As Thymine is given as 28%, so total A+T is 56%.
  • Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds.
    Remaining 44% (100-56) equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, thymine (T) always pairs with adenine (A), forming a complementary base pair. Similarly, cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). The base pairing in DNA is always complementary, and the total percentage of purines (adenine + guanine) equals the total percentage of pyrimidines (thymine + cytosine).

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

 

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is crucial in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with syncope, particularly to rule out cardiac causes such as atrial fibrillation, which can lead to episodic reductions in cardiac output and cerebral perfusion. Atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia in the elderly, can cause transient episodes of dizziness and loss of consciousness due to irregular and often rapid heart rate leading to ineffective heart pumping.

 

Note - In an elderly w/ first episode of syncope detailed history, clinical exam (cardiac, postural BP, neuro exam), basic investigations (ECG, +/- ECHO) is required

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done: While a CT scan might be considered if there is suspicion of a neurological cause after a thorough clinical evaluation, it is not automatically the next step following a normal ECG, especially in the absence of neurological symptoms or signs suggestive of structural brain disease.

 

Option C. Tilt-table testing: This is generally reserved for cases where recurrent unexplained episodes of syncope occur, particularly when a vasovagal or orthostatic cause is suspected, not typically used after a first episode unless specific indications are present.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms: Vestibular neuritis can cause severe vertigo and imbalance but typically does not cause loss of consciousness, making it less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.

 

Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

 

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

 

Functions of pili:

 

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: While important for many cellular functions, the cytoplasmic membrane itself is not typically involved in adhesion.

 

Option B. Mesosomes: These are folded invaginations in the bacterial membrane thought to be artifacts of cell preparation and not involved in adhesion.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS): Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, LPS can play a role in interactions with the host immune system but are not primarily responsible for adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial polyp

 

  • The image is an ultrasound image of the uterus with a thickened endometrium.
  • The presence of a feeding vessel is very suggestive of an endometrial polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibroid uterus: Fibroid uterus would generally show a different pattern on ultrasound and is characterized by increased vascularity, but it wouldn't typically present with a single feeding vessel like an endometrial polyp.

 

Option C. Endometrial carcinoma: In endometrial carcinoma, the endometrium would be irregularly thickened with loss of endo-myometrial junction and cystic spaces with increased vascularity throughout.

 

Option D. Leiomyosarcoma: Leiomyosarcoma, similar to fibroids, would show increased vascularity but with more aggressive features and not a solitary feeding vessel as seen in polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a single feeding vessel in a mass seen on ultrasonography is highly suggestive of an endometrial polyp.

 

Ref: Page no 460, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: Where chemical waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow

 

Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male pt presented to your clinic with persistent non-pitting edema in their lower extremities as shown below. What could be the most likely reason for this symptom? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the likeliest cause.
  • It involves the build-up of protein-rich fluid in tissue interstitial spaces.
  • It shows typical “non-pitting” edema in the second stage of lymphedema.
  • Filariasis is the most common etiology.
  • In severe and long standing cases, skin changes are seen giving the limb an appearance of “Elephantiasis”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial Disorders: Arterial disorders may lead to symptoms such as leg pain, intermittent claudication, and tissue damage due to reduced blood supply. Edema is uncommon.

 

Option C. Venous Disorders: These disorders can encompass conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and venous ulcers. Venous disorders may result in symptoms like leg swelling, pain, and skin changes, and they can vary in severity. No evidence of skin changes associated with varicose veins are seen.

 

Option D. Coronary Heart Disease: Coronary heart disease (CHD), also known as coronary artery disease (CAD), is a common heart condition where the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become narrowed or blocked due to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis). CAD may lead to heart failure leading to bilateral lower limb pitting edema, which is not seen in the case above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphedema is characterized by non-pitting edema due to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the tissue interstitial spaces. It can lead to significant swelling and skin changes, particularly in the lower extremities, distinguishing it from other causes of edema.

choices.text: Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout
Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout
Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3-
Increased excretion of H+

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows pH= 7.30, HCO3= 10 mEq/L, paco2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

 

ABG shows pH 7.3 (acidosis) → Metabolic (HCO3- = 10)

 

Expected pCO2 = HCO3 +15 = 25 is < actual pCO2 (30) suggesting there is excess CO2 than expected. Hypoventilation leads to CO2 accumulation.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hyperventilation leads to excess CO2 washout: And would have reduced the pCO2 levels than the expected values.

 

Option C. Increased absorption of HCO3: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option D. Increased H+ excretion: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of metabolic acidosis, compare the actual respiratory response (PaCO2) with what is theoretically expected. Inadequate reduction in PaCO2, or relative hypoventilation, suggests partial compensation, highlighting a need for further intervention to correct the underlying acid-base disturbance.

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

 

The symptoms described are indicative of panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort that may include palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, and feelings of impending doom. These attacks can occur unexpectedly or in anticipation of a specific trigger, such as before an exam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms not explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition.

 

Option C. Social anxiety disorder is characterized by an intense fear of social situations.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities most days for at least 6 months, not limited to performance situations like exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom. The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

 

Distichiasis refers to the additional row of eyelashes behind the grey line. It may happen as a result of inherited or acquired factors.

 

The cornea may become irritated by these lashes. The treatment involves separating the lids and applying cryotherapy to the hair follicles' bases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichiasis: Refers to the misdirection of eyelashes that grow inward towards the eye, causing irritation and potential damage to the cornea. The lid margin remains in its normal position.

 

Option C. Tylosis: Refers to the thickening of the tarsal plate, often associated with chronic inflammation and lid margin disease, but not related to an extra row of eyelashes.

 

Option D. Madarosis: Refers to the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, which can be due to various causes including trauma, systemic diseases, and dermatologic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the options below is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) High LDL

 

High LDL: This is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome according to the NCEP-ATP III guidelines. While high LDL cholesterol is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease, it is not part of the metabolic syndrome criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertriglyceridemia: Elevated triglyceride levels are a criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicate dyslipidemia.

 

Option C. Central Obesity: Defined by waist circumference, this is a key criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicates visceral fat accumulation.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the criteria for metabolic syndrome, reflecting its association with increased cardiovascular risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, criterion for metabolic syndromes are:

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Optic tract

 

The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

 

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is a type of light reflex. The blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction on illumination, while the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary reaction.

 

It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumors of the optic thalamus.

 

Homonymous hemianopia HH is characteristically seen in optic tract pathway

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve: Incorrect. A lesion in the optic nerve typically results in a loss of vision in the eye served by the affected nerve but does not produce hemianopic pupillary responses. Instead, it might lead to a direct pupillary defect (also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or Marcus Gunn pupil).

 

Option C. Optic radiation: Incorrect. Lesions in the optic radiation cause visual field deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia) but do not affect the pupillary light reflex because the optic radiations carry visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex and are not involved in the reflex arc of the pupil light reflex.

 

Option D. Optic chiasma: Incorrect. Lesions at the optic chiasm typically cause bitemporal hemianopia due to the crossing of nasal retinal fibers at this location. This type of lesion affects the visual fields of both eyes but does not specifically result in a hemianopic pupillary response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lesion site for Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is the optic tract, which when damaged, leads to a characteristic pupillary response where the pupil does not react to light shown on the side of the retina corresponding to the damaged tract. This finding is indicative of a post-chiasmal visual pathway issue and is useful for localizing neurological damage in clinical assessments.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding in a patient with left heart failure? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Focal oligemia

 

Focal oligemia, also known as the Westermark sign, is a radiological finding indicative of pulmonary embolism, not heart failure. It represents a regional reduction in lung vascularity and is seen on chest radiographs as an area of decreased blood flow and enhanced clarity due to vascular obstruction from a clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiological Findings in Left Heart Failure:

 

Option A. Kerley B lines: These are thin linear opacities caused by interstitial edema, especially near the lung bases, and are commonly associated with congestive heart failure.

 

Option C. Increased venous blood in lung: Also known as pulmonary venous hypertension, this finding is due to increased pressure in the pulmonary veins that results from left heart failure.

 

Option D. Change in upper lobe circulation: This refers to the redistribution of blood flow to the upper lobes, a classic sign of pulmonary venous hypertension seen in left heart failure.

 

Further Stages of Left Heart Failure on CXR:

 

  1. Stage 1 (PCWP 13-18 mmHg): Cardiomegaly, redistribution of pulmonary vessels, broad vascular pedicle.
  2. Stage 2 (PCWP 18-25 mmHg): Kerley B lines and peribronchial cuffing indicating interstitial edema.
  3. Stage 3 (PCWP > 25 mmHg): Alveolar edema leading to consolidation and pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with suspected heart failure, radiological findings such as Kerley B lines, increased pulmonary venous pressure, and altered upper lobe circulation are indicative. Focal oligemia, however, suggests a differential diagnosis of pulmonary embolism and should prompt further investigation for this condition rather than heart failure.

 

 

Reference - Radiology assistant/ CXR in heart failure

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.

 

Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: Which drug is used as a first line management for postmenopausal female with osteoporosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases (pyrophosphate analogs) bind to the surface of hydroxyapatite crystals and inhibits resorption.
  • These drugs are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine.
  • Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss (as occurs with estrogen replacement therapy).
  • These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures.
  • These are the drugs of choice in postmenopausal osteoporotic females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raloxifene. Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) act as estrogen antagonist in breast tissue and as an agonist in bone. Raloxifene selectively stimulates estrogen receptor in bone and is used in treatment of osteoporosis. It reduces risk of breast cancer also.

 

Option C. Estrogen. Hormone replacement therapy is the mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis with estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Combined OC pills. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs) alleviate climacteric symptoms and might have a positive effect on BMD. Of note, progestin is the dominant component over estrogen in COCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first line drugs or drugs of choice to treat osteoporosis in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis has been experiencing visual changes, including blurry vision and halos around lights. She has been on medication for her rheumatoid arthritis for a couple of years now. Which of the following drugs she might be taking is known to get deposited in the cornea? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

 

Chloroquine, an antimalarial drug also used in rheumatoid arthritis, can get deposited in various ocular tissues, including the cornea and retina. Corneal deposits are usually reversible upon discontinuation of the drug but can lead to visual disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leflunomide: Leflunomide is an immunomodulatory drug used in rheumatoid arthritis but is not known for deposition in the cornea. It has a different side effect profile mainly affecting the liver and gastrointestinal system.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a commonly used drug for rheumatoid arthritis but does not get deposited in the cornea. It has its own set of side effects like bone marrow suppression, liver toxicity, and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Option D. Sulfasalazine: Sulfasalazine is also used for rheumatoid arthritis but is not known to deposit in the cornea. Its main side effects include gastrointestinal symptoms, skin rash, and rarely, hematologic abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloroquine, used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, can get deposited in the cornea, leading to visual disturbances such as blurry vision and halos around lights. This side effect is an important consideration in the long-term management of patients on chloroquine therapy.

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation is incorrect ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

 

The foramen ovale is an opening in the interatrial septum that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. After birth, as the baby begins to breathe and the lungs expand, the pressure in the left atrium increases relative to the right atrium, causing the flap-like valve of the foramen ovale to close.

 

Functional closure, where the valve is pressed shut due to the pressure difference between the atria, usually occurs immediately after birth. Anatomical closure, where the tissue actually grows together and seals the foramen, typically occurs within the first year of life, but not as quickly as 3 to 5 days. Hence, this statement is false.

 

Usually it takes anywhere between 1 to 12 months for the anatomical closure of foramen ovale

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days:

 

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly to the heart.
  • After birth, the ductus venosus constricts and eventually closes, typically within a few days to a week. It becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum venosum.

 

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent:

 

  • In fetal circulation, there are two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein. The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. It's noteworthy that only the left umbilical vein persists, while the right one regresses early in development. Hence, this statement is accurate.

 

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks:

 

  • The ductus arteriosus is a vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. It allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional for breathing.
  • After birth, increased oxygen concentration and decreased levels of certain prostaglandins cause the ductus arteriosus to constrict. Functional closure usually happens within the first couple of days after birth, and it undergoes anatomical closure (becoming the ligamentum arteriosum) typically within the first few weeks to months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350 mg/dL, pH - 7.2, HCO3- 10 mEq/L, pCO2 – 25 mmHg. What is the metabolic abnormality? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic acidosis

 

The patient presents with a significantly acidic pH (7.2) and a low bicarbonate level (HCO3- = 10 mEq/L), indicating metabolic acidosis. The pCO2 is also reduced (25 mmHg), which suggests a respiratory compensatory mechanism aiming to increase acid excretion (by hyperventilating to blow off CO2) to counterbalance the acidosis.

 

This presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a common complication of diabetes that leads to metabolic acidosis, elevated blood glucose, and electrolyte imbalances due to the production of ketoacids from the breakdown of fats. The high blood sugar level of 350 mg/dL supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect as the low HCO3- and acidic pH point to acidosis, not alkalosis.

 

Option C. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect as the low pCO2 is a compensatory response to the metabolic acidosis, not the primary disorder.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect as this would involve an elevated pCO2, opposite of what is observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of high blood sugar and the reported ABG values, metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis, should be considered. This condition requires prompt recognition and management, typically involving fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, and electrolyte management to reverse the ketosis and acidosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has been taking theophylline for bronchodilation. She now presents with a respiratory infection, and the physician is considering antibiotic therapy. Which of the following antibiotics should not be prescribed with theophylline? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythromycin

 

Erythromycin is known to inhibit the metabolism of theophylline, resulting in elevated blood levels of theophylline. This increases the risk of theophylline toxicity, which can lead to symptoms like nausea, vomiting, seizures, and even cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cefotaxime: Cefotaxime is a cephalosporin antibiotic and is generally not known to interact significantly with theophylline. It is a safer choice compared to erythromycin in patients on theophylline therapy.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: Cotrimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole and is not known to have a significant interaction with theophylline. It can be used safely in patients taking theophylline.

 

Option D. Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a penicillin antibiotic and does not have significant interactions with theophylline. It can be safely co-prescribed with theophylline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythromycin should not be prescribed with theophylline because it inhibits the metabolism of theophylline, leading to elevated blood levels and an increased risk of toxicity.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the following EEG finding? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM sleep

 

EEG recording is showing "Sawtooth waves" which are characteristic of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is also associated with rapid eye movements, muscle atonia (paralysis), and dreaming.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Transition between wakefulness and sleep, contains theta waves.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, characterized by delta waves.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep follows NREM sleep. EEG in REM sleep shows sawtooth waves and increased activity similar to awake state (beta activity) along with return of alpha activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 534.

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds
Secondary and Tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tertiary structure is three dimensional

 

Explanation:

 

The tertiary structure of proteins refers to the overall three-dimensional arrangement of a polypeptide chain, shaped by various interactions including hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and van der Waals forces. This structure is crucial for the protein's functional specificity, allowing the precise positioning of amino acid side chains necessary for biological activity. The three-dimensional nature of tertiary structure is essential for the functionality of enzymes and other proteins in biological systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary, secondary, and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation: Denaturation typically affects secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures, but the primary structure, which is the sequence of amino acids linked by peptide bonds, remains intact. Therefore, this statement is partially correct but not entirely.

 

Option C. Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds: Disulphide bonds primarily stabilize tertiary and sometimes quaternary structures by forming covalent links between different parts of the protein or between different protein subunits. Secondary structures like alpha-helices and beta-sheets are primarily stabilized by hydrogen bonds.

 

Option D. Secondary and Tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence: While this statement holds truth in that the primary sequence does dictate the secondary and tertiary structures due to the chemical properties of the amino acids involved, it's not the complete answer regarding the "true" statement sought by the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Structure of proteins –

 

  1. Primary structure of protein means the order of amino acids in the polypeptide chain and the location of disulfide bonds, if any.
  2. Secondary structure is the formed by folding of primary structure by hydrogen bonding between various residues. Example alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends
  3. Tertiary structure denotes the overall 3D arrangement formed by interactions of the various regions, or domains of a single polypeptide chain. The tertiary structure is maintained by noncovalent interactions between amino acid residue such as hydrophobic bonds, electrostatic bonds and van der Waals forces.
  4. Quaternary structure results when the proteins consist of two or more polypeptide chains held together by noncovalent forces like hydrogen bonds, electrostatic bonds, hydrophobic bonds and van der Waals forces.

 

There will be nonspecific alterations in secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures of protein molecules. Primary structure is not altered during denaturation.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome
Villous adenoma
Juvenile polyp

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

 

  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations. These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable. The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five. When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps. The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puetz Jegher syndrome: Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are neoplastic and present with a different histopathological pattern of finger-like or villous projections.

 

  • They are usually found in older adults and are not typically associated with painless rectal bleeding in children.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that can range from small polyps to large sessile lesions.

 

  • They do not exhibit the cystically dilated glands seen in juvenile polyps and are also more common in older adults.

 

Note - Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of rectal polyps in children under five, characterized by cystically dilated crypts and glands, and often present with painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G2P1

 

Explanation:

 

  • The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history as follows:
    • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
    • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages
    • L - Living children.
  • The GTPAL system includes the following:
    • Gravida
    • Term (>37 weeks)
    • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
    • Abortions (<20 weeks)
    • Number of living children

 

Obstetric Score

 

  • Gravidity:
    • G2 (Second pregnancy)
  • Parity:
    • P1 (One previous pregnancy reaching viability, twins count as one para)

 

So, the correct obstetric score for this lady is G2P1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gravida denotes the number of pregnancies, and para denotes the number of pregnancies reaching the period of viability. Twins count as one in the para score, and the current pregnancy is included in gravida but not in para until delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A young child complained to his parents that he was touched inappropriately by a neighbor.  On examination by a doctor in the OPD, he complained of pain when touched in the perianal area. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine pirate. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option D. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective

 

The Barberio test detects the presence of spermine from semen by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate, making it the correct test for the described scenario.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of hematuria. Upon examination, he is found to be normotensive and has pedal edema. Further investigations reveal a lack of glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. A renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below. Which of the following investigations should be conducted to identify the underlying disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti GBM antibodies

 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPG) is suspected based on the clinical history and microscopy showing crescents. Among the options presented, anti-GBM antibody testing should be performed because it is part of the RPGN work-up. 

 

HISTOLOGY:

 

Glomeruli — Regardless of the underlying cause, all forms of RPGN exhibit pathognomonic 'crescents' on the inside of Bowman's capsules. Crescents compress the glomerular tuft and obliterate the Bowman's space.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANA: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is used for diagnosing autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is more typically associated with Type II RPGN. It is not the primary investigation for Type I RPGN.

 

Option C. HIV RNA: This test is used for detecting HIV infection. While HIV can cause kidney disease, it is not specifically associated with the pathology seen in this case.

 

Option D. Urine immunoelectrophoresis: This test is used to detect abnormal proteins in the urine, such as in multiple myeloma. It is not relevant for diagnosing RPGN, specifically Type I RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testing for anti-GBM antibodies is crucial in the diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) with crescents on histology, particularly for identifying Type I RPGN (anti-GBM disease).

questions.text: Which of the following variables indicates the difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Attributable risk

 

The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk. Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Relative risk: Is a measure of the strength of association between exposure and disease, and it compares the risk of disease in exposed individuals to the risk in non-exposed individuals.

 

Option C. Population attributable risk: Is a measure of the Incidence of the disease that is likely to be reduced if the risk factor is modified/eliminated.

 

 

Option D. Odds ratio: Is a measure of the odds of exposure among cases compared to the odds of exposure among controls in a case-control study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attributable risk is the metric that indicates the difference in the incidence of disease between exposed and non-exposed groups, representing the proportion of disease occurrence attributable to the exposure.

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

 

Clinical history is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Presence of low TSH with suspected hypothyroidism indicates loss of Log relationship of TSH & fT4 indicating a central cause. Administration of TRH improving TSH level indicates TRH deficiency which is mainly produced from the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Hyperthyroidism due to pituitary:  Cause like TSHoma is very rare. Also, symptoms of thyrotoxicosis are not present in the patient.

 

Option B. In pituitary disease: TSH will not improve with TRH administration as the gland is defective and cannot produce TSH.

 

Option D. Thyrotoxicosis symptoms are not present in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a patient with hypothyroid symptoms and low TSH that responds to TRH administration, consider hypothalamic dysfunction as a probable cause. This is indicative of secondary hypothyroidism due to a lack of TRH production, affecting the pituitary’s secretion of TSH in the absence of exogenous stimulation.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hypothyroidism/Chap 383

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient? ( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1c

 

T1c: Correct. T1c is for tumors > 2 to ≤ 3 cm in size, which matches the patient's tumor size of 2.5 cm.

 

According to TNM staging, a patient with lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm is staged as T1c.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2b: Incorrect. T2b is used for tumors > 4 to ≤ 5 cm in size.

 

Option C. T2a: Incorrect. T2a is for tumors > 3 to ≤ 4 cm in size.

 

Option D. T1a: Incorrect. T1a is for tumors < 1 cm in size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TNM staging system for lung cancer uses tumor size and extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M) to classify the disease. A tumor measuring 2.5 cm is classified as T1c according to the TNM 8th edition criteria.

choices.text: Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

WISKOTT-ALDRICH SYNDROME (WAS)

 

  • It is a complex, recessive, X-linked disease

 

Mutations:

 

  • WASP gene (affect not only T lymphocytes but also the other lymphocyte subsets, dendritic cells, and platelets).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • WASP regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting cell and target cells.

 

Clinical manifestations:

 

  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Eczema
  • Bleeding caused by thrombocytopenia
  • Null mutations predispose affected individuals to invasive and bronchopulmonary infections, viral infections, severe eczema, and autoimmune manifestations.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Reduced-sized platelets on a blood smear.
  • Intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASP) expression in blood cells.

 

Treatment:

 

  • According to the severity of disease expression.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and careful topical treatment of eczema.
  • Although splenectomy improves platelet count in a majority of cases, this intervention is associated with a significant risk of infection (both before and after HSCT).
  • Allogeneic HSCT is curative, with fairly good results overall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B:  Chediak higashi occurs due to LyST (Lysosomal transfer protein) defect characterized by recurrent infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism

 

Option C: TAR is associated with thrombocytopenia at birth

 

Option D:  Hermansky-Pudlak occurs due to deficiency of dense granules in platelets characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, ILD, Granulomatous colitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is distinguished by its symptom triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections, directly related to mutations in the WASP gene affecting cellular function and immune response. Understanding these features is critical in diagnosing the syndrome and managing its complex clinical manifestations effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Immunodeficiencies/Chapter 351,374

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations. It is being transmitted with equal frequency from affected father to his daughters and son. So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.  The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome

 

Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue, including the skeleton, cardiovascular system, and eyes.

 

Important features of Marfan syndrome:

 

  • Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs and fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Aortic root dilation, which can lead to aortic aneurysm and dissection
  • Mitral valve prolapses
  • Lens dislocation, which can cause visual impairment or blindness
  • Skeletal abnormalities, such as scoliosis and chest deformities
  • Stretch marks (striae) on the skin that are not related to weight gain or loss
  • Joint hypermobility
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is made based on clinical features and genetic testing. Treatment typically involves management of cardiovascular complications, such as regular monitoring of the aorta and prophylactic aortic surgery, if necessary, as well as management of other symptoms such as lens dislocation and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

 

  • The ECG shows supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
  • The patient is also hemodynamically unstable, as indicated by the low blood pressure (70/40 mm Hg) and feeble pulse.
  • When a patient presents with SVT and hemodynamic instability, immediate rhythm conversion is essential.
  • The recommended treatment in such cases is direct current (DC) cardioversion.
  • This involves delivering an electric shock to the heart to restore a normal rhythm and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV adenosine: Adenosine temporarily slows or stops the heart's electrical activity and is often the first-line treatment for terminating stable, narrow complex supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). However, in hemodynamically unstable patients, its short-lived effects make it less suitable.

 

Option B. IV diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the rate in atrial fibrillation or flutter and certain types of SVT. In hemodynamically unstable patients, slowing the heart rate without converting the rhythm can be dangerous.

 

Option D. Ibutilide: Ibutilide is an antiarrhythmic drug used to treat certain types of atrial fibrillation or flutter. It's not the first-line treatment for hemodynamically unstable SVT and carries a risk of proarrhythmia, meaning it can sometimes cause new or worsening rhythm problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and hemodynamic instability, direct current (DC) cardioversion is the recommended and most effective treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1744

choices.text: BCR ABL

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PML-RARA

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

The long arm of chromosome 17 encodes the retinoic acid alpha receptor gene (RARA). It is primarily expressed in hematopoietic cells and plays an important role in gene expression regulation. RARA is bound by the nuclear corepressor factor in the absence of retinoid acid, causing transcriptional repression. RARA is activated in the presence of retinoic acid, and promyelocytes undergo terminal differentiation.

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a distinct subtype of acute leukemia distinguished by abnormal promyelocyte proliferation, life-threatening coagulopathy, and the chromosome translocation t (15;17) (q22;q11-12). This results in an abnormal fusion protein known as PML-RARA, which has a low affinity for retinoids. This inhibits transcription and thus prevents gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.

 

 

Rx: The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates DNA transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL: Associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

  • Treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib, not ATRA.

 

Option C. CMYC: Associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

 

  • Involves translocation t (8;14) affecting the c-Myc oncogene.

 

Option D. RUNX1-ETO: Associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with t (8;21).

 

  • Treated with standard chemotherapy regimens, not specifically ATRA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the t(15;17) translocation. This treatment promotes the differentiation of leukemic promyelocytes, improving clinical outcomes in APL patients.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human gonadotropin. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

  • The image is a transvaginal ultrasound showing the ovaries which appear significantly enlarged with fluid in the pelvic cavity (the black spaces seen in between the ovaries)
  • In view of her history of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation in IVF, the answer is OHSS
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability and leakage of intravascular fluid to the third space.
    • It is commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH or HCG injections.
    • Multiple enlarged follicles are arranged in a necklace pattern in bilateral ovaries.
    • The mainstay of management is conservative. The ongoing stimulation cycle is suspended, and further administration of exogenous gonadotropins are stopped in that cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Theca lutein cysts: Enlarged cysts seen in molar pregnancy, not related to the provided scenario or ultrasound findings.

 

Option C. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a risk factor for OHSS, but given the history and the ultrasound image, OHSS is the more appropriate answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OHSS is characterized by multiple enlarged ovarian follicles and fluid accumulation in the pelvic cavity, often occurring after exogenous gonadotropin administration in infertility treatments.

 

Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On US, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like
    • B/l renal agenesis
    • B/l dysplastic kidneys
    • B/l Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal anemia: Severe fetal anemia also can cause hydrops and polyhydramnios like in Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome and Rh iso-immunization

 

Option C. Barter syndrome and option D. Anencephaly cause polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral dysplastic kidneys, or bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease.

 

Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: A female patient has been receiving first-line pharmacological treatment for bipolar disorder for 6 months. She is fasting for religious reasons and is experiencing seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness. Which of the following tests should be performed to help diagnose her condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum lithium level

 

The patient's symptoms of seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness are highly suggestive of lithium toxicity. Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index, with toxicity often occurring at levels above 1.5 mEq/L. Fasting and dehydration can exacerbate lithium toxicity due to increased renal absorption of lithium, which occurs similarly to sodium under these conditions.

 

Given that the patient has been on first-line pharmacological treatment for bipolar disorder and her symptoms align with those of lithium toxicity, checking serum lithium levels is the most appropriate diagnostic step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium level: While potassium imbalances can cause muscle weakness and arrhythmias, these are less likely to be the primary issue given the patient's history of bipolar treatment and her current symptoms. Potassium levels do not directly explain the symptoms related to lithium toxicity.

 

Option C. ECG: An ECG might be useful in some scenarios to identify heart issues, but it is less likely to provide insights into the patient's symptoms related to bipolar treatment and fasting. It is not the first-line diagnostic test for suspected lithium toxicity.

 

Option D. Serum sodium level: While fasting might affect sodium levels, the kidneys typically compensate to maintain serum sodium levels. However, this compensation also increases lithium reabsorption, leading to toxicity. Measuring serum sodium levels alone is unlikely to provide a definitive diagnosis related to her symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum lithium level should be checked in a patient receiving lithium therapy for bipolar disorder who presents with symptoms such as seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness, especially in the context of fasting or dehydration. This is crucial to diagnosing and managing lithium toxicity.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intussusception

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and the barium study are characteristic of intussusception.

 

INTUSSCUSCPTION

 

  • Age: 6-8 months most common
  • Can be seen in adults due to a lead point like polyp or carcinoma.
  • C/F: Painful red currant jelly stools.
