  • Mc type: Ileocolic Intussusception.
  • Initial: USG

 

 

Target/ Donut/ Sandwich/ Pseudo-kidney sign

 

IOC/Gold standard: Barium most commonly done/Air/Saline enema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Volvulus: Typically presents with a massively dilated loop of bowel and may show a "whirl sign" on CT rather than the findings seen on this barium study.

 

Option C. Diverticulitis: Would show inflamed and sometimes perforated diverticula; barium would outline these pouches, not the pattern seen here.

 

Option D. Ulcerative colitis: Chronic inflammatory condition of the colon, typically demonstrates continuous colonic involvement with loss of haustra, mucosal edema, and ulceration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception in adults requires prompt diagnosis and often surgical intervention, especially when associated with a pathological lead point. The barium study is crucial for diagnosis, showing specific patterns like the "target" sign that aid in identifying this condition.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heart failure

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are indicative of congestive heart failure (CHF), specifically biventricular failure. The elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema are typical signs of right heart failure, which suggests poor venous return management by the heart. Additionally, the presence of crackles at the lung bases points to left ventricular failure, which often presents with pulmonary congestion due to backflow of blood into the pulmonary circulation. This combination points to heart failure involving both the left and right sides of the heart (biventricular failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: While this condition can cause symptoms of heart failure, the presentation would typically include other specific signs such as a systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border and possibly signs of dynamic outflow obstruction, which are not specifically mentioned here.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation could present with symptoms similar to heart failure; however, a hallmark sign would be a pan-systolic murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla, which isn't mentioned. The systemic signs such as hepatomegaly and ascites are less commonly associated with isolated mitral regurgitation unless it has led to significant heart failure.

 

Option D. Portal hypertension: This condition would explain hepatomegaly and ascites but would not typically include pulmonary symptoms like crackles at the lung bases or findings like elevated JVP and positive hepatojugular reflux without concurrent heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which of the following is the most likely primary cause? (NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

 

Enlargement of the inguinal lymph node is most commonly caused by the anal canal below the dentate line (which marks the border between the anal canal and rectum) goes into the inguinal lymph nodes. As a result, anal cancer occurring below the dentate line can lead to the enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes.

 

However, lymphatics from the anal canal above the dentate line (i.e., the rectum) drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes through superior rectal lymphatics.

 

Anal Cancer:  A malignancy that originates in the anal canal or anal margin.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage from the anal canal is to the inguinal lymph nodes. Hence, an enlarged inguinal lymph node can indicate the spread of a tumor from the anal region.
  • Clinical Relevance: Patients with anal cancer may present with anal bleeding, pain, or itching. Inguinal lymph node enlargement is an important sign to check for, as it indicates lymphatic spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the testes.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Therefore, testicular tumors typically spread first to these nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While testicular cancer can metastasize to the inguinal lymph nodes, it's an unusual pathway and typically occurs after a surgical procedure in the groin, which can disrupt the typical lymphatic drainage patterns.

 

Option C. Sigmoid Colon Cancer: Malignancy that arises from the sigmoid portion of the colon.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the sigmoid colon is to the colic nodes and then to the inferior mesenteric nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Inguinal lymph node enlargement is not a typical early site of metastasis for sigmoid colon cancer. More common metastatic sites include the liver and lungs.

 

Option D. Prostate Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the prostate gland.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the prostate is to the internal iliac lymph nodes and then to the external iliac nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While it's possible for prostate cancer to metastasize to the inguinal nodes, it's not the typical pattern of lymphatic spread. Symptoms of prostate cancer include urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty starting and maintaining a steady stream of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: Female on maize as a staple diet. History of diarrhea and lesion in the neck region. It is due to deficiency of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

This is a typical picture of Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causing pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by 4Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dermatitis (Casal’s Necklace) dementia and Death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc Deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pellagra

 

  1. Maize and Jowar in Diet: The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Jowar has high content of leucine which inhibits tryptophan to Niacin conversion.
  2. Carcinoid syndrome: In this, Trp is mainly used for serotonin formation causes deficiency of trp for Niacin synthesis.
  3. Malabsorption
  4. Drugs like Isoniazid as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

Explanation:

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.

 

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma should be considered in pediatric patients presenting with visual disturbances and evidence of a calcified mass in the suprasellar region on imaging. This diagnosis is important due to the potential impact on the optic pathways and pituitary gland function, requiring careful management.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quinsy

 

The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever.

 

EXAMINATION FINDINGS

 

  1. The tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen. Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillars
  2. Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  3. Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  4. Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy is commonly seen. This involves jugulodigastric lymph nodes.
  6. Torticollis. Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess

 

Investigations - Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent. Needle aspiration of an abscess provides material for culture and sensitivity of bacteria.

 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngitis: Typically presents with a sore throat and possible fever but lacks the severe localized symptoms and findings of quinsy.

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Would likely present with swelling and pain in the parotid gland area, externally visible.

 

Option C. Bezold's Abscess: An infection that spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, which would involve more distinct signs of ear and mastoid involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 299

choices.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula
Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Take the patient to the ICU and intubate

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

 

History is suggestive of tension pneumothorax and hence immediate decompression is required to maintain hemodynamic stability. Definitive management involves insertion of Chest tube/Pigtail in the triangle of safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV fluids with large bore cannula: While IV fluids are important in managing hypotension, they do not address the immediate life-threatening issue of tension pneumothorax and might actually exacerbate the patient's condition by increasing venous return and further compressing the heart.

 

Option C. Take the patient to the ICU and intubate: Intubation in the setting of tension pneumothorax without prior decompression can worsen the patient’s hemodynamic status by increasing intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Start positive pressure ventilation: Positive pressure ventilation could potentially increase the pressure in the pleural cavity, worsening the tension pneumothorax and leading to rapid hemodynamic deterioration.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is critical to stabilize the patient and prevent further cardiovascular compromise. This emergency procedure is a life-saving intervention that precedes further definitive management like chest tube insertion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pneumothorax/ Chap 294

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

  • Clinical scenario suggests cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Features include early involvement of lateral rectus palsy due to involvement of abducent nerve passing through the cavernous sinus.
  • Later involvement of oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, related to the lateral wall of cavernous sinus.

*image added

 

 

  • Other signs include proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Retinoblastoma: Occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

 

Option B. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
Decreased release of 02
It has less P50
It is less acidic

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

 

Explanation

 

The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

 

The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.

 

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.

 

Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased release of O2: Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.

 

Option C. It has less P50: Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.

 

Option D. It is less acidic: Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

choices.text: Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium
Thiazides act as an add-on drug to lithium
Thiazides increase the tubular resorption of lithium
Thiazides cause water loss thereby increasing lithium levels

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a long-standing history of bipolar disorder has been stable on lithium therapy. Recently, he was diagnosed with hypertension and started on thiazide diuretics. After a few days, he presented with coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. What is the likely mechanism of this interaction between lithium and thiazides? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiazides increase the tubular resorption of lithium

 

Thiazides reduce the excretion of sodium in the renal tubules. Lithium is reabsorbed in a manner similar to sodium, leading to its increased reabsorption and elevated blood levels, resulting in potential toxicity. In this clinical case, the patient's symptoms of lithium toxicity are most likely due to the thiazide-induced increase in tubular reabsorption of lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium: Lithium is primarily excreted unchanged by the kidneys, not metabolized. Thiazides don't affect lithium's metabolism.

 

Option B. Thiazides act as an add-on drug to lithium: There's no evidence that thiazides synergistically increase the toxic or therapeutic effects of lithium.

 

Option D. Thiazides cause water loss thereby increasing lithium levels: Thiazides do act as diuretics, but the primary mechanism of increasing lithium levels is through enhanced tubular reabsorption rather than water loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics increase the tubular reabsorption of lithium, leading to elevated blood levels and potential toxicity. This interaction is crucial to consider when prescribing thiazides to patients on lithium therapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. She is relieved of these symptoms by either walking or moving her legs. Which of the following drugs is used in treating the condition?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

 

The symptoms described by the patient are consistent with restless legs syndrome (RLS). Gabapentin, and pregabalin, belong to the alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands and have now become the preferred first-line treatments for many patients with RLS due to their effectiveness and good side effect profile.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Pramipexole: Pramipexole and other dopamine agonists were traditionally first-line agents but can have side effects, including augmentation (worsening of RLS symptoms over time with treatment), which makes them less favorable for long-term management.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is not a standard treatment for RLS.

 

Option D. Iron tablets: Iron tablets may be prescribed if a patient has iron-deficiency anemia, which can exacerbate RLS symptoms. However, they are not the primary treatment for RLS unless this condition is present.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an unpleasant sensation in the legs and an urge to move them, especially at night. It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, are first-line treatments.

 

Reference: The Management of Restless Legs Syndrome: An Updated Algorithm Silber, Michael H.Earley, Christopher J. et al. Mayo Clinic Proceedings, Volume 96, Issue 7, 1921 - 1937.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

It is an autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to gradually deteriorate, eventually leading to thyroid failure. It is most common in women between the ages of 45 and 65. The presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase causes it.

 

There is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland with an intact capsule morphologically. It is clearly separated from the surrounding structures.

 

There are two types of Hashimoto's thyroiditis: the classic form, which is more common, and the fibrosing variant, which occurs in only 10% of cases.

 

The classic form is distinguished by diffuse, symmetric, firm, and rubbery thyroid enlargement. The fibrosing variant has a firm, enlarged thyroid with surrounding tissue compression.

 

Histologically:

 

  1. Classic form has intense lymphocytic infiltration, atrophied thyroid follicles, and follicular epithelial cells that have degenerated into Hurthle cells (also called Askanazy cells, or oxyphil cells, or oncocytes).
  2. The fibrosing variant of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by significant fibrous replacement of thyroid parenchyma and a less prominent lymphoid infiltrate

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graves' disease: Characterized by hyperthyroidism, presence of anti-TSH receptor antibodies, and typically does not present with Hurthle cells.

 

  • Clinical features include exophthalmos, pretibial myxedema, and a diffusely enlarged hypervascular thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma: A type of thyroid cancer that presents with different histological features, such as follicular cell proliferation and capsular or vascular invasion, but not typically Hurthle cells.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of thyroid: Arises from parafollicular C cells and is associated with amyloid deposits and elevated calcitonin levels.

 

  • Histologically different from Hashimoto's thyroiditis and does not feature Hurthle cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which of the following locations does meiosis normally occur in the human body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

 

Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary.

 

  • Meiosis is the process by which gametes (sperm and eggs) are produced in sexually reproducing organisms.
  • It occurs only in germ cells and leads to the formation of haploid gametes.
  • To reduce the number of chromosomes to the haploid number of 23, meiosis requires two cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.
  • In females, meiosis occurs in the ovaries during fetal development, but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • After puberty, meiosis resumes and one ovum is produced each month.
  • In males, meiosis occurs in the testes and produces sperm.
  • Meiosis in the testes begins during puberty and continues throughout adulthood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal: The adrenal glands are located atop each kidney and are involved in the production of various hormones, such as cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids. Meiosis, the process by which germ cells divide to produce gametes with half the number of chromosomes, does not occur in the adrenal glands. Instead, the adrenal glands are involved in steroidogenesis or the production of steroid hormones.

 

Option C. Prepubertal testis: The testes are the male reproductive organs that produce spermatozoa (sperm cells) and testosterone. In males, meiosis begins during puberty. In the prepubertal testis, the germ cells are not yet undergoing meiosis to form mature sperm cells. These germ cells (spermatogonia) proliferate by mitosis during childhood but only enter meiosis to become spermatocytes and eventually mature spermatozoa after the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. Hypothalamus: It is a region of the brain responsible for various vital functions, including the release of hormones that regulate the pituitary gland. It is not involved in meiosis. Instead, it plays an essential role in regulating various physiological processes, such as body temperature, thirst, hunger, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a significant role in controlling the release of hormones from the anterior pituitary by producing releasing or inhibiting hormones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult ovaries are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.

 

After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes. Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: Which influenza virus was responsible for the 2009 pandemic? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) H1N1

 

The 2009 influenza pandemic, commonly referred to as the "swine flu" pandemic, was caused by the H1N1 influenza A virus. This virus emerged in Mexico and quickly spread worldwide, causing widespread illness and leading to a global pandemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H5N1: Known as the "bird flu" virus.

 

  • Year: First identified in 1997 in Hong Kong.
  • Impact: Primarily affects birds but can infect humans, causing severe respiratory illness.

 

Option C. H5N7: This subtype of influenza is not known to have caused any major pandemics or widespread outbreaks in humans.

 

Option D. H3N2: This subtype of influenza A virus is known to cause seasonal flu epidemics but was not responsible for the 2009 pandemic.

 

  • Year: H3N2 was involved in the 1968 influenza pandemic, known as the "Hong Kong flu."

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza Pandemics

 

SWINE FLU, H1N1 → 2009, Mexico

BIRD FLU, H7N9 → 2013, China

BIRD FLU, H5N1 → 1997, Hong Kong

BIRD FLU, H10N3 → 2021, China

questions.text: During a surgical procedure on a patient exhibiting symptoms indicative of peritonitis, a diverticular rupture is observed, accompanied by fecal peritonitis. What would be the corresponding stage according to the Hinchey's classification? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

Hinchey's Classification is used to describe the severity of perforated diverticular disease. It helps guide the management of diverticulitis by categorizing the condition into different stages based on the clinical presentation and severity of the disease.

 

Hinchey's Classification Stages:

 

  • Stage 0: Mild clinical diverticulitis with symptoms such as left lower quadrant abdominal pain, low-grade fever, and leukocytosis. Management typically includes oral antibiotics.
  • Stage Ia: Confined pericolic inflammation or phlegmon. This stage can be managed with antibiotics, with or without CT-guided drainage.
  • Stage Ib: Confined pericolic abscess. Similar to Stage Ia, management includes antibiotics, with or without CT-guided drainage.
  • Stage II: Distant abscess. This requires abscess drainage, often through percutaneous methods.
  • Stage III: Purulent peritonitis. This stage involves the presence of pus in the peritoneal cavity, usually managed with Hartmann's surgery.
  • Stage IV: Fecal peritonitis. This stage indicates the presence of fecal matter in the peritoneal cavity due to a perforated diverticulum, and it is managed with Hartmann's surgery.

 

In the given scenario, the patient has a diverticular rupture with fecal peritonitis, which corresponds to Stage IV in Hinchey's classification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Stage 1 is divided into Stage Ia and Stage Ib. Stage Ia involves confined pericolic inflammation or phlegmon, while Stage Ib involves a confined pericolic abscess. Neither of these stages includes peritonitis.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 involves the presence of a distant abscess. This stage does not include peritonitis and is managed with abscess drainage.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 involves purulent peritonitis, which includes the presence of pus in the peritoneal cavity. However, it does not involve fecal contamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hinchey's Classification of diverticulitis is essential for determining the appropriate management strategy. Stage IV in Hinchey's classification corresponds to fecal peritonitis, which requires immediate surgical intervention, typically Hartmann's surgery.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

The recommended course of action for a patient with a clean-cut injury who received their last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago is to administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid. This recommendation is based on the standard guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis in wound management.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of Regression

 

Coefficient of Regression can be used to calculate one variable using another variable.

 

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

 

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Coefficient of Correlation:  Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

 

Option C.  The Coefficient of Variation: Is a measure of the relative variability of a dataset.

 

Option D. The Coefficient of Determination: Is a measure that determines the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with a diagnosis of schizophrenia was started on an antipsychotic medication. Within a few weeks, he developed symptoms of Parkinsonism, such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and a shuffling gait. The medical team is considering prescribing an additional medication to manage these extrapyramidal side effects. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trihexyphenidyl

 

Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms like Parkinsonism that may arise as a side effect of antipsychotic medications. It can counteract the dopamine antagonism caused by antipsychotic drugs, thereby alleviating symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entacapone: Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease to prolong the action of levodopa. It's not typically used to treat drug-induced Parkinsonism.

 

Option C. Rasagiline: Rasagiline is a monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitor used primarily in Parkinson's disease. It's not commonly used for drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Pramipexole: Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist also used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease but is ineffective in treatment of extrapyramidal symptoms induced by antipsychotic medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trihexyphenidyl is the appropriate medication for managing extrapyramidal side effects, such as Parkinsonism, induced by antipsychotic medications. It works by counteracting the dopamine antagonism and restoring the balance between acetylcholine and dopamine in the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

Amiodarone is a class III anti arrhythmic drug. One of the adverse effects of amiodarone that is seen with long term therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive. Therefore, it is contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

The other adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism (Amiodarone is 40% iodine by weight), blue grey skin pigmentation, corneal deposits, constipation and bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sotalol: Sotalol is also a class III antiarrhythmic agent but does not have the same risk of pulmonary toxicity as amiodarone. It is generally considered safer for patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

Option C. Quinidine: Quinidine is a class I antiarrhythmic drug that is not associated with pulmonary toxicity. It has other potential side effects but is not contraindicated in interstitial lung disease.

 

Option D. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (lidocaine) is a class Ib antiarrhythmic agent primarily used for ventricular arrhythmias. It does not have pulmonary toxicity and is not contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease due to its potential to cause pulmonary fibrosis, a serious and potentially irreversible adverse effect. It is essential to consider this risk when prescribing antiarrhythmic therapy to patients with pre-existing lung conditions.

choices.text: Transcervical resection of septum

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.

 

 

Other Options

 

Metroplasty is a type of unification procedures in mullerian anomalies

 

Option A. Jones metroplasty and Option C. Tompkins metroplasty are for septate uterus but are not preferred now. As now the treatment of choice is hysteroscopic resection of the septa.

 

Option B. Strassman metroplasty: Strassman metroplasty is for bicornuate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the best corrective procedure for a septate uterus to improve obstetric outcomes, as it does not scar the uterus and allows for future vaginal deliveries.

 

Ref: Page no 659, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid. Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface. This in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B12 to be absorbed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: Incorrect as the primary site for folate absorption is the jejunum. While partial jejunal resection could impact folate absorption, the redundancy in folate absorption along the small intestine generally compensates unless the resection is extensive.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Incorrect because gastric ulcers are typically related to factors affecting the stomach lining, such as Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use, and are not directly caused by resections of the ileum or jejunum.

 

Option D. Constipation: Incorrect as constipation is more commonly associated with colonic function disruptions or changes in diet following gastrointestinal surgery, not specifically related to the ileum or jejunum resections which would more likely impact diarrhea due to reduced absorption capacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resection of the terminal ileum specifically compromises vitamin B12 absorption due to the loss of the primary site where the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is absorbed. This can lead to significant clinical issues related to vitamin B12 deficiency, such as anemia and neurological disturbances, unless managed with appropriate supplementation.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

 

  • Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

The sensation of insects or bugs crawling on or under the skin, known as "formication", is classically associated with cocaine use. While it can also be seen with the use of other stimulants, including amphetamines, it is most emblematic of cocaine intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cannabis: Typically results in effects like altered perception, increased appetite, and paranoia.

 

Option C. Amphetamine: Another stimulant that can lead to increased energy, euphoria, and sometimes similar tactile hallucinations.

 

Option D. Alcohol: Produces symptoms such as impaired judgment, slurred speech, and incoordination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cocaine intoxication can lead to tactile hallucinations, notably the sensation known as formication. This sensation, often described as feeling like bugs crawling on or under the skin, is a classic symptom of cocaine use and can lead to skin picking and resultant lesions. This is also known as cocaine bugs or magnun phenomenon.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

 

One of the most characteristic findings in respiratory distress syndrome is failure of the respiratory epithelium to secrete adequate quantities of surfactant, a substance normally secreted into the alveoli that decreases the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, therefore allowing the alveoli to open easily during inspiration.

 

The surfactant-secreting cells are type II alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. It appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

 

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 pneumocytes: Incorrect because although Type 1 pneumocytes cover a large surface area of the alveoli and are involved in the gas exchange process, they do not produce surfactant. The defect in Type 1 pneumocytes generally leads to issues with the structural integrity of the alveolar walls, not surfactant deficiency.

 

Option C. Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: Incorrect as these cells line the alveolar capillaries and are involved in the blood-air barrier for gas exchange. Defects in these cells can lead to issues like pulmonary edema but are not directly related to surfactant production or respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Option D. Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: Incorrect because these cells line the bronchial passages and are primarily involved in mucous production and the removal of particulates and pathogens from inhaled air. They are not involved in surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

questions.text: The graph below shows the relationship between the log(dose) and the response of three drugs, A, B, and C. Which of these drugs has the highest potency? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

  • The potency of a drug corresponds to the power of the drug. The drug which produces the response at a lower dose is more potent than another drug which produces the same response at a higher dose.
  • The more left the curve is on the DRC, the greater is its potency.
  • On the other hand, efficacy means the maximum response that is produced by a drug. In a DRC, the more the height of the curve, the more efficacious that drug is.

 

Therefore in this case,

 

  • The potency of Drug A > Drug B > Drug C
  • The Efficacy of Drug A = Drug B > Drug C

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a dose-response curve, the drug with the curve furthest to the left is the most potent because it produces the desired effect at the lowest dose. In this case, Drug A is the most potent.

questions.text: Which absorbs least water? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cellulose

 

Cellulose is an insoluble fiber that does not absorb water to a significant extent. It remains relatively dry when exposed to water and does not become gummy. Cellulose is known for its role in providing structure to plant cell walls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucilage: Mucilage is a type of soluble fiber that absorbs water and becomes gummy when mixed with it. It has the capacity to absorb a significant amount of water and is often used in various applications due to its water-absorbing properties.

 

Option C. Gums: Gums, such as guar gum and xanthan gum, are water-soluble fibers that can absorb water and form a gel-like consistency. They have the ability to absorb moderate amounts of water.

 

Option D. Pectins: Pectins are another type of water-soluble fiber found in plant cells. When pectins come into contact with water, they form a gel-like substance and can absorb a considerable amount of water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cellulose:

 

  • Most abundant natural polysaccharide
  • Unbranched                                     
  • Made up of β–Glucose residues
  • Acts as fibres in the diet (as β-bonds cannot be easily broken in body)

 

Ref - Lehninger 6th ed pg 257

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

The histopathological picture of the caseating granuloma, eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells (horse shoe shape), and lymphocytes, as well as the clinical history, indicate tuberculosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES: Tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leprosy: Skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis is characterized by caseating granulomas with eosinophilic necrotic debris, surrounded by epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes. This histopathological pattern, along with the clinical presentation of chronic cough and cervical lymphadenopathy, is indicative of tuberculosis.

choices.text: Inferior vena cava
Right atrium
Superior vena cava

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation

 

  • Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.
  • Fetal heart pumps large quantity of blood into the placenta for exchange of substances.
  • From placenta, the umbilical veins collect the blood, which has more oxygen and nutrients.
  • Umbilical vein passes through liver, some amount of blood is supplied to liver from umbilical vein, large quantity of blood is diverted from umbilical vein into the inferior vena cava through ductus venosus.
  • Liver receives blood from portal vein also.
  • In liver, the oxygenated blood mixes slightly with deoxygenated blood and enters the right atrium via inferior vena cava.
  • From right atrium, major portion of blood is diverted into left atrium via foramen ovale. Foramen ovale is an opening in intra-atrial septum.
  • Blood from upper part of the body enters the right atrium through superior vena cava. From right atrium, blood enters right ventricle.
  • Then, blood is pumped into pulmonary artery. From pulmonary artery, blood enters the systemic aorta through ductus arteriosus.
  • Only a small quantity of blood is supplied to fetal lungs. Blood from left ventricle is pumped into aorta.
  • Fifty percent of blood from aorta reaches the placenta through umbilical arteries.

 

 

Mixing potentially occurs at 4 sites:

 

  1. Left umbilical vein (Oxygen saturation ~80%) – Portal vein (Much bypassed by ductus venosus to Inferior Vena cava)
  2. Left umbilical vein – Inferior vena cava – Portal vein (Oxygen saturation of IVC blood is ~65%)
  3. Superior vena cava – Right atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale)
  4. Pulmonary veins – Left atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Incorrect. While the right atrium receives blood from the inferior vena cava, it also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava, leading to a mixture that has a lower oxygen concentration than the incoming blood from the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava: Incorrect. The superior vena cava carries deoxygenated blood from the head and upper limbs of the fetus, thus having a lower oxygen concentration.

 

Option D. Ascending aorta: Incorrect. Although the ascending aorta in the fetus does carry oxygenated blood, the highest concentration of oxygen is found in the blood before it reaches the heart, specifically in the inferior vena cava due to the direct input from the umbilical vein through the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation is found in the inferior vena cava due to its receipt of oxygen-rich blood from the umbilical vein, which has directly exchanged gases in the placenta. This setup is crucial for delivering a sufficient oxygen supply to the developing fetus.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell from a motorbike and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulbar urethra injury

 

  • Clinical Features: Swelling and bruising in the perineal area; difficulty passing urine; blood at the urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Surgical repair, which may involve primary anastomosis or placement of a suprapubic catheter, depending on the extent of the injury.

 

The presentation of being unable to urinate (urinary retention), the presence of blood at the urethral meatus (hematuria), and the swelling of the penis and scrotum are all indicative of a urethral injury, most likely at the bulbar segment given the described mechanism of injury.

 

The bulbar urethra is the most common site of injury in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma, such as the one described in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Membranous Urethra Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: inability to pass urine; blood at the urethral meatus, suprapubic bulge, floating prostate (Vermooten sign).
  • Treatment Plan: Suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Option C. Prostatic Urethra Injury:

  • Similar to membranous urethral rupture.

 

Option D. Urinary Bladder Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: Severe lower abdominal pain, distention, inability to pass urine, signs of shock (hypotension, rapid pulse). No blood is seen at urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Immediate surgical repair to close the bladder rupture, followed by drainage of urine, and addressing any associated injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethra injury is a common site of urethral trauma, particularly in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma. The key clinical features include difficulty in urination, blood at the urethral meatus, and swelling of the penis and scrotum. The treatment often involves surgical repair or placement of a suprapubic catheter.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen

 

 

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • ﻿﻿Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • ﻿﻿It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • ﻿﻿The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • ﻿﻿Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which is typically associated with bloody diarrhea or dysentery and liver abscesses, not the watery diarrhea commonly seen with Giardia.

 

Option C. Microsporidia: A group of obligate intracellular parasites, known to cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, but they do not produce the trophozoites seen in Giardia infections.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia: Another protozoan that can cause watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients, but is identified by different morphological features on histology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

 

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

 

This is a rare type of breast cancer that occurs more frequently in older women and grows slowly. The prognosis of colloid carcinoma is better than that of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

 

The tumor is typically a soft, gelatinous mass with well-defined borders.

 

Histologically, colloid carcinoma has a lot of extracellular epithelial mucin and mucin-filled acini. Floating in large lakes of mucin are cuboidal to tall columnar tumor cells, some of which show mucus vacuolation. Nuclei in intracellular type are pushed to the periphery, forming a signet ring appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary carcinoma of the breast is characterized by the presence of papillary structures lined by neoplastic cells.

 

  • It does not typically present with large pools of mucin.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is characterized by large, high-grade cells with a syncytial growth pattern, prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders.

 

  • It lacks the extensive mucin pools seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single-file lines or targetoid patterns.

 

  • It typically lacks the mucin pools characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

questions.text: A patient with gout develops hypertension. The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following is not administered? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that can lead to Hyperuricemia as its side effect. So, it should not be used in the management of hypertension in a patient with gout. The other side effects of thiazides include Hypokalemia, Metabolic alkalosis, Hyperglycemia, Hypomagnesemia and Hypercalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker that does not typically affect uric acid levels and is considered safe for use in patients with gout.

 

Option C. Enalapril: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that does not increase uric acid levels and is suitable for managing hypertension in patients with gout.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker that does not affect uric acid levels and can be safely used in patients with gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide should not be used to manage hypertension in patients with gout due to its potential to increase uric acid levels and exacerbate the condition. Other antihypertensive drugs, such as beta-blockers (atenolol), ACE inhibitors (enalapril), and alpha-blockers (prazosin), do not have this adverse effect and are suitable alternatives.

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign shown in the image below:(NEET  PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Popeye sign

 

The above image depicts the popeye sign, which is caused by a rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii.

 

Popeye sign:

 

  • Description: This refers to the prominent bulge of the biceps muscle in the arm.
  • Cause: The sign is named after the cartoon character "Popeye the Sailor Man" who had bulging forearm muscles. It's observed in cases where there's a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. When the tendon ruptures, the muscle can sometimes ball up, creating a bulge in the mid-arm.
  • Clinical Relevance: Often accompanied by pain and weakness, it usually requires clinical evaluation to determine the need for surgical intervention.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs sign (or lesion):

 

  • Description: It is a compression fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • Cause: This lesion occurs when the humeral head impacts against the anterior glenoid rim during an anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Clinical Relevance: The presence of a Hill-Sachs lesion can predispose an individual to recurrent shoulder dislocations. Its size and location may dictate treatment strategy in recurrent shoulder instability.

 

 

Option C. Griesinger sign:

 

  • Description: It refers to the presence of a postauricular sulcus or groove behind the ear.
  • Cause: This sign is seen in cases of acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media. The groove results from the edema and venous congestion in the sigmoid sinus secondary to the adjacent inflammation.
  • Clinical Relevance: Acute mastoiditis is a serious condition that requires prompt treatment, often including surgical intervention. The presence of Griesinger's sign helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option D. Rising sun sign:

 

  • Description: This is a radiological sign observed on imaging of the head.
  • Cause: It's seen in cases of tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder. On imaging, it refers to the appearance of subependymal nodules in the lateral ventricles that project into the ventricle. The nodules resemble the sun rising over the horizon.
  • Clinical Relevance: Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in many parts of the body. The presence of the "Rising sun" sign can help confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Popeye sign is a clinical indication of the rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon, leading to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle, which requires thorough clinical assessment and possibly surgical repair.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding non-competitive inhibition?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constant Km and decreased Vmax

 

Explanation:

 

Noncompetitive inhibition has constant Km and decreased Vmax.

 

More complex noncompetitive inhibition occurs when binding of the inhibitor does affect the apparent affinity of the enzyme for substrate, causing the lines to intercept in either the third or fourth quadrants of a double-reciprocal plot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common habit-forming drug is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heroin

 

Heroin is an opioid and is the most commonly abused opioid. Heroin has the highest dependence potential among all drugs listed. It is highly addictive, and users can develop a strong physical dependence, leading to withdrawal symptoms if the drug is not taken.

 

Most commonly abused drugs: This can vary from one country to another. Generally, alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, opioids are most commonly abused drugs:

 

  • Alcohol is the most common Used/Abused Substance in the World
  • Tobacco is the most common Used/Abused Substance in India
  • Cannabis is the most common “illegally” used drug in India as well as world, though its dependence potential is relatively lower.
  • Heroin is the most commonly abused opioid, and is the drug with highest dependence potential amongst all the drugs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming.

 

Option C. LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen. It can be abused, but it does not have the same level of physical dependence potential.

 

Option D. Phencyclidine (PCP): PCP is a dissociative drug with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming drug.

 

Educational Objective

 

Common habit-forming drugs:

 

  • Cannabis
  • Opioids
  • Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • Ecstasy
  • Cocaine

 

Heroin is the most common drug which is habit forming or in other words can cause physical dependence in which a patient gets withdrawal if he does not take the drug.

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

 

This is the correct answer. DPPC is a major component of pulmonary surfactant, and its deficiency in preterm infants is a key factor in the development of RDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. While it is a component of pulmonary surfactant, the primary deficiency in RDS is of DPPC.

 

L:S (Lecithin: Sphingomyelin) ratio > 2 is an indicator of fetal lung maturity at 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Option B. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. It is found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is not directly related to pulmonary surfactant.

 

Disease related to Cardiolipins

 

  1. Barth Syndrome: Defect in cardiolipin remodelling
  2. Anti-Phospholipid Syndrome: Occurs due to Anticardiolipin antibodies formed in body. C/f are A thrombotic condition and Disease females has history of recurrent infection

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because, as explained above, DPPC is deficient in preterm babies with RDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234

choices.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

questions.text: Which of the following is the etiology of the Werner syndrome with premature aging?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

 

This is the correct explanation for the etiology of Werner syndrome. Individuals with Werner syndrome have mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a helicase enzyme involved in DNA repair and maintenance. These mutations lead to the loss of helicase function and result in the accumulation of DNA damage and shortened telomeres, contributing to premature aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased length of telomere: This option is not the cause of Werner syndrome. In fact, individuals with Werner syndrome have shortened telomeres, not increased length. Telomeres are the protective caps at the end of chromosomes, and their shortening is associated with aging and age-related diseases.

 

Option C. Increased advanced glycation end products: Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) are associated with various age-related conditions, but they are not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. While AGEs can contribute to cellular damage, they are not the central mechanism behind this syndrome.

 

Option D. Decreased lipid peroxidation: Decreased lipid peroxidation is not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. Lipid peroxidation refers to the oxidative damage to lipids (fats), and although oxidative stress is involved in aging, it is not the primary driver of Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Werner syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging. It is caused by mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a protein called Werner syndrome ATP-dependent helicase (WRN). The WRN protein is involved in DNA repair, maintenance of genome stability, and telomere maintenance. One of the other functions of this protein is DNA helicase.

 

In Werner syndrome, there is a loss of function of the WRN protein, leading to problems with DNA repair and telomere maintenance. Telomeres are the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, and they shorten with each cell division. In Werner syndrome, there is accelerated telomere shortening, and this contributes to premature aging. There is also increased risk of cancer.

 

Ref: Harper’s 31st/e pg. 370

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus

 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is characterized by the triad of dementia, gait disturbance (typically apraxia or magnetic gait), and urinary incontinence. This condition often involves enlargement of the cerebral ventricles due to cerebrospinal fluid accumulation, which can exert pressure on surrounding brain structures, particularly affecting the frontal lobes responsible for cognitive and urinary control. The clinical presentation aligns well with the symptoms described in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia: This condition often presents with prominent personality changes and language difficulties rather than the classic triad seen in NPH. Falls are less commonly associated with this form of dementia in its early stages.

 

Option C. Parkinson disease: Typically presents with motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While dementia can occur in later stages, it is not typically accompanied by urinary incontinence and would not explain the early presence of falls as the primary symptom.

 

Option D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: Known for rapid progression of neurological symptoms including dementia, myoclonus (sudden muscle spasms), and significant motor dysfunction. It progresses much faster than what is typically seen in NPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NPH is characterized by Dementia, Apraxia/Magnetic gait with urinary incontinence due to frontal lobe dysfunction

 

Reference - Harrison/Dementia/Chap 434

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of variation

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is used to compare the relative variability of different datasets. It is a standardized measure of dispersion of a probability distribution or frequency distribution. The CV is particularly useful because it expresses the standard deviation as a percentage of the mean, making it possible to compare the degree of variation from one dataset to another, regardless of the unit of measurement or magnitude of the mean.

 

  • Co-efficient of Variation [COV] = SD/Mean x 100
  • It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance measures the spread of a set of numbers. It is the average of the squared differences from the mean. While it indicates variability, it does not provide a standardized measure for comparison between different datasets.

 

Option C. Standard Error of Mean (SEM): The SEM measures how much the sample mean of the data is likely to vary from the true population mean. It is used to understand the accuracy of the sample mean but is not used for comparing variability between datasets.

 

Option D. Standard Deviation (SD): Standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. While it indicates the spread of data points, it does not standardize this measure in relation to the mean, which is necessary for comparing different datasets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisate oxidase

 

Option A. Homogentisate oxidase: This is the correct enzyme.

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase, which leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body. This acid can darken upon exposure to air, resulting in blackened urine and other symptoms.

 

It is compatible with fairly normal life. The only abnormality is the blackening of urine on standing. The homogentisic acid is oxidized by polyphenol oxidase to benzoquinone acetate. It is then polymerized to black colored alkaptone bodies.

 

By the 3rd or 4th decade of life, patient may develop ochronosis (deposition of alkaptone bodies in intervertebral discs, cartilages of nose, pinna of ear). Black pigments are deposited over the connective tissues including joint cavities to produce arthritis.

 

Diagnosis of Alkaptonuria:

 

  1. Urine becomes black on standing when it becomes alkaline. Blackening is accelerated on exposure to sunlight and oxygen. The urine when kept in a test tube will start to blacken from the top layer.
  2. Ferric chloride test will be positive for urine.
  3. Benedict’s test is strongly positive. Due to reducing nature of homogentisic acid in urine.

 

Treatment: No specific treatment is required. But minimal protein intake with phenylalanine less than 500 mg/day is recommended.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase is not associated with Alkaptonuria. It is involved in the metabolism of purines, not in the pathway related to this condition.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), a different metabolic disorder causing mousy/musty body odor.

 

Option D. Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the pyrimidine biosynthesis pathway and is not related to Alkaptonuria.

 

Educational objective:

 

The diagnosis is alkaptonuria in which urine becomes black on standing due to oxidation of homogentisic acid present in the urine. The disease is autosomal recessive inherited and it is due to the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase/dioxygenase required for further metabolism of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shock

 

Apoplexy refers to acute neurologic impairment due to a vascular compromise, usually hemorrhage, resulting in headache, visual disturbance and hormonal dysfunction due to infarction of pituitary gland.

 

Loss of glucocorticoids results in shock.

 

MRI is used to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Management:

 

  • If shock is present: IV glucocorticoids + IV fluids to maintain hemodynamic stability
  • If worsening neurologic symptoms (VA, GCS): Surgical decompression

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension: Typically, hypertension is not a direct consequence of pituitary apoplexy. Instead, hypotension and shock are more common due to adrenal insufficiency.

 

Option C. Unconsciousness: While not the most direct symptom, unconsciousness can occur if the apoplexy leads to significant increase in intracranial pressure or severe complications, but it's not as characteristic as shock.

 

Option D. Fatigue: Although patients may experience fatigue due to hormonal imbalances, it's not a primary or immediate concern in the acute setting of pituitary apoplexy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shock is a critical and life-threatening manifestation of pituitary apoplexy that arises from acute adrenal insufficiency. Immediate recognition and treatment with IV glucocorticoids and fluids are essential to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications. This condition is diagnosed via imaging, typically an MRI, and may require surgical intervention depending on the severity and the presence of neurological symptoms.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pituitary tumor syndromes/Page no 2897

questions.text: Vitamin B12 is found maximum in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Animal products

 

Vitamin B12 is most abundant in animal-derived foods such as meat, fish, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. These sources are rich in this essential vitamin, making it an important part of the diets of individuals who consume animal products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green Leafy Vegetables: Green leafy vegetables, while nutritious and a source of many vitamins and minerals, are generally not a significant source of vitamin B12. In fact, plant-based sources of B12 are limited, and green leafy vegetables are not a reliable source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Roots and Tubers: Roots and tubers are also not a substantial source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not typically found in plant-based foods in significant quantities, so relying solely on roots and tubers for B12 would likely result in a deficiency.
