Option D. Sunlight: Sunlight is not a source of vitamin B12. This vitamin is not synthesized by the body through exposure to sunlight, as is the case with vitamin D.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 is naturally present in foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. Hence, vegetarians usually are prone to develop vitamin b12 deficiency. Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

choices.text: Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

A water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan pulse, is characterized by a rapid and forceful rise in pulse with a quick collapse. It is typically seen in aortic regurgitation. This phenomenon occurs due to the regurgitation of blood from the aorta back into the left ventricle during diastole, leading to an increased stroke volume and a subsequent forceful arterial pulse that collapses suddenly as the blood quickly flows back into the ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: In aortic stenosis, the pulse is described as pulsus parvus et tardus—'small and slow,' reflecting the reduced and delayed pulse wave due to the obstruction across the aortic valve.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation: When these two conditions coexist, the pulse is known as pulsus bisferiens, which is characterized by a double peak per cardiac cycle—not the rapid rise and fall typical of a water hammer pulse.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: In mitral regurgitation, the pulse may be described as hyperkinetic due to the increased volume load on the left ventricle, but it does not exhibit the rapid collapse seen in water hammer pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The water hammer pulse is a distinctive physical finding primarily associated with aortic regurgitation and is useful in the physical diagnosis of this condition. This type of pulse helps clinicians in the assessment of the severity and impact of valve dysfunction on the cardiovascular system.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: Where sharp waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) White container

 

Sharp waste, which includes items like needles, scalpels, and other sharp objects that can puncture or cut, must be disposed of in containers specifically designed to prevent punctures and leaks. These containers are typically white, puncture-resistant, leak-proof, and tamper-proof. This ensures that sharp objects are safely contained to prevent injuries and the spread of infections.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoma Esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of an elderly female presenting with symptoms such as progressive dysphagia, loss of appetite and weight loss along with the given barium study which shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins. These findings are suggestive of Carcinoma Esophagus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Is a motility disorder of esophagus and appears as a corkscrew esophagus.

 

Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma: Is a benign neoplasm of the esophagus and on barium swallow it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass well outlined by barium.

 

Option D. Esophageal webs: Refers to an esophageal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient presenting with progressive dysphagia for solids and significant weight loss, the presence of irregular narrowing and shouldered margins on a barium swallow is highly suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. Diagnostic confirmation typically requires upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and biopsy. For tumor staging, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is used for T and N staging, while PET-CT is utilized for M staging.

questions.text: Identify the marked cell from the given histological image of cerebellum: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Purkinje cells

 

The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells.

 

 

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Purkinje cells are specialized neurons located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • They are flask-shaped cells arranged in a single layer with even spacing.
  • Each Purkinje cell has a dendrite that rises from its neck and enters the molecular layer, where it branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell descends, crosses the granular cell layer, and enters the white matter. These axons are the only efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons, which provide inhibitory feedback.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei, where it synapses with other neurons to modulate motor function.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to regulate cerebellar output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: These are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their axons give rise to basket-like formations that surround the soma and initial axon segment of the Purkinje cells.
  • They play a role in modulating the activity of Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Golgi cells: These are also inhibitory interneurons, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.

 

  • Their dendrites extend into the molecular layer where they synapse with the parallel fibers of granule cells.
  • Golgi cells provide feedback inhibition to granule cells, modulating their output.

 

Option D. Granule cells:

 

  • These are the most numerous neurons in the brain, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • They are excitatory neurons that receive input from the cerebellar afferents through the mossy fibers.
  • Their axons ascend into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate and run parallel to the surface, forming the parallel fibers. These fibers synapse with the dendrites of the Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are among the largest neurons in the brain, located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. They have a large, flask-shaped soma from which extend many branching dendrites. The dendritic tree is oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the cerebellum, extending into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells pass into the white matter and are the only axons that leave the cerebellar cortex to synapse with cells in the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rifampicin

 

Among the options mentioned above, Rifampicin is the drug that acts by blocking RNA polymerase enzyme. It is one of the 1st line Anti Tubercular and anti-Leprosy drugs. It has the bactericidal effect against the mycobacteria, that are present both intracellularly as well as extracellularly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-Fluorouracil: This is an anticancer drug that primarily inhibits thymidylate synthase, affecting DNA synthesis rather than specifically inhibiting RNA synthesis.

 

Option C. Nitrofurantoin: This drug is primarily used for treating urinary tract infections. It does inhibit bacterial DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis but is not specifically an inhibitor of RNA synthesis alone.

 

Option D. Novobiocin: This antibiotic inhibits DNA gyrase, an enzyme involved in DNA supercoiling, but it does not inhibit RNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.

 

Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.

 

Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: Which method of measurement of scoliosis has been depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobb’s angle

 

  • This X-ray of spine shows lateral curvature (scoliosis) and angle marked is for its measurement – Cobb’s angle.

 

COBB’S ANGLE

 

  • Most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal scoliosis, on plain radiographs.
  • Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.
  • A Cobb angle can also aid kyphosis or lordosis assessment in the sagittal plane.
  • Measurement:
    • To measure the Cobb angle, one must first decide which vertebrae are the end vertebrae of the curve deformity (the terminal vertebrae) – the vertebra whose endplates are most tilted towards each other. 
    • Lines are then drawn along the endplates (or the pedicles if the endplates are not properly visualized), and the angle between the two lines, where they intersect, measured. 
    • In cases where the curvature is not marked, then the lines will not intersect on the film/monitor, in which case a further two lines can be plotted, each at right angles to the previous lines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kite’s angle. Kite’s angle or talocalcaneal angle is the angle between the lines drawn down the axis of the talus and calcaneus measured on weight bearing foot radiograph. This angle varies depending on the position of the calcaneus under the talus and the stiffness of the foot ligaments. Measurement: midtalar line should pass through/just medial to the base of 1st metatarsal and the mid-calcaneal line should pass through the base of 4th metatarsal. In hindfoot varus, the talocalcaneal angle is < 25⁰; in hindfoot valgus, it is > 40⁰; while in a normal foot, it is 25-40⁰.

 

 

Option C. Bohler’s angle. Tuber angle of Bohler (Tuber-joint angle) is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures. It is formed between a line drawn from highest points of anterior process of the calcaneus and highest point of posterior facet, and a line drawn tangentially to the superior edge of the calcaneal tuberosity. It is normally 20-40 degrees. Flattening/Reduction/Reversal of this angle indicates that the weight-bearing posterior facet has collapsed (intra-articular fracture) or Degree of proximal displacement of the tuberosity (intra-articular and extra-articular fracture both).

 

 

Option D. Gissane angle. Also known as critical angle of Gissane, it is used to evaluate the severity of calcaneal fractures. It is formed by two cortical struts extending laterally, one along the lateral margin of posterior facet and other extending to the beak of the calcaneus. Normally, it is an obtuse angle of 95-105 degree. It increases in intra-articular fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost benefit analysis

 

Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): CBA is a method used to evaluate the total costs versus the total benefits of a project or decision in monetary terms. It helps determine whether the benefits of a project or decision outweigh the costs, thereby justifying the investment. This type of analysis assigns a monetary value to all outcomes, allowing for a direct comparison between costs and benefits. For example, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) might report that it saved $12 million in a given year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): Definition: CEA assesses the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action.

 

  • Output: It is measured in non-monetary terms such as health outcomes (e.g., quality-adjusted life years (QALY) saved). For instance, the NTEP might measure its effectiveness by the number of lives saved or the improvement in the quality of life.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Definition: This is a quantitative method that involves mapping out and analyzing the sequence of activities and events in a project.

 

  • Tools: It includes techniques like Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM).
  • Usage: Network analysis is used to identify the sequence of tasks, the longest path through the project (critical path), and to optimize the project schedule.

 

Option D. Input Output Analysis: Definition: This method examines the relationship between inputs and outputs in an economic system.

 

  • Application: It can include both cost-benefit and cost-effective analyses as it calculates the effects of changing inputs on the outputs. This type of analysis is often used in economics to understand how different sectors of an economy interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a program analyzed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $

 

CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a program analyzed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.

 

INPUT-OUTPUT ANALYSIS - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)

 

NETWORK ANALYSIS – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating ocular trauma.
  • It can occur 2 weeks to 3 months after initial injury in 65% of cases, or following intraocular surgery.
  • The injured eye is called ‘exciting eye’ and the fellow eye is called ‘sympathising eye’.
  • The clinical picture of iridocyclitis in the sympathising eye can be divided into two stages:
  • Prodromal stage: 
    • Earliest symptoms: sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects.
    • Signs: retrolental flare and cells, a few keratic precipitates (KPs), mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and occasional disc oedema.
  • Fully-developed stage: 
    • Typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis.
    • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and multifocal choroidal infiltrates with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen-Fuchs nodules can be seen in the mid-periphery of the fundus.
  • Treatment includes:
    • High-dose oral prednisolone for several months.
    • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate for resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
    • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury to prevent the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Differential diagnosis of Sympathetic Ophthalmia is Vogy-Koyanagi-Harada Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blunt ocular trauma: typically does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Option C. Chemical injury: primarily affects the ocular surface and cornea rather than causing granulomatous uveitis.

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: is unrelated to ocular conditions and does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

choices.text: Conversion of uric acid to allantoin

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with chronic gout is under consideration for a change in treatment plan due to poor response to conventional therapies like allopurinol and colchicine. The healthcare team is discussing the potential use of pegloticase. What is the mechanism of action of pegloticase?" (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of uric acid to allantoin.

 

Pegloticase is a recombinant uricase enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, which is more soluble and easier to excrete through the kidneys. This action helps to lower high levels of uric acid in patients with chronic gout who have not responded well to conventional therapies such as allopurinol and colchicine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of xanthine oxidase: This is the mechanism of action for allopurinol, not pegloticase. Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, which is an enzyme involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid.

 

Option C. Increase excretion of uric acid: Some medications like probenecid work by this mechanism to increase the renal excretion of uric acid.

 

Option D. Inhibition of granulocyte migration: Colchicine works through inhibiting granulocyte migration, but pegloticase primarily works by metabolizing uric acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegloticase works by converting uric acid to allantoin, a more soluble compound that is easily excreted by the kidneys. This mechanism is distinct from other gout treatments and is particularly useful for patients with refractory chronic gout.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Extravasation into venous system
﻿﻿﻿Bilateral cornual block

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

 

The given HSG (hysterosalpingogram) film shows bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes, suggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx. Hydrosalpinx is typically caused by the end result of repeated mild endo-salpingitis (inflammation of the fallopian tubes) by pyogenic organisms of low virulence but highly irritant.

 

The organisms involved include:

 

  • Staphylococcus
  • E. coli
  • Gonococcus
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

During the initial infection, the fimbriae become edematous and in-drawn with the serous surface, adhering together to produce closure of the abdominal ostium. The uterine ostium gets closed by congestion. This results in the secretion being pent up, causing the tube to distend. The distension is marked more in the ampullary region than in the more rigid isthmus. As the mesosalpinx is fixed, the resultant distension makes the tube curled and look 'retort'-shaped. The wall is smooth and shiny, containing clear fluid inside, which is usually sterile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extravasation into venous system: This would show contrast leaking into the venous system and not confined to the Fallopian tubes.

 

Option C. Normal HSG: A normal HSG would show patent Fallopian tubes without distension or blockage.

 

Option D. Bilateral cornual block: This would show blockage at the cornua (the point where the Fallopian tubes enter the uterine cavity) without the dilated, fluid-filled appearance seen in hydrosalpinx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrosalpinx is characterized by bilaterally enlarged Fallopian tubes filled with clear fluid, often due to repeated mild infections causing obstruction and distension.

 

Ref: Page no 171, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female condom

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image is of a female condom. 
  • It is made of aa synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end
  • One ring is open – lies outside the vagina.
  • The closed ring is fitted under the symphysis like a diaphragm
  • Male condoms should not be used simultaneously due to friction leading to slippage of condom or tearing
  • Also offers protection against STDs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male Condom:

 

 

Option C. Cervical diaphragm:

 

 

Option D. Cervical Cap:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female condom is a synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end, providing contraceptive protection and protection against STDs.

 

Ref: Page n 612, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Environmental enteropathy
Celiac disease
Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW)

 

Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.

 

Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

 

 

  • Prior to biopsy, noninvasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features: -
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma

 

Treatment – Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.

 

DAPSONE for dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages (see image below).

 

 

Option D. Chronic pancreatitis: Causes malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Not associated with the specific histopathological features seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

choices.text: Heparan sulfate
Collagen Type IV

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Heparan sulfate

 

Explanation

 

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is an essential component of the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. As the major determinants of the anionic charge of the GBM, heparan sulfate chains have been thought to impart charge selectivity to the glomerular filtration. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibronectin: While fibronectin is involved in cell adhesion and matrix assembly, it does not primarily contribute to the charge-dependent filtration properties of the GBM.

 

Option C. Collagen Type IV: This type of collagen forms a structural scaffolding in the GBM, providing mechanical strength and stability rather than charge-based selectivity.

 

Option D. Entactin: Also known as nidogen, entactin helps link the network of laminin and collagen IV in the GBM but does not directly influence charge-based filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heparan sulfate is the critical component responsible for the charge-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane. Its negative charge effectively repels similarly charged molecules, preventing their passage into the urine, which is essential for the body's ability to retain vital proteins and other negatively charged substances.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency

 

The clinical scenario describes a 3-year-old girl with ambiguous genitalia, specifically an enlarged clitoris, and a karyotype of 46XX. This presentation is indicative of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), which is most commonly caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of CAH and accounts for more than 95% of cases. This enzyme deficiency leads to impaired cortisol production, which results in an increased production of androgens. The excess androgens cause virilization, leading to ambiguous genitalia in genotypically female infants.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ambiguous genitalia: This includes an enlarged clitoris, which is often a sign of virilization due to increased androgens.
  • Karyotype 46XX: Confirms the genetic female status.
  • Increased serum androgens: Result from the enzyme deficiency and lead to masculinization of the external genitalia.

 

Clinical scenario: Ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 11 hydroxylase deficiency: This can also lead to CAH but is less common and typically presents with hypertension due to the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone, which has mineralocorticoid activity.

 

Option C. 3 beta dehydrogenase deficiency: This is a rarer form of CAH and typically presents with both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid deficiencies along with ambiguous genitalia in both sexes.

 

Option D. 2, 3 lyase deficiency: This is not a commonly recognized cause of CAH. The primary enzyme deficiencies leading to CAH are 21-hydroxylase, 11-hydroxylase, and 17-hydroxylase deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female (46XX) is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, a form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastroschisis

 

The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

 

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital birth defect characterized by a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilicus, which leads to the evisceration of the bowel loops which are not covered by a sac and are exposed to the external environment. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.

 

Congenital umbilical hernia: Umbilical hernia is a protrusion of the abdominal contents through a weakness in the umbilical ring, and ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital anomaly in which the urinary bladder is located outside the abdominal cavity.

 

 

Option B. Umbilical hernia: In case of umbilical hernia we do not usually see content of bowel coming out. Umbilical hernia is a cystic swelling which regresess when the baby is sleeping & appears during crying. No treatment is required for such condition.

 

Option D. Ectopia vesicae: Ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital malformation where the urinary bladder is located outside the lower abdominal wall. This condition is often associated with other abnormalities of the urinary tract and reproductive system. Ectopia vesicae is typically noticed at birth, and its severity can vary depending on the specific case

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital defect characterized by the herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus, without a protective sac covering the contents.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

  • The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. High incidence of spondylolysis in gymnasts and other athlete’s suggest repetitive injury, which may be the contributing mechanism. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage as measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate collar or broken neck on the scottie dog in spondylolysis.

 

 

Collar or broken neck on the scottie dog appearance

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebrae upon another. It nearly always occurs between L5 and S1 (most common) or L4 and L5. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. The extent of slippage may not be correlated with severity of pain. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage is measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate beheaded dog in spondylolisthesis (Beheaded Scottish terrier sign).

 

 

Beheaded dog appearance

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. The bone contains increased number of osteoclasts but these do not resorb bone as evidenced by absence of ruffled borders and clear zones and are unable to respond to PTH. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Malignant osteopetrosis (congenital form) is autosomal recessive (AR, 11q13) and late onset osteopetrosis tarda (adolescence/adult form) is AD (1P 21). Intermediate form is AR. Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth, resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Fragile, brittle bones, and Pathological fractures are seen. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen on radiograph. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

 

Marble bone appearance

 

 

Rugger jersey spine

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is the radiological feature seen in osteoporosis, called as codfish appearance of vertebra.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

 

The presence of empty appearing nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

 

  • Histological Appearance: Papillary carcinoma has a papillary growth pattern with branching papillae composed of fibrovascular stalks and cuboidal epithelial cells.
  • Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei: Papillary carcinoma cells have distinct Orphan Annie eye nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and an optically clear or empty appearance.
  • Psammoma Bodies: Papillary carcinoma often contains psammoma bodies, which are concentrically calcified structures found within the papillae.
  • Lymphatic Invasion: Papillary carcinoma commonly exhibits lymphatic invasion; involvement of blood vessels is uncommon.
  • Genetic Alterations: Papillary carcinoma is associated with specific genetic changes, including gene rearrangements like RET/PTC and NTRK1, as well as BRAF gene mutations.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular carcinoma: This is incorrect. Follicular carcinoma typically presents with a different histological pattern, characterized by small follicles. It does not exhibit Orphan Annie eye nuclei, which are specific to papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Toxic nodular goitre: This is incorrect. Toxic nodular goitre, or multinodular goitre, is a benign condition and does not present with Orphan Annie eye nuclei or the other specific histological features of papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: This is incorrect. Medullary carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is characterized by amyloid deposits and the presence of calcitonin, rather than the histological features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathological examination is a key diagnostic feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.

 

  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children. It typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots. This rash typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes. It is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI (upper respiratory infection) and a sandpaper-like rash. It does not have Koplik spots.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient

 

“Onus of proof” implies the responsibility to prove or disprove a crime.

 

As a general rule, the onus to proof lies with the victim (or his lawyer), and not with the accused, in both civil and criminal cases. The accused is assumed to be innocent. It is the responsibility of victim (or his lawyer) to prove that accused has done a crime.

 

In criminal case, the burden of proof is always on the state (i.e., the public prosecutor, the government lawyer for victim). The state must prove that the accused is guilty.

 

In civil case, the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff. The plaintiff is a person who brings a case against another in a civil court. The person against whom the case is filed is called defendant. For e.g. in a medical negligence case, the patient is the plaintiff and the doctor is the defendant. Ordinarily the patient (and his lawyer) has to prove that the Doctor is negligent.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Police not under rank of sub inspector: Involved in criminal investigations but does not bear the onus of proof in civil negligence cases.

 

Option C. Magistrate: Presides over legal proceedings but does not bear the onus of proof.

 

Option D. Doctor: The doctor is the defendant in a negligence case and does not bear the initial burden of proof.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:

 

  • RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.

questions.text: Which of the options was initiated to ensure complete immunization of children? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MISSION INDRADHANUSH INCLUDES

 

  1. Polio
  2. Diphtheria
  3. Pertussis
  4. Tetanus
  5. TB
  6. Measles
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Rota Virus
  9. MR
  10. IPV
  11. JE
  12. HiB
  13. PCV

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.text: The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

 

The best indicators for air pollution surveillance are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

 

  • Overall best Air Pollution Indicator - SO2
  • Overall best chemical Indicator of Air Pollution - SO2
  • Best biological Indicator of Air Pollution → LICHENS
  • Air Pollution Monitoring → CPCB [Central Pollution Control Board]

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. These provide a comprehensive assessment of air quality and are crucial for monitoring the impact on health and the environment.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

  • The drug that is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness is Promethazine.
  • Promethazine is an H1 receptor antagonist with anticholinergic, sedative, and antiemetic properties. It works by blocking the action of histamine in the brain, reducing the symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and dizziness associated with motion sickness.
  • Other drugs used for the treatment of motion sickness include scopolamine (DOC), dimenhydrinate and meclizine, which also have antihistamine properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetirizine: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine primarily used for the treatment of allergic rhinitis, hives, and other allergic conditions. It lacks significant sedative and antiemetic effects and is not typically used for motion sickness.

 

Option C. Misolastine: Misolastine is another second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conditions but is not indicated for motion sickness due to its lack of sedative and antiemetic properties.

 

Option D. Loratadine: Loratadine is also a second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conditions. Similar to cetirizine and misolastine, it does not possess the sedative and antiemetic effects required to treat motion sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Promethazine is used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness due to its strong antihistamine, anticholinergic, sedative, and antiemetic properties. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine, misolastine, and loratadine are not effective for this purpose due to their lack of these properties.

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal
Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B receives a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

 

Point A

 

  • A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os.
  • Represents the anatomical location of the ureter.
  • The total dose to point A should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Point B

 

  • A point 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Represents a dose to the pelvic wall.
  • The dose to point B is about 25 – 30% of the dose to point A (4500 – 6500 cGy).

 

False Statement Explanation

 

  • Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal:
    • This statement is false because Point A is defined as 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, not 5 cm lateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point A in cervical cancer radiotherapy is located 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, and the total dose should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Ref: Page no 350, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

 

The above image is suggestive of a Cirsoid aneurysm.

 

  1. Definition: Cirsoid aneurysms, also known as arteriovenous fistulas or arteriovenous malformations, are abnormal connections between arteries and veins without the usual intervening capillaries.
  2. Common locations: They most commonly occur in the scalp and face, although they can occur in other locations in the body.
  3. Causes: They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired, often as a result of trauma.
  4. Symptoms: Cirsoid aneurysms often present as a pulsatile mass, sometimes accompanied by a bruit (a sound heard over an artery due to turbulent blood flow). They can cause cosmetic concerns, headaches, and in severe cases, bleeding.
  5. Diagnosis: They can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Angiography can provide a detailed view of the blood vessels.
  6. Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision, embolization (blocking off the abnormal vessels), or a combination of both. The choice of treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the patient's overall health status.
  7. Complications: If left untreated, they can result in complications such as bleeding, ulceration, and, rarely, heart failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Location: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that can affect multiple systems, including the skin and nerves.
  • Symptoms: Symptoms vary but can include skin tumors (neurofibromas), café-au-lait spots, and neurological problems

 

 

Option B. Liposarcoma:

 

  • Location: Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically arises in fat cells in various parts of the body, including the limbs and abdomen.
  • Causes: The exact cause is often unknown, but some genetic factors may contribute. Symptoms: Symptoms may include a painless lump, swelling, or pain in the affected area.

 

Option D. Varicocele:

 

  • Location: Varicoceles are dilated veins in the scrotum, specifically in the spermatic cord. Causes: Varicoceles often develop due to faulty valves in the testicular veins, which allow blood to pool in the scrotum.
  • Symptoms: They may cause a dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, especially after prolonged standing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live birts) by the year 2030? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) <70

 

In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SDGs – Targets & Indicators

 

3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70

3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25

3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.

3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.

3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.

3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.

3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.

3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.

3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • The clinical image depicts a newborn covered in a shiny membrane that resembles parchment, suggesting a disorder on the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum (Lamellar ichthyosis, Bathing suit ichthyosis, Harlequin ichthyosis)
  • Icthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in the Filaggrin gene (FLG).
  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is unlikely because it does not manifest at birth.

 

Fig: Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, Shedding of collodion membranes after 1 week.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamellar ichthyosis

  • Description: Infants with lamellar ichthyosis are often born with a collodion membrane, which sheds after a few weeks. The skin then becomes darkly pigmented with large, plate-like scales. Ectropion and eclabium can also be present.

 

Option C. Bathing suit ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a rare type of ichthyosis where the scaling is restricted to the trunk, sparing the extremities and face. It's called "bathing suit" due to the distribution pattern resembling the area covered by a bathing suit.

 

Option D. Harlequin ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a severe form of ichthyosis, where infants are born with very thick skin that forms large, diamond-shaped plates separated by deep fissures as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Features like ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory difficulties are common.

 

Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) includes the following:

 

  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI)
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI)
  • Congenital Ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self-limiting congenital ichthyisis (SLCI)
  • Collodion baby

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an unlikely diagnosis in a new-born presenting with a collodion membrane, ectropion, eclabium, and extensive skin lesions, given that ichthyosis vulgaris is typically a milder form and less likely to present with such severe symptoms at birth.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 65 Page no 65.4, 65.6-65.10

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8161842/

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External anal sphincter

 

Explanation

 

  • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter:
    • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa.
  • In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ischiocavernosus: This muscle is located more laterally and is less likely to be involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Option C: Bulbospongiosus: This muscle is located in the perineal body and is usually affected by a standard episiotomy, but not specifically by a backward extension beyond the perineal body.

 

Option D: Urethral sphincter: This sphincter is located anteriorly and is not involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where an episiotomy extends backward beyond the perineal body, the external anal sphincter is the structure most likely to be injured.

 

Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and in type 2 respiratory failure was admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given

 

Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) is often the initial treatment of choice for patients with COPD who present with an acute exacerbation and are in type 2 respiratory failure (characterized by hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis). NIPPV can improve gas exchange and reduce the work of breathing without the need for endotracheal intubation, thereby decreasing the risk of infection and other complications associated with invasive mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (IPPV): This is generally reserved for patients who fail NIPPV or present with severe acidosis, hemodynamic instability, or decreased level of consciousness that precludes the use of NIPPV.

 

Option C. IV corticosteroids: While systemic corticosteroids are commonly used in the management of acute COPD exacerbations, the initial focus in a patient in respiratory failure should be on stabilizing the patient's breathing and gas exchange. Corticosteroids can be administered orally or intravenously, but this would not be the primary concern in the immediate management.

 

Note - Oral steroids (prednisolone) is given for 5-14 days in acute exacerbations.

 

Option D. Permissive hypercapnia: This is a strategy used in mechanical ventilation where slightly elevated levels of carbon dioxide (hypercapnia) are tolerated to avoid high ventilatory pressures that can lead to lung injury, however pH is maintained above 7.3. It is applicable during mechanical ventilation if it becomes necessary but is not an initial management step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a COPD patient presenting with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure, non-invasive ventilation is the preferred initial management strategy to stabilize the patient's respiratory status, reducing the need for intubation and potentially improving clinical outcomes.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/COPD/chapter 292

choices.text: Interstitial lung disease
Scleroderma renal crisis

questions.text: Which among the following is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis when compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal dysmotility

 

Esophageal dysmotility is more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), particularly as part of the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). This condition involves abnormalities in the motility of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulties in swallowing and gastroesophageal reflux.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myopathy: While myopathy can occur in systemic sclerosis, it is not specifically more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis compared to the diffuse type.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): ILD is actually more commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis due to broader and more aggressive skin involvement and higher prevalence of specific autoantibodies like Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase).

 

Option D. Scleroderma renal crisis: This is a severe complication more frequently seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, particularly in the early stages of the disease, often exacerbated by the use of corticosteroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ Chap 360

choices.text: Myxoid liposarcoma
Spindle lipoma

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myxoid liposarcoma

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

The image shows a lot of ground substance, as well as some branching capillaries and immature adipocytes.

 

Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults, typically appearing in the fifth to sixth decade of life.

 

They are most commonly found in the proximal extremities (deep soft tissues) and the retroperitoneum.

 

Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into four subtypes: 

 

  • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: resembles lipoma but contains uni- or multi-vacuolated lipoblasts. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-g15.
  • Myxoid liposarcoma: Most common histologic type. It is composed of monomorphic, fusiform or stellate cells representing primitive mesenchymal cells, lying dispersed in mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance. Occasional tumor giant cells may be present. Prominent meshwork of capillaries forming chicken-wire patterns is a conspicuous feature. It is associated with t (12;16).
  • Round cell liposarcoma is composed of uniform, round to oval cells having fine multi vacuolated cytoplasm with central hyperchromatic nuclei. Round cell liposarcoma may resemble a signet-ring carcinoma but mucin stains help in distinguishing the two.
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: highly undifferentiated and the most anaplastic type. There are numerous large tumor giant cells and bizarre lipoblasts. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoma: This is incorrect. Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue and do not show the histological features or molecular translocation (t (12;16)) seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option C. Spindle lipoma: This is incorrect. Spindle cell lipomas are benign tumors composed of spindle-shaped cells mixed with mature adipocytes and do not have the mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance or the t (12;16) translocation seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option D. Polymorphic lipoma: This is incorrect. Polymorphic lipomas are also benign and do not exhibit the characteristic histological features or molecular markers of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxoid liposarcoma is the most common histologic type of liposarcoma, characterized by a mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance, a prominent capillary network forming chicken-wire patterns, and the presence of the translocation t (12;16).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent skin infections is admitted to the hospital for cellulitis. He has been treated with penicillin in the past but his current infection is not responding well to the treatment. The healthcare team suspects that the infecting bacteria may produce beta-lactamases and are considering alternative antibiotics. What is the mechanism of resistance by beta-lactamases to penicillins? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Degradation of antibiotics.

 

Beta-lactamases enzymatically degrade the beta-lactam ring of penicillin, rendering it inactive. This is the primary mechanism by which beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteration of penicillin binding protein is a resistance mechanism seen in bacteria like MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus) but is not the mechanism by which beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillins.

 

Option C. Drug efflux is a different mechanism of antibiotic resistance where the bacteria pump out the antibiotics like tetracyclines, but it is not the mechanism for beta-lactamase resistance.

 

Option D. Alteration in the 50s ribosome structure is a mechanism of resistance against antibiotics that target the bacterial ribosome, such as macrolides, and is not relevant to beta-lactamase-mediated resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillins by enzymatically degrading the beta-lactam ring of the antibiotic, rendering it inactive. This is the primary mechanism by which beta-lactamase-producing bacteria evade the effects of beta-lactam antibiotics.

questions.text: A female present with pain and swelling over multiple peripheral small joints and deformity as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

  • The image shows swan neck deformity seen in RA.
  • Characteristic Deformities of Hand and Foot In RA:

 

 

 

 

Finger deformities in RA

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand. Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.

 

 

Option D. Scleroderma. Scleroderma is a severe CTD characterized by vascular, immune and fibrotic changes in the skin and internal organs. While tethering of the skin is the clinical hallmark of SSc, many patients develop musculoskeletal symptoms also. Manifestations may include rheumatic complaints ranging from arthralgias to frank arthritis, contractures and tendon friction rubs. Articular involvement contributes to disability and impaired quality of life. All joints may be affected, although the fingers (in particular the MCP and PIP joints), wrists and ankles predominate. As the disease progresses, there is tethering and contracture of the joints with impairment of movement and function.

 

 

Calcinosis and contracture of joints

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Battle sign

 

The image shows Battle's sign.

 

It is retroarticular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

 

Option D: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition

choices.text: 4 years
7 years
9 years

questions.text: A child who is a victim under POCSO act is brought to the department of forensic medicine for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is shown below. What is the likely age of the child? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 13 years

 

The X-ray image shows:

 

  • All carpal bones are developed. This implies age is > 10 years. Pisiform is the last bone to appear which is visible and can be easily identified as marked below:

 

 

  • Base of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft (It fuses at 15-17 years age). This implies age is < 17 years.

 

Hence, age is 10-17 years. So, the best answer here is 13 years.

 

Educational Objective

 

Age of appearance of carpal bones is given below:

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

 

  • The Lumbricals (+ interossei) paralysis causes claw hand (MCP hyperextension and IP joint flexion).

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

 

Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia).

 

Accommodative esotropia:

 

It occurs due to overaction of convergence associated with accommodation reflex. It is of three types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia (Short-sightedness):

  • Esotropia: Less common in myopic children.
  • Refractive Error: Light focuses in front of the retina.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty seeing distant objects clearly.

 

Option B. Astigmatism:

  • Effect on Squint: Can cause both esotropia and exotropia depending on the axis and severity of astigmatism.
  • Refractive Error: Light is focused at multiple points due to an irregular corneal shape.
  • Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Option D. Emmetropia (Normal Vision):

  • Esotropia: Rarely associated.
  • Refractive Error: No significant refractive error; light focuses correctly on the retina.
  • Symptoms: Normal vision without the need for corrective lenses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternothyroid

 

  • Sternothyroid and sternohyoid muscles attach to the thyroid cartilage and can help prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.
  • The apex of thyroid gland is directed laterally to the oblique line of thryroid catilage where it is limited above by the attachment of sternothyroid muscle.
  • The sternohyoid muscle, which arises from the posterior surface of the manubrium and the medial end of the clavicle, also inserts onto the thyroid cartilage and can help anchor the gland in place.
  • Together, the attachment of these muscles to the thyroid cartilage can help prevent the gland from pushing upward and causing compression of adjacent structures in the neck.

 

 

  • The thyroid gland is surrounded by the pretracheal fascia, which is connected to the larynx and enables the thyroid to move during swallowing.
