  • The thyrohyoid membrane, a fibrous ligament, attaches to the top of the thyroid cartilage and the hyoid bone, facilitating the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.
  • The ligament of Berry, also known as the suspensory ligament, extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid gland, preventing it from descending into the mediastinum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pretracheal fascia: The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland, trachea, and associated structures. It anchors the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring that the gland moves up and down with swallowing. However, it does not prevent the upward extension of a thyroid swelling specifically through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage.

 

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane: It is a broad, fibrous sheet that connects the thyroid cartilage (of the larynx) to the hyoid bone. It contains the superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. While it's a strong structure, its primary role is not to prevent the upward extension of thyroid swellings.

 

Option D. Ligament of Berry: It is a band of fibrous tissue that connects the thyroid gland's posterior aspect to the cricoid cartilage and the first two tracheal rings. This ligament is a key anatomical structure that serves to limit the superior (upward) movement of the thyroid gland. When performing thyroid surgeries, the ligament of Berry is a crucial landmark as it is located near the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sternothyroid muscle originates from the posterior surface of the manubrium of the sternum and inserts into the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage. It functions to depress the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

choices.text: Human papilloma virus
Herpes simplex virus
Human immunodeficiency virus

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human papilloma virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Benign vulval warts are caused by HPV-6 and 11 (low risk HPV types)

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes genital herpes, characterized by painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) causes AIDS, which leads to immunosuppression and various opportunistic infections.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a member of the herpesvirus family and can cause infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not cause vulval warts.

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Benign vulval warts (condyloma acuminata) are caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parainfluenza

 

Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

 

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

 

Management:

 

  • ﻿﻿Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.
  • Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • ﻿﻿Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>|V>|M). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • ﻿﻿Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (Sp02 <92 %)

 

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moraxella: More commonly associated with conditions like otitis media and sinusitis rather than croup.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Although capable of causing respiratory tract infections, it is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Known for more severe respiratory conditions like bacterial tracheitis, which is distinct from viral croup and presents with more severe symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza is a common cause of croup. The 'Steeple sign' on X-ray supports this diagnosis, emphasizing the need for prompt and effective treatment to ensure rapid recovery and prevent complications.

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliverdin 

 

Meconium is a dark and sticky substance that is normally present in a newborn's intestine at birth and is excreted in the feces after birth. It is first detected in the ileum at around 70-85 days of fetal life and fills the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of meconium is due to bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract, mainly biliverdin, which is formed from the oxidation of bilirubin.

 

  • Biliverdin is responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in newborns. Biliverdin production starts later in gestation or closer to delivery, perhaps due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.
  • Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.
  • Meconium itself is the first stool of the baby, which contains biliverdin, giving it the greenish-black color.
  • Gut flora: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of stools and neonatal jaundice, but not for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Option C. Meconium: Meconium is the substance itself, not the cause of its greenish-black color. The color is due to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Gut flora of neonate: Newborns do not have gut flora at birth, so it is not responsible for the greenish-black color of the first stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with a history of loss of interest in day-to-day activities, weight loss, insomnia, and sadness for six months. She also recalls hearing a voice once that ordered her to kill herself. What is the DSM-V diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

 

The patient's symptoms of loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness align with major depressive disorder. The presence of auditory hallucination (voice ordering her to commit suicide) indicates an additional psychotic feature. Hence, the diagnosis would be Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: It is a chronic disorder typically lasting more than 6 months, with symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc. without a predominant mood episode.

 

Option C. Schizoaffective disorder: It has features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders concurrently.

 

Option D. Delusional disorder: The primary feature is a persistent delusion without other symptoms of psychosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder. Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

 

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: Causes quartan malaria with a longer incubation period and typically presents with band-form trophozoites across the red cells, distinct from the forms seen in P. falciparum.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Known for causing tertian malaria with similar clinical presentations to P. vivax, including the presence of Schüffner's dots and slightly enlarged and ovale-shaped erythrocytes.

 

Option D. P. vivax: Also causes tertian malaria, characterized by Schüffner's stippling in erythrocytes, larger ring forms than P. falciparum, and less severe disease outcomes compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: What is the photostress test used to differentiate between?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Macula and optic nerve disease

 

  • Photo stress test helps differentiate between diseases involving the macula and optic nerve.
  • This test is particularly useful in early macular diseases like central serous retinopathy.
  • One eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on a near chart.
  • A bright light is shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again.
  • The time taken to recover is noted, and the test is repeated with the other eye.
  • In normal people and patients with optic nerve disease, recovery time is not affected.
  • In patients with macular disease, recovery time is prolonged, usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time.
  • Photoreceptor damage and delayed visual pigment regeneration process contribute to prolonged recovery time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract and glaucoma: The photostress test is not designed to differentiate between cataract and glaucoma. Cataract affects the lens, while glaucoma primarily affects the optic nerve and intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Lens and cornea: The photostress test does not help in differentiating between lens and corneal pathologies. Issues with the lens (e.g., cataracts) and cornea are typically diagnosed with slit-lamp examination and other tests.

 

Option D. Retina and vitreal pathologies: The photostress test is not specifically used to differentiate between retinal and vitreal pathologies. Other diagnostic methods, such as ophthalmoscopy, fundus photography, and optical coherence tomography (OCT), are more appropriate for these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The photostress test is a simple and effective diagnostic tool used to differentiate between macular diseases and optic nerve diseases, based on the recovery time of vision following bright light exposure.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Supraphysiological doses of Vitamin B3, also known as Niacin, have been known to cause adverse effects, including macular edema and macular cysts. This side effect is relatively rare but has been documented in some cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to various eye problems, but it is not associated with macular edema and macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D is essential for various bodily functions, including bone health, but it is not known to cause macular edema or macular cysts.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that helps protect cells from damage, but it is not associated with macular edema or macular cysts caused by supraphysiological doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning and tingling. Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage (Raised AST and ALT levels, Fulminant hepatitis)

 

Niacin causes a reversible toxic cystoid maculopathy that occurs in approximately 0.67% of patients taking high doses of the drug.

 

Other symptoms –

 

  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Glucose intolerance (therefore weekly glucose monitoring done if given in diabetics)
  • Hyperuricemia

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 37 degrees C

 

Frostbite should be managed with rapid and complete thawing using a circulating water bath maintained between 37°C and 40°C. This temperature range is optimal to reverse vascular stasis and initiate reperfusion without causing thermal injury.

 

Thawing at this range is typically performed for 30 to 60 minutes and should be done only when the possibility of refreezing is excluded. Higher temperatures like 42°C are not recommended and may worsen tissue injury.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 42°C: Too hot. It exceeds the upper recommended limit and can risk thermal damage to already compromised tissue.

 

Option C. 32°C: Insufficient to produce effective rewarming. Rewarming would be slow and incomplete.

 

Option D. 30°C: Ineffective. Tissue remains partially frozen and vulnerable to re-freezing injury.

 

Educational Objective:


Frostbite should be rewarmed in circulating water at 37–40°C for 30–60 minutes, avoiding hot air or dry heat.

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

 

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses enzyme-labeled antibodies and an enzymatic reaction to produce a detectable signal, usually a color change, and typically requires more time and equipment to perform.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Involves the use of fluorescent-labeled antibodies to detect specific antigens or antibodies in a sample, requiring specialized equipment to visualize fluorescence.

 

Option D. Chemiluminescence: Relies on a chemical reaction that produces light to detect antigens or antibodies, also requiring specialized equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunochromatographic tests, such as the HbsAg card test, provide a rapid, user-friendly, and effective means of testing for certain antigens or antibodies directly at the point of care. Their simplicity and speed make them invaluable tools in clinical settings, especially where quick decision-making is crucial.

choices.text: Wavy fibers
Neutrophils in cardiac muscle
Swelling of cells
Eosinophilic contraction band

questions.text: Histology of reperfused myocardium is suggestive of which of the following features? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eosinophilic contraction band 

 

Light microscopy of reperfused myocardium reveals eosinophilic contraction bands. When blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI, they occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes.

 

 

Because the vasculature is injured during the period of ischemia and leaks when flow is restored hence a re-perfused infarct is usually hemorrhagic.

 

Microscopic examination reveals that myocytes that were irreversibly injured during reperfusion frequently have contraction bands, which are intensely eosinophilic intracellular "stripes" composed of closely packed sarcomeres. These are caused by myofibril contractions that are exaggerated when perfusion is restored, exposing the interior of dead cells with damaged plasma membranes to a high concentration of calcium ions from the plasma. Reperfusion thus not only saves reversibly injured cells but also changes the morphology of lethally injured cells.

 

Because of impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemma damage, intracellular calcium levels rise during ischemia. After reperfusion, this causes augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wavy fibers:

 

  • Description: Wavy fibers are an early histologic change seen in myocardial infarction, indicating stretching of non-contracting fibers.
  • Timing: These are seen in the early stages of ischemic injury before reperfusion.

 

Option B. Neutrophils in cardiac muscle:

 

  • Description: Neutrophil infiltration is a typical feature of the inflammatory response that occurs a few hours to days after myocardial infarction.
  • Timing: These are seen in the subsequent inflammatory phase following ischemic injury and are not specific to reperfusion injury.

 

Option C. Swelling of cells:

 

  • Description: Cellular swelling is a sign of reversible injury and occurs early in the ischemic process due to the failure of ion pumps.
  • Timing: This occurs before the irreversible injury and reperfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosinophilic contraction bands are a characteristic histological feature of reperfused myocardium, indicating irreversible injury and exaggerated myofibril contraction due to high intracellular calcium levels upon restoration of blood flow.

choices.text: 90% is associated with ANCA positivity
30% is associated with Hepatitis B

questions.text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 30% association with Hepatitis B

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis predominantly affecting medium-sized arteries, often associated with Hepatitis B in about 30% of cases. The association with Hepatitis B is significant because the virus can trigger immune complex deposition, contributing to vascular inflammation and damage characteristic of PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing inflammation of large vessels: This is incorrect because PAN specifically affects medium-sized, not large vessels. Large vessel vasculitis includes conditions like Giant Cell Arteritis and Takayasu Arteritis.

 

Option B. Patient has hypogammaglobulinemia: This is incorrect; PAN is often associated with hypergammaglobulinemia due to chronic immune activation, not hypogammaglobulinemia.

 

Option C. 90% is associated with ANCA positivity: This statement is also incorrect. Polyarteritis nodosa is typically ANCA-negative; the presence of ANCA is more characteristic of other forms of vasculitis such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) and Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening of immigrants to a country

 

Prospective screening is conducted primarily for the benefit of the community or the public health system, rather than for the direct benefit of the individual being screened. It aims to control the spread of diseases and protect public health by identifying potential carriers of infectious diseases or individuals with certain health conditions that may pose a risk to others.

 

Screening of immigrants to a country: This is a classic example of prospective screening. It is done to detect infectious diseases or other health conditions in immigrants to prevent the spread of disease and protect the health of the population in the host country. This screening is often mandated by public health authorities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient:  This is an example of prescriptive screening, as it is conducted for the individual's benefit to detect cervical cancer early.

 

Option B. Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism:  This is also an example of prescriptive screening aimed at early detection and management of hypothyroidism in newborns.

 

Option D. Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man:  This is another example of prescriptive screening, used to detect diabetes in the individual.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The scope of Project MONICA includes: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cardiovascular diseases 

 

Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.

 

The WHO MONICA (MONItoring trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) Project was designed to measure trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease mortality and coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease morbidity, and to assess the extent to which these trends are related to changes in known risk factors in different populations in 27 countries (10 years’ period)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scope of Project MONICA is focused on cardiovascular diseases, specifically monitoring trends in coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease and examining the impact of various risk factors on these conditions.

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ampulla

 

Explanation:

 

 

Ampulla:

 

  • The ampulla is the widest section of the fallopian tube and is the most common site for fertilization.
  • This region provides an optimal environment for the sperm to meet the ovum and for the subsequent fertilization process to occur.
  • The ampulla is also the most common site of ectopic pregnancy, where a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.

 

Structure of the Fallopian Tube:

 

The fallopian tube has four main parts:

 

  1. Infundibulum: The funnel-shaped opening near the ovary with finger-like projections called fimbriae.
  2. Ampulla: The widest and longest part where fertilization typically occurs.
  3. Isthmus: A narrow section adjacent to the uterus.
  4. Interstitial (or intramural): The part that traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isthmus: The isthmus is the narrow section of the fallopian tube close to the uterus. While it plays a role in the transport of the fertilized egg to the uterus, it is not the primary site for fertilization.

 

Option C. Interstitial: This portion of the fallopian tube traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity. It is not typically where fertilization occurs.

 

Option D. Infundibular: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped opening near the ovary, equipped with fimbriae to help capture the released ovum. Fertilization does not typically occur here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, which is the widest and longest part of the tube.

 

Ref: Page no 23, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is receiving theophylline as part of her management plan. She reports increased urination since starting the medication. Theophylline causes diuresis by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine antagonism.

 

Theophylline's diuretic effect is primarily due to its antagonism of adenosine receptors, leading to increased renal blood flow and diuresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PDE 4 inhibition: Phosphodiesterase (PDE) 4 inhibition by theophylline is more related to its bronchodilatory effects rather than diuresis.

 

Option C. Activation of histone deacetylase: This mechanism is thought to contribute to theophylline's anti-inflammatory effects but is not related to diuresis.

 

Option D. PDE 3 inhibition: This is more related to theophylline's cardiac effects rather than diuresis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of Adverse Effects of Theophylline

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

 

  • This image shows typical finding on physical examination, which is caused by bulging of the biceps muscle belly after rupture of the biceps tendon, known as Popeye sign or Popeye deformity.
  • The Popeye is a cartoon character with bulging muscles, hence its name.

 

POPEYE SIGN

 

  • Etiology:
    • Due to sudden eccentric biomechanical load is applied with the forearm flexed and supinated, which can cause the rupture of either the proximal or the distal tendon junctions.
       
  • Risk factors: 
    • Older age
    • Smoking habit
    • Usage of certain drugs (corticosteroids, statins).
    • Shoulder overuse (sports or work-related activities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted champagne bottle sign. This sign is seen in Lipodermatosclerosis, also referred to as sclerosing panniculitis or hypodermitis sclerodermaformis, which is a persistent inflammatory disorder characterized by the development of subcutaneous fibrosis and induration of the skin of the lower extremities. The chronic phase of lipodermatosclerosis is characterized by well-defined, circumferential, thick, darkly pigmented, non-tender plaques. These plaques are described as having a firm, “woody” induration, and the sclerotic change with circumferential narrowing of the lower leg and concurrent proximal and distal edema, that produces the classic “inverted champagne bottle” appearance of the lower extremity. The rounded cork of the champagne bottle is symbolic of the edematous foot, the central fibrosis around the ankle represents the neck, and the bottle's body embodies the lymphedema proximal to the area of constriction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

questions.text: The appearance of saphenofemoral junction on USG, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mickey mouse sign

 

Explanation:

 

The Mickey Mouse sign is the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound at the saphenofemoral junction.

 

 

Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ

 

IOC for varicose veins, SFJ incompetence: Doppler USG

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: String sign results from a severe narrowing of a bowel loop, which makes the lumen resemble a string. Seen in case of Pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Option B: Tillaux sign is positive in the case of mesenteric cyst. It is described as a mass lesion of the abdomen which is only mobile in the horizontal and not in vertical direction.

 

Option D: Stemmer sign is seen as non-pitting edema in cases of lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Mickey Mouse sign" on ultrasound is a useful anatomical descriptor for the normal configuration of the saphenofemoral junction, aiding in the assessment and diagnosis of venous issues at this location.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Water’s view

 

Occipitomental view is also called Water's view.

 

Water's view: The patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward.

 

Structures seen in Water's view are:

 

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's view - Typically used for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum.

 

 

Structures seen – 

Arcuate eminence

Superior semicircular canal

Mastoid antrum

Internal auditory canal

Tympanic cavity

Cochlea

External auditory canal

 

Clinical application – Acoustic neuroma, Petrositis

 

Option C. Law's view - Generally related to imaging of the shoulder or elbow, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stenver's view - A radiographic projection used primarily for detailed imaging of the mastoid process and middle ear structures.

Structures seen –

Arcuate eminence

Internal auditory meatus

Labyrinth with vestibule

Mastoid antrum

Cochlea

Entire petrous pyramid

 

 

Educational Objective:


Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

choices.text: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Anuj has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erythromycin only

 

In this case, the close contact of the patient is a 3-year-old child who had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, most likely as the 4th dose (1st booster). Therefore, only erythromycin is needed for prophylaxis.

 

It is crucial to monitor all household contacts for 7 days and obtain cultures from their nose and throat. Regardless of immunization status, all contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis such as benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One booster dose: This is not necessary because the child had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, which should still provide adequate immunity.

 

Option B. Nothing as the child is already exposed: This is incorrect because close contacts need to be managed to prevent the spread of diphtheria, and antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended.

 

Option C. Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid: This option is for those who have received less than three doses of diphtheria toxoid or have an unknown vaccination history. Since Ajay has been recently vaccinated, only erythromycin is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When Additional Toxoid is Needed:

  • <3 doses total received
  • >5 years since last dose
  • Unknown vaccination history
     

For a close contact of a diphtheria patient who has received the diphtheria vaccination within the last five years, antibiotic prophylaxis with erythromycin is the appropriate management step.

questions.text: What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dL, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR = 2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Class B

 

To determine the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, each of the five clinical measures is scored with points from 1 to 3 based on specific criteria:

 

  1. Bilirubin:
    • <2 mg/dL = 1 point
    • 2-3 mg/dL = 2 points (Patient has 2.5 mg/dL)
    • 3 mg/dL = 3 points
  2. Albumin:
    • 3.5 g/dL = 1 point
    • 2.8-3.5 g/dL = 2 points
    • <2.8 g/dL = 3 points (Patient has 3 g/dL, scoring 2 points)
  3. INR:
    • 1-1.7 = 1 point
    • 1.8-2.3 = 2 points (Patient has INR = 2)
    • 2.3 = 3 points
  4. Ascites:
    • None = 1 point
    • Controlled = 2 points (Patient has mild ascites, scoring 2 points)
    • Refractory = 3 points
  5. Encephalopathy:
    • None = 1 point (Patient has none)
    • Grade 1-2 = 2 points
    • Grade 3-4 = 3 points

 

Scoring Calculation:

 

  • Bilirubin = 2 points
  • Albumin = 2 points
  • INR = 2 points
  • Ascites = 2 points
  • Encephalopathy = 1 point
    Total = 9 points

The patient scores 9 points, placing them in Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class B.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system

 

 

Inference:

 

  • CTP A: 5-6
  • CTP B: 7-9
  • CTP C: 10-15

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chapter 344

questions.text: A 24-year-old presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schwannoma

 

The histopathological examination is suggestive of schwannoma.

 

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that surround but do not invade the associated nerve. They are frequently associated with NF2 gene inactivating mutations on chromosome 22g12.

 

The tumor is composed of fibrocellular bundles that form a whorled pattern under the microscope. There are dense and compact cellular areas (Antoni A pattern) that alternate with loose acellular areas (Antoni B pattern). Antoni A pattern areas have palisaded nuclei known as Verocay bodies. Nerve fibres are typically found stretched across the capsule but not within the tumor. Hemosiderin and lipid-laden macrophages are found in degeneration areas.

 

Schwann cells characteristically express S-100 protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors but differ histologically. They are not encapsulated and involve the nerve itself. They do not show the distinct Antoni A and B patterns or Verocay bodies seen in schwannomas.

 

Option C. Neuroma: Neuromas are non-neoplastic proliferations of nerve tissue, often occurring after nerve injury. They lack the distinctive histopathological features of spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies.

 

Option D. Glioma: Gliomas are primary tumors of the central nervous system originating from glial cells. They do not present with the histopathological features described and are not typically found in peripheral locations like the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannomas are characterized by spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies, forming well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses. These features, along with S-100 protein expression, distinguish schwannomas from other types of nerve sheath tumors and central nervous system tumors.

questions.text: Apolipoprotein B 48 is a made of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA editing

 

 ApoB-48 is produced through RNA editing. RNA editing involves the modification of the nucleotide sequence of an RNA molecule, specifically the conversion of a cytosine (C) to a uracil (U) in the mRNA. In the case of ApoB-48, this editing changes a codon, resulting in the synthesis of a shorter protein product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA Alternate Splicing: RNA alternate splicing is a process where different exons (coding regions) of a pre-mRNA are combined in various ways to generate different mature mRNA molecules. This process can result in the production of different protein isoforms, but it is not the mechanism for generating ApoB-48.

 

Option C. DNA Editing: DNA editing typically refers to genetic engineering techniques that modify the DNA sequence, such as CRISPR-Cas9. This is not the process by which ApoB-48 is generated.

 

Option D. RNA Interference: RNA interference (RNAi) is a cellular process involved in gene regulation, where small RNA molecules inhibit gene expression. It does not play a direct role in the synthesis of ApoB-48.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In liver cell, Apo B100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is > 70mm

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG abdomen. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

 

Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm: True. Generally, surgery (either open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic male patients when the AAA reaches a diameter of 5.5 cm (55mm) or greater. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the diameter surpasses this threshold, so this is the currently accepted cutoff for intervention in many guidelines.

 

Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

 

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size <55mm.

 

Other Options:

 

The size of an AAA determines the risk of rupture, and this risk informs the decision for surgical intervention.

 

Option A. Urgent endovascular aneurysm repair: Not necessarily true for a 40mm AAA. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is a less invasive method than open surgery, but it is not typically done urgently for aneurysms of this size unless they are symptomatic or rapidly increasing in size.

 

Option C. Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery: Not true for a 40mm AAA. As the aneurysm is still below the general threshold for surgical intervention, there's no need for urgent operation unless there are other complicating factors (e.g., rapid growth or symptoms).

 

Option D. Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >70mm: Not true. Waiting for an AAA to reach 70mm before considering surgery would expose the patient to a very high risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery (open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater due to the increased risk of rupture beyond this size. Regular monitoring is advised for smaller aneurysms.

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Induration

 

ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration.

 

ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

 

ASEPSIS SCORE

 

 

Criterion Not Included: 

 

Option D. Induration: Induration (hardening of the tissue) is not included in the ASEPSIS wound scoring system. The criteria focus on discharge, erythema, separation of tissues, bacterial isolation, and additional treatments rather than tissue induration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ASEPSIS wound scoring system does not include induration as a criterion. It focuses on factors like purulent and serous discharge, erythema, separation of deep tissue, additional treatments, bacterial isolation, and extended hospital stay to evaluate surgical site infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-man presents with swelling over knee joint. Biopsy reveals mononuclear and giant cells. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

 

  • Lesion with giant cells and mononuclear cells in skeletally mature patient, GCT is the best answer.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

 

The clinical presentation of a swollen belly and dull face in a child fed mostly rice water, along with findings of low serum protein and low albumin, is suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by:

 

  • Edema: Resulting from hypoalbuminemia, which leads to fluid retention and swelling, especially in the abdomen.
  • Apathy and irritability: The child often appears listless and irritable.
  • Poor diet history: Often associated with diets low in protein, such as those predominantly consisting of carbohydrates like rice water.
  • Other symptoms: Growth retardation, muscle wasting, and skin and hair changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe acute malnutrition but is characterized by severe wasting and absence of edema. Children with marasmus appear extremely thin with prominent ribs and have a "skin and bones" appearance.

 

Option C. Indian childhood cirrhosis: This is a chronic liver disease in children characterized by liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, but it does not typically present with the acute signs of protein malnutrition like Kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: This is an acute febrile illness of unknown etiology that primarily affects children under 5 years of age and involves inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis). It does not present with symptoms of malnutrition such as a swollen belly due to low protein intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, apathy, and growth retardation due to a diet deficient in protein, often with a swollen belly and low serum protein levels.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

 

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

 

Nerve supply of external auditory canal

 

External Auditory Canal

 

  1. Anterior wall and roof: auriculotemporal (V3).
  2. Posterior wall and floor: auricular branch of vagus (CN X) aka Arnolds nerve
  3. Posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibres of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus

 

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): Stimulation of Arnold's nerve in the external auditory canal during wax removal evokes reflex cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve - Provides sensation to the anterior wall and roof of the canal, not typically associated with triggering cough.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve - Primarily involved in the sensation of the skin around the ear, not the inner canal.

 

Option D. Facial nerve - While it contributes sensory fibers, it is not the primary cause of the cough reflex in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothelial injury

 

Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

 

Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system.

 


 

Three primary abnormalities, known as the Virchow triad, are known to cause thrombosis.

 

They include:

 

  • Endothelial injury - most important factor
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet activation: While platelet activation is a crucial step in the formation of a thrombus, it is typically initiated by endothelial injury, making endothelial injury the primary initiating event.

 

Option C. Coagulation cascade: The coagulation cascade is activated following endothelial injury and platelet activation, but it is not the initiating event of thrombosis.

 

Option D. Vasoconstriction of vessels: Vasoconstriction occurs as a response to endothelial injury and helps limit blood flow to the site of injury, but it is not the initiating factor in thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombosis is primarily initiated by endothelial injury, which is a key component of the Virchow triad and leads to the subsequent activation of platelets and the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, but the right heart valves may also be involved in some cases.

 

Vegetations can be single or multiple, with one or more valves involved. Embolization is common and, due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli, can result in septic infarctions or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgment.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

 

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis shows small, friable vegetations.

questions.text: A tumor arising from the uncinate process of the pancreas is most likely to compress which of the following vessels? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Superior mesenteric artery

 

A tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas affects the superior mesenteric artery.

 

Superior mesenteric artery originates from the anterior surface of the aorta just below the celiac trunk. It supplies blood to the midgut structures, including parts of the small intestine and the proximal large intestine.

 

Anatomically, the uncinate process of the pancreas lies posterior to the SMA, and its proximity means that tumors arising from the uncinate process can compress or invade the SMA.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Portal vein: It is formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas by the confluence of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein. It conveys blood from the gastrointestinal tract and spleen to the liver. While tumors of the pancreas can involve the portal vein, especially those in the head and neck region, the uncinate process's direct relationship is more with the Superior mesenteric artery than with the portal vein.

 

Option C. Common hepatic artery: The common hepatic artery typically arises from the celiac trunk and bifurcates into the proper hepatic artery (supplying the liver) and the gastroduodenal artery. It runs superior to the head of the pancreas. While it's possible for a pancreatic tumor to involve this artery, especially if the tumor is extensive, the uncinate process's primary vascular relationship remains the Superior mesenteric artery.

 

Option D. Inferior mesenteric artery: It is the third major branch of the abdominal aorta and supplies blood to the hindgut structures, including the distal part of the large intestine. It is anatomically distant from the uncinate process of the pancreas, so it's less likely to be directly affected by a tumor in this location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uncinate process of the pancreas is a small extension of the pancreas that hooks around the superior mesenteric artery and vein. Its anatomical relations include:

 

Superiorly:

 

  • Neck of the pancreas

 

Inferiorly:

 

  • Superior mesenteric vein
  • Superior mesenteric artery

 

Anteriorly:

 

  • Third part of the duodenum
  • Root of the small bowel mesentery

 

Posteriorly:

 

  • Inferior vena cava
  • Aorta
  • Left renal vein
  • Left psoas muscle
  • Transverse mesocolon

 

Medially:

 

  • Pancreatic duct
  • Common bile duct

 

Laterally:

 

  • Right renal vessels
  • Right psoas muscle

 

The uncinate process is an important landmark for the surgeon during pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) as it is often involved in the dissection of the superior mesenteric vein and artery.Top of Form

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lateral pons

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons

 

 

Lateral Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The facial nerve or its nucleus leading to ipsilateral facial weakness. (differentiating feature from lateral medullary syndrome).
  • The spinothalamic tract leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Medulla: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract leading to contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The medial lemniscus leading to contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • The hypoglossal nerve leading to ipsilateral tongue deviation.
  • This doesn't match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Medial Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract causing contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The abducens nerve leading to ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle palsy.
  • The medial lemniscus causing contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • This doesn't align with the symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Lateral Medulla: Lesions in this region (often due to Wallenberg syndrome or lateral medullary syndrome) would result in:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face due to the involvement of the descending tract and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body due to the involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus.
  • Vertigo, nausea, nystagmus due to vestibular nuclei involvement.
  • Ataxia and dysmetria because of the involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
  • While some symptoms match, the facial weakness characteristic of facial nerve involvement is not a feature of lateral medullary lesions.
  • If there was no mention of facial weakness then lateral medullary syndrome would had been the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

 

Stroke symptoms

 

Rule of 4’s

 

  1. 4 cranial nerves originate above pons (2 in midbrain), 4 in pons, 4 in medulla
  2. 4 midline cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12) (divide equally into 12 except 1 and 2)
  3. 4 Midline structures that begin with M 
    • Motor pathway (aka corticospinal tract)
    • Medial lemniscus
    • Medial longitudinal fasciculus
    • Medial cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12)
  4. 4 structures to the Side that begin with S 
    • Spinocerebellar pathway (ipsilateral ataxia of arm and leg)
    • Spinothalamic pathway
    • Sensory portion of CN V
    • Sympathetic pathway

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth. (BNS 229)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (up to 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 7 years. (BNS 238)

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease. Identify the true statement about intermittent claudication: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

 

Most commonly felt in the calf muscles: Correct. Intermittent claudication most commonly affects the calf muscles because the disease often affects the arteries supplying the lower limbs, usually the superficial femoral artery (70% of cases). Patients describe it as a cramping or aching sensation that occurs with walking or exertion and is relieved with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Felt at rest: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest. It occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the muscles during exertion.

 

Option C. Day to day distance is variable: Incorrect. While the severity of peripheral artery disease can change over time (especially without treatment), typically, the distance a person can walk before symptoms begin is fairly consistent, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Relieved after getting out of bed: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication pain is typically relieved after a few minutes of rest and doesn't specifically correlate with getting out of bed. The pain usually occurs during physical activities, such as walking, and subsides with rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles due to the high prevalence of peripheral artery disease affecting the arteries that supply the lower limbs. This condition is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest.

questions.text: A patient presents with a clinical scenario of obstructive jaundice. Which of the following results can be seen on Van der Bergh's reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Direct positive

 

In obstructive jaundice, the Van den Bergh reaction may show a positive result for direct bilirubin. Direct bilirubin is also known as conjugated bilirubin, and it is water-soluble. Elevated levels of direct bilirubin in the blood can be an indicator of liver or biliary tract dysfunction, which is often seen in obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indirect positive: Indirect bilirubin, also known as unconjugated bilirubin, is typically associated with hemolytic disorders rather than obstructive jaundice. Therefore, in the context of obstructive jaundice, the Van den Bergh reaction may not show a positive result for indirect bilirubin.

 

Option C. Both positive: In the context of obstructive jaundice, it's more common for the Van den Bergh reaction to show a positive result for direct bilirubin (conjugated bilirubin) rather than indirect bilirubin. However, if there is a combination of liver dysfunction and hemolysis, both direct and indirect bilirubin levels may be elevated, resulting in both being positive on the Van den Bergh reaction.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrin: Coproporphyrin is not typically measured using the Van den Bergh reaction. It is a different component related to porphyrin metabolism and is not directly associated with the assessment of bilirubin levels in obstructive jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Van den Bergh reaction is a chemical reaction used to measure bilirubin levels in blood, specifically amount of conjugated bilirubin in the blood.

 

Principle: bilirubin reacts with diazotized sulphanilic acid to produce purple colored azobilirubin. This reaction is highly useful in understanding the nature of jaundice.

 

This test helps to identify the type of jaundice –

 

  1. The serum of the patient is mixed with diazo reagent. If a red color develops immediately, it is called a direct positive. It happens if conjugated bilirubin is present.
  2. In an indirect positive test, the patient's serum is first treated with alcohol and later mixed with diazo reagent. This causes development of a red color. It is seen if unconjugated bilirubin is present.
  3. If both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are present the reaction is termed a biphasic reaction.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with neck stiffness and severe headache with CT showing blood in the basal cistern suggests towards the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is an extra axial intracranial hemorrhage and denotes the presence of blood within the subarachnoid space. NCCT shows the hyperdense “star of death” appearance.

 

The modified Fisher scale is a grading method for SAH as seen on non-contrast CT (NCCT). The Hunt and Hess scale is used to describe the severity of SAH and to predict survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Meningitis can also present with neck stiffness and headache. NCCT would be normal. CE-MRI shows thickened enhancing meninges.

 

Option C: Intraparenchymal hemorrhage is acute accumulation of blood within the parenchyma of the brain and on CT scan a hyperdense collection of blood, often with surrounding hypodense edema.

 

Option D: Hemorrhagic stroke is a broader classification and usually indicated IC bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a critical condition indicated by CT findings of blood in the subarachnoid space, presenting clinically with rapid onset headache and neck stiffness. It requires immediate medical attention and further evaluation with grading scales like the modified Fisher scale to assess severity and guide treatment.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that affects the structure of the heart, specifically the four major components of the heart: the pulmonary valve, the right ventricle, the ventricular septum, and the aortic valve. It is a combination of four heart defects, which are:

 

  1. Pulmonary stenosis - narrowing of the pulmonary valve, which reduces blood flow to the lungs.
  2. Ventricular septal defect - a hole in the wall that separates the right and left ventricles, which allows oxygen-poor and oxygen-rich blood to mix.
  3. Overriding aorta - the aorta is located over the ventricular septal defect, which allows blood to flow from both the left and right ventricles to the body.
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy - thickening of the right ventricle due to increased workload, which can lead to heart failure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): This condition typically shows plethoric lung fields and a wide, fixed split of S2. The X-ray findings in the question do not correlate with ASD, as it does not present with a boot-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD usually shows wide, variable splitting of S2 and plethoric lung fields due to increased pulmonary blood flow. The X-ray findings described do not match VSD.

 

Option D. Ebstein's anomaly: This condition often presents with a box-shaped heart due to maternal lithium intake during pregnancy. The X-ray findings in the question do not show a box-shaped heart, thus not fitting Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JC Virus: Known for causing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), especially in patients with severe immunodeficiency, but it is less common than CMV in affecting renal transplant patients in the early months post-transplant.

 

Option C. BK Virus: This virus can affect renal transplant recipients by causing BK virus-associated nephropathy, which can lead to graft dysfunction and loss. However, its peak incidence typically occurs slightly later than CMV.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): While EBV can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), it is not as commonly the predominant pathogen in the early post-transplant period compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and managing CMV infection in the early months following renal transplantation is crucial due to its potential to cause significant morbidity and impact on graft survival. Monitoring for CMV activity and initiating pre-emptive or therapeutic antiviral treatment as indicated is key to improving transplant outcomes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with a history of advanced-stage colorectal cancer is being evaluated for a new chemotherapy regimen. The oncologist is considering drugs that would inhibit DNA synthesis as a part of her treatment. Which of the following drugs is a known inhibitor of DNA synthesis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6-Mercaptopurine

 

6-Mercaptopurine is a purine analog that acts by inhibiting the purine synthesis, required for the synthesis of DNA, in the S phase of the cell cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mitomycin acts as an alkylating agent which leads to DNA damage by creating cross links.

 

Option C. Actinomycin acts by creating single-strand breaks in DNA. It blocks RNA transcription as well.

 

Option D. L-Asparaginase causes the breakdown of asparagine and thus interferes with protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

6-Mercaptopurine is a purine analog that inhibits DNA synthesis by interfering with purine synthesis, making it a critical component in chemotherapy regimens that aim to inhibit cell proliferation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type III

 

The classification of achalasia into types I, II, and III is based on the Chicago Classification. This system uses high-resolution manometry to categorize esophageal motility disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina
Complete vaginal atresia

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina. Identify the cause of this presentation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  •  Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain is suggestive of an obstructive cause.
  • O/e a bulge seen protruding from the vagina is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen.
  • The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina: This also will present as primary amenorrhoea with cyclical abdominal pain as the menstrual blood accumulates inside. But on examination, the bulge wont be seen at the introitus as the obstruction is higher up in a proximal or high transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option B. Complete vaginal atresia: In Complete vaginal atresia, also the symptoms of primary amenorrhoea and cyclical abdominal pain will be present, but again the obstruction will be high. There will be hematometra. Local examination will reveal an absent vagina or a bling ending vagina.

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: In cervical agenesis, again there will be hematometra, I.e. the obstruction is higher up and there will not ne any bulge seen on local exam.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain and a bulge protruding from the vagina is indicative of an imperforate hymen, requiring cruciate incision and drainage of hematocolpos.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: An employee who has been diagnosed with tuberculosis is eligible for an extended sickness benefit for? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 2 years

 

Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948, employees who are diagnosed with specific long-term illnesses, including tuberculosis, are eligible for an extended sickness benefit. This benefit provides financial support to cover a significant portion of their wages during prolonged periods of illness. The extended sickness benefit offers 80% of the employee's wages for up to 2 years. This provision ensures that employees have continued financial support while they are unable to work due to their medical condition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 years

 

  • The X-ray shows 7 Carpal bones. Thus, minimum age is 5 here.
  • Also, pisiform is not seen. Hence, the age is between 5-12.
  • The best answer is 7 years as the normal age range for appearance of pisiform is 8-12 years.

 

BONE AGE

 

  • Left hand and wrist X-ray PA view – most commonly used for bone age assessment – Based on appearance of carpal bones
  • First to appear is Capitate, then in a counter-clockwise fashion except pisiform which is the last carpal bone to appear
  • Pisiform is ossified at the age of nine to 13 years as evident from different studies.
  • The appearance of ossification center of pisiform bone is one of the important evidence for estimating age among young children between nine to 13 years.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:
