Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule which are re-opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced.

 

In Modified Young's operation, partial closure of the nostril is done to avoid discomfort.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasomotor rhinitis - Typically managed with medications such as antihistamines and nasal sprays; surgery is not a standard treatment.

 

Option C. Invasive aspergillosis - Treatment involves antifungal medications; surgical debridement may be necessary but does not involve closing the nostrils.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis - Managed with allergy medications, immunotherapy, and avoiding allergens; surgery is not indicated for occluding nostrils.

 

Educational Objective:


Young's operation is a unique surgical technique reserved for severe cases of atrophic rhinitis where other treatments have failed. This procedure helps in restoring the normal function and structure of the nasal mucosa by temporarily occluding the nostrils to allow healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 173

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 180-220

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD →Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD →Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD →Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

So, 68% population will cover, Mean ± 1SD.

Mean = 200

Standard Deviation = 20

 

68% population will lie between = 200 ± 20 = 180 - 220

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Oral amoxicillin for five days

 

According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, the management of childhood pneumonia has been updated based on new evidence. In the given scenario, a 2-year-old child presents with a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and chest indrawing, which fits the criteria for pneumonia but without general danger signs. According to the revised classification, the appropriate management for this case is oral amoxicillin for five days and home care advice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately: This is recommended for children showing general danger signs or very severe disease, not for pneumonia with chest indrawing without other danger signs.

 

Option C. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours: This would be applicable for severe cases requiring inpatient care, not for managing a case of pneumonia without general danger signs at an outpatient department.

 

Option D. Start antipyretics urgently: While antipyretics may be used to manage fever, they do not address the underlying pneumonia and are not the primary management step in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Mannitol salt agar
Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar
Sorbitol MacConkey agar

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli O157: H7? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

E.coli O157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, 0157:7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC 0157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

O157: H7 strains also are negative for -glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-B-glucuronide test. More than 90 per cent of other E. coli tests positive with this substrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol salt agar: This medium is primarily used for the isolation of Staphylococcus species because it contains high concentrations of salt, inhibiting most other bacteria.

 

Option B. Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar: Used for the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species, which are also important enteric pathogens.

 

Option D. CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) medium: Designed for urinary tract infections to inhibit the swarming of Proteus species and allow the differentiation of other urinary pathogens based on lactose fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sorbitol MacConkey agar is critical for distinguishing E. coli O157 from other E. coli strains due to its unique inability to ferment sorbitol, helping guide appropriate public health responses and treatment options during outbreaks of foodborne illness.

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan’s syndrome

 

  • The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
  • When postpartum hemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels (pituitary apoplexy) and panhypopituitarism. It is characterized by:
    • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
    • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
    • Loss of sexual and axillary hair
    • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion
    • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor Syndrome: Also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin

 

Option C. Prolactinoma: This will not present lactation failure. Instead, there will be galactorrhea and symptoms like headache, luring of vision due to pressure effects of the prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Acromegaly: It is a disorder that results in excess growth of certain parts of the human body. It is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed. The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet. There may also be an enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose. Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision. Complications of the disease may include type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan’s syndrome is characterized by postpartum hemorrhage leading to vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, resulting in panhypopituitarism with symptoms like lactation failure and amenorrhea.

 

Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Amongst the poisons given below, which poison can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arsenic

 

Arsenic gets fixed to the bones and gets released from it very slowly over a period of time and thus can be detected in the bones for several years after death.

 

Toxicokinetic of Arsenic:

 

  1. Because of short half-life of arsenic in the blood, arsenic is rapidly cleared from the blood. Hence it is less reliable to detect arsenic poisoning.
  2. After clearing from blood, arsenic gets deposited in almost all the tissues where it is found for prolonged period. However, arsenic does not cross blood brain barrier.
  3. Highest concentration is found in liver (followed by kidney)
  4. Urine becomes positive within 6 hours of poisoning and may continue to be positive for about 2-3 weeks. Urine is better than blood to detect arsenic poisoning.
  5. Arsenic also gets deposited in hair, nails, skin and bones where it remains for a much more prolonged time (even for years) after exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin in the blood but does not leave detectable residues in skeletal remains.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulphide: Hydrogen sulphide is a gas that affects soft tissues and is not detected in skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus can affect soft tissues but is not typically detected in bones long after death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arsenic can be found in skeletal remains for several years after death due to its strong binding to the bone matrix and slow release over time.

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Nephrogenic DI

 

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused by a mutation in the genes that encode for aquaporin channels, specifically Aquaporin-2. These channels are involved in water reabsorption in the kidney's collecting ducts. A defect in these channels impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine in response to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to the excretion of large amounts of dilute urine, despite the presence of adequate or even elevated levels of ADH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liddle syndrome:  Is characterized by gain of function mutation of ENaC channels causing HTN, Hypokalemia with metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Occurs due to mutation in CFTR membrane proteins.

 

Option D. Occurs due to mutation in Ascending Loop of Henle (Na-K-CL /Bertin/NA-Cl transporters).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

A mutation in the aquaporin channels, particularly Aquaporin-2, leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition is characterized by an inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine in response to ADH, resulting in the production of large volumes of dilute urine. Understanding the genetic basis of nephrogenic DI is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management, which typically involves addressing the symptoms and managing water intake rather than hormone therapy.

 

Reference - Harrison/Diabetes Insipidus/Chapter 381

choices.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter
The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both a and b

 

Rape on Children:

 

In rape of a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because of two reasons:

 

  • Vaginal opening is very small, hence penetration very difficult. Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. And as such, only redness and tenderness of vulva may be caused.
  • Hymen is deeply situated, hence even if some penetration occurred, it is not ruptured.

 

Also, in a child, there may be no signs or very few signs of general violence since the child has no idea of the act and is also unable to offer resistance.

 

However, in rare cases of great violence, the penis may be forcibly introduced, causing rupture of the vaginal vault, Hymen and associated visceral injuries. In this case the injuries will be more severe than adults and such injuries might result in death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoarthritis

 

  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand.

 

 

  • Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis spares DIP and involves PIP, MCP and Wrist.
  • Diseases And Usual Joints Affected:

 

 

  • Characteristic Joint involvement in HANDS in various Arthritis:

 

 

 

 

The hand (to diagnose arthritis)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Commonly Involved Joints (14 joints are used for diagnosis according to 1987 criterion – Right or left side) are Wrist joint, Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, Elbow joint, Knee joint, Ankle joint, and Metatarsophalangeal joint. Less Commonly Involved joints are Upper cervical spine (facet joint) with Atlantoaxial subluxation, Hip joint, Temporomandibular joint, Subtalar and forefoot joints. Usually, DIP is not involved but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops. The involvement in late stages is due to the pull of tendons/soft tissues in these deformities. Lumbar Spine is Usually Spared in RA.

 

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option D. Jaccoud arthropathy. It typically affects MCP joints but can also affect PIP joints of the hand, wrist joint and knee joint. It is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by ulnar deviation of 2nd-5th fingers with MCP joint subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E-FAST

 

Given the scenario described with the stab injury, bradycardia, hypotension, and clear lung fields on chest radiography, there's a concern for a potential cardiac injury and tamponade, and E-FAST would be the most rapid and effective tool to evaluate for these as well as other potential injuries.

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma. It is an ultrasound examination that is performed on trauma patients in the emergency department to identify any life-threatening conditions that need to be addressed immediately. The components of E-FAST include:

 

  1. Subxiphoid view: This assesses for pericardial effusion (fluid around the heart) which could indicate a cardiac tamponade.
  2. Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid (which could indicate internal bleeding) in Morrison's pouch (the space between the liver and the right kidney).
  3. Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid in the splenorenal recess (the space between the spleen and the left kidney).
  4. Suprapubic view: This assesses for free fluid in the pelvis.
  5. Anterior Chest view: This is performed bilaterally to assess for pneumothorax (air in the pleural space that can cause lung collapse) or hemothorax (blood in the pleural space).

 

The "extended" in E-FAST refers to additional views which can be added depending on the patient's condition and the clinician's suspicion of injury. These may include views of the thoracic spine and the lung bases to look for signs of additional injury.

 

 

E-FAST: Given the patient's presentation with hypotension, this would be the most appropriate initial step to rapidly identify a life-threatening condition in an unstable patient, like cardiac tamponade, which can cause bradycardia and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tube thoracostomy: Also known as a chest tube placement, it is used to treat pneumothorax or hemothorax by draining air or blood from the pleural space. However, in this patient, the chest radiography showed clear lung fields, suggesting that he does not have a significant hemothorax or pneumothorax.

 

Option C. CECT chest: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the chest can provide detailed images of the chest's anatomy and may identify injuries to the thoracic structures. However, in an acutely unstable trauma patient, a CT scan is not the best initial test due to the time it takes to perform and the need to transport the patient to the scanner.

 

Option D. CECT abdomen: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen can identify injuries to the abdominal organs. However it will be avoided in an unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST is a rapid ultrasound examination used in trauma patients to assess for life-threatening conditions such as cardiac tamponade, hemothorax, and pneumothorax. It is the most appropriate initial step for an unstable patient with a stab injury, bradycardia, and hypotension, given its ability to quickly provide critical information needed for immediate management.

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

 

The best advice for the exposed students is to receive antibiotic prophylaxis. This is recommended for close contacts of a person with meningococcal meningitis, such as household members, intimate contacts, and anyone who has had direct contact with the patient's oral secretions. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible after exposure and can be effective in preventing secondary cases of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Two doses of polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination is important, it takes time to provide protection. Therefore, it is not the best option for immediate protection in this situation.

 

Option C. Two doses of conjugate vaccine: The conjugate vaccine is recommended for adolescents and children, but similar to the polysaccharide vaccine, it does not provide immediate protection. Antibiotic prophylaxis is still necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Option D. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine: Again, vaccination alone is not sufficient for immediate protection, and antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tryptophan

 

Tryptophan due to presence of conjugated double bonds in phenyl group has a strong UV absorbance at 280 nm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginine: Arginine does not have a strong absorbance peak at 280 nm, so it would not significantly increase UV absorbance at this wavelength when substituted for alanine.

 

Option C. Guanine: Guanine is a nucleotide base found in DNA and RNA, but it is not an amino acid. It absorbs at 260 nm.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine, like arginine, does not have a strong absorbance peak at 280 nm and would not significantly increase UV absorbance when substituted for alanine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

UV absorption occur due to conjugated double bonds in the ring. So, to increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm, alanine should be replaced by any aromatic amino acids such as Phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan. Out of these, tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine due to presence of two rings in its side chain compared to only one in other two amino acids.

 

All other amino acid given here do not absorb UV light due to lack of conjugated double bonds.

 

Guanine is nitrogenous base not amino acid. It absorbs at 260nm.

 

Additional information:

 

Absorbance of compounds:

 

  • Proteins - 280nm (Aromatic amino acids)
  • Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases)
  • NADH/NADPH - 340 nm
  • Porphyrins - 400 nm (Soret band).

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paralytic squint

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

 

Paralytic Squint:

  • Caused by paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles due to nerve damage or muscle pathology.
  • Secondary deviation (movement of the non-paralyzed eye when the paralyzed eye is fixating) is greater than primary deviation.
  • The forced duction test is negative, indicating no mechanical restriction.
  • Patients may experience diplopia and adopt a compensatory head posture to minimize double vision.

 

Additional Information

 

The squint may be either concomitant or incomitant.

• Concomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes.

• Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes.

 

 

FORCED DUCTION TEST:

 

  • Performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of extraocular muscle and that due to mechanical restriction of the ocular movements.
  • FDT is positive (resistance encountered during passive rotation) in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction.
  • FDT is negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concomitant Squint:

  • The angle of deviation is the same in all directions of gaze.
  • Commonly seen in childhood and associated with hereditary factors, uncorrected refractive errors, or perinatal injury.
  • Diplopia is typically absent because the brain suppresses the image from the deviating eye.

 

Option B.  Restrictive Squint:

  • Caused by mechanical restriction of the extraocular muscles due to conditions like thyroid eye disease, trauma, or fibrosis.
  • The forced duction test is positive, indicating resistance during passive eye movement due to mechanical restriction.
  • Diplopia is often present, and the degree of deviation varies depending on the direction of gaze.

 

Option D.  Pseudosquint:

  • An apparent squint where there is no actual misalignment of the eyes.
  • Commonly due to facial anatomical features such as epicanthal folds or a wide nasal bridge.
  • No actual deviation is present, and there are no associated symptoms like diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paralytic squint is characterized by secondary deviation greater than primary deviation and a negative forced duction test, indicating the absence of mechanical restriction.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is most likely affected here ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Interossei and lumbricals

 

  • Damage to the ulnar nerve can lead to weakness or atrophy of the lumbrical and interossei muscles in the hand.
  • These muscles play a crucial role in flexing the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extending the interphalangeal (IP) joints through their attachment to the dorsal digital expansions.
  • As a result of the nerve injury, the MCP joints may become extended, while the IP joints may become flexed.

 

Note: The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for

 

  • First and second lumbrical
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor digitorum: This muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and inserts into the dorsal digital expansions of the medial four fingers.

 

  • It acts primarily to extend the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and interphalangeal (IP) joints of the fingers.
  • If the extensor digitorum were affected, you would expect difficulty in extending the MCP and IP joints.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis: 

  • It refers to two muscles, the abductor pollicis longus (located in the forearm) and abductor pollicis brevis (intrinsic hand muscle) whose primary function is to abduct the thumb. Dysfunction would primarily impact thumb movements and would not lead to the clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: 

  • It is one of the thenar muscles of the hand and plays a key role in thumb movement, especially in its abduction. Like the abductor pollicis longus, an issue with this muscle would impact thumb movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interossei and lumbricals are the intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

  • The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. They act to flex the MCP joints and extend both the proximal and distal IP joints.
  • The interossei (both dorsal and palmar) act to abduct (DAB - Dorsal Abduct) and adduct (PAD - Palmar Adduct) the fingers at the MCP joints and assist the lumbricals in flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints.
  • If these muscles are affected, as indicated in the clinical picture, there would be an extension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints (due to unopposed action of extrinsic flexors and extensors).

choices.text: Vitamin B12 deficiency
Folate deficiency
Pyridoxine deficiency

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the classic causes of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Pernicious anemia is a type of megaloblastic anemia caused by autoimmune gastritis and an inability to produce intrinsic factors, resulting in vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Histologically, there is chronic atrophic gastritis with parietal cell loss, a prominent infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells similar to those seen in erythroid precursors.

 

There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

 

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the a and B subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Folate deficiency: Folate deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia with macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils but is not typically associated with atrophic gastritis.

 

  • Folate deficiency does not usually present with the same gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting) or the autoimmune component seen in pernicious anemia.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine deficiency: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with sideroblastic anemia, not megaloblastic anemia.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Option D. Niacin deficiency: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the "4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death.

 

  • It does not cause macrocytic anemia or atrophic gastritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency, often due to pernicious anemia, is characterized by macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and atrophic gastritis. This condition involves an autoimmune mechanism that impairs the production and function of intrinsic factor, essential for vitamin B12 absorption.

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-4

 

IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

 

IL-4 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in promoting B-cell differentiation and class switching to produce IgE antibodies. It is primarily produced by T-helper 2 (Th2) cells and stimulates B-cells to undergo isotype switching, leading to the production of IgE instead of other antibody isotypes, such as IgG or IgM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2:

 

Role: IL-2 is crucial for T-cell proliferation, survival, and activation. It is not directly involved in the induction of IgE production by B-cells.

 

Option C. IL-1:

 

Role: IL-1 is involved in inflammation and immune responses, acting as a pro-inflammatory cytokine. It does not directly induce IgE production.

 

Option D. IL-6:

 

Role: IL-6 is important for inflammation, immune responses, and hematopoiesis. It has roles in the differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells, but it does not specifically induce IgE production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-4 is the key cytokine that stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE-secreting plasma cells, playing a crucial role in the allergic response and defense against parasites.

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loss of myelin sheath

 

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is primarily characterized by the autoimmune-mediated demyelination of central nervous system neurons. The myelin sheath is crucial for proper and fast electrical conduction along nerve fibers; it facilitates saltatory conduction, which allows the action potential to jump rapidly from one node of Ranvier to the next. The loss of this myelin sheath in MS results in significantly slowed and disrupted nerve signal conduction, which underlies many of the neurological symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gliosis: Gliosis is not seen in MS but seen in viral encephalitis, Alzheimer's disease, traumatic brain injury, and gliomas

 

Option C. Defect at node of Ranvier: Although alterations in the nodes of Ranvier occur secondary to demyelination, the primary issue is the loss of the myelin sheath itself, not initial defects at the nodes.

 

Option D. Leaky Na+ channel: This option refers to a specific type of channelopathy that isn't characteristic of MS. In MS, the problem is more about the insulation (myelin) around the nerve fibers rather than the ion channels within the nerve cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other.

 

Reference - Harrison/Multiple sclerosis/Chap 444

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

 

Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

 

On light microscopy, characteristic feature is no apparent abnormality in the glomeruli except for slight increase in the mesangial matrix at the most.

 

 

By electron microscopy, the most characteristic feature of the disease is identified which is diffuse flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and, hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.

 

In contrast to other types of GN, no deposits are visible, and the GBM is normal. No complement or immunoglobulin deposits are detected using immunofluorescence microscopy (nil deposit disease).

 

It's also seen in other diseases like membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. These diseases are also known as podocytopathies because they affect podocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroid resistant glomerulonephritis: This term is more of a clinical description rather than a specific pathological diagnosis. Steroid-resistant cases can include various glomerulonephritis types such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which also shows podocyte effacement but is not the classic example of it.

 

Option C. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is associated with severe glomerular damage and rapid loss of kidney function. It does not specifically show effacement of podocyte foot processes as its primary feature.

 

Option D. Chronic glomerulonephritis: Chronic glomerulonephritis encompasses various forms of long-standing glomerular diseases leading to chronic kidney damage. It is associated with glomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis but not specifically with podocyte foot process effacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-Arginine

 

Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from L-arginine through the action of enzymes known as nitric oxide synthases (NOS). There are different forms of NOS enzymes, including endothelial NOS (eNOS) and neuronal NOS (nNOS), which are involved in the production of NO in various tissues and cells. L-arginine serves as the precursor for NO synthesis in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L-Citrulline: While L-citrulline is related to the nitric oxide pathway, it is not the direct precursor for NO synthesis. Instead, L-citrulline can be converted back into L-arginine in the body, and then L-arginine is used for NO production. This makes L-citrulline indirectly involved in the regulation of NO levels.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an amino acid with its own metabolic functions in the body but is not a precursor for NO.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine is also not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an essential amino acid with its own roles in protein synthesis and metabolism but is not part of the NO synthesis pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells.

 

 

NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). It causes vasodilatation and acts through the formation of secondary messenger cGMP.

 

NOS (multienzyme complex)

 

  • There are three isoforms of NOS 
    1. iNOS- inducible
    2. nNOS - neuronal
    3. eNOS- endothelial

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protein degradation

 

The primary function of the proteasome is to degrade intracellular proteins. It plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular homeostasis by breaking down unneeded or damaged proteins. Proteins are targeted for degradation by being tagged with a small protein called ubiquitin, and the proteasome then recognizes and degrades these ubiquitinated proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein folding: The proteasome is not involved in protein folding. Protein folding is a process where newly synthesized proteins attain their three-dimensional, functional structures. It typically occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and is assisted by chaperone proteins.

 

Option B. Post-translational modification: While some post-translational modifications of proteins can occur in the proteasome, its primary function is not post-translational modification. Post-translational modifications include processes like phosphorylation, glycosylation, and ubiquitination, which may occur on proteins both before and after they enter the proteasome.

 

Option D. Protein sorting: Protein sorting involves directing proteins to their correct cellular locations, such as organelles like the mitochondria or lysosomes. The proteasome's main function is not related to protein sorting but rather protein degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells. The proteasome assembly has a central cylindrical hollow core. Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein into small oligopeptides of 5-6 amino acids length

 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.    

 

It plays the major role in the degradation of proteins, and is particularly associated with disposal of misfolded proteins and regulatory enzymes that have short half-lives.

questions.text: Plethoric lung fields are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

Plethoric lung fields are indicative of increased pulmonary arterial blood flow and are seen in:

 

  • Left to right shunts
  • TAPVC
  • TGA
  • Persistent truncus arteriosus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tricuspid atresia does not have plethoric lung fields because in this condition right atrium is atretic.

 

Option C. Ebstein’s anomaly has atrialisation of RV, leading to small outflow tract, and resultant reduced pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option D. TOF has oligemia due to infundibular pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TAPVC is characterized by plethoric lung fields due to the excessive flow of oxygenated blood returning to the right side of the heart and flowing back into the lungs instead of going to the systemic circulation, leading to increased pulmonary pressure and congestion. This condition is a serious congenital heart defect that typically requires corrective surgery.

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dL and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-3 L of Normal saline over 1-3 hours

 

IV fluids are the next best management as the patient is in shock and needs immediate correction. ABG here could show HAGMA secondary to type A lactic acidosis or ketoacidosis. Hence, ABG wouldn’t help in the diagnosis here. Shock in patient with DKA is not common and suggest an underlying sepsis as excess glucotoxicity causes shift of H2O to the intravascular compartment. IV fluid bolus is given in the emergency immediately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin therapy is critical in the management of DKA, it should only be started after initial fluid resuscitation has been commenced and any electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium, have been assessed and addressed.

 

Option C. Arterial blood gas: While ABG can provide valuable information about the severity of acidosis and help guide management, it is not the immediate next step before ensuring adequate fluid resuscitation.

 

Option D. Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV: An insulin bolus can potentially exacerbate hypokalemia in the setting of DKA. Fluid resuscitation and stabilization should precede any insulin bolus or infusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of DKA presenting with signs of dehydration and shock, the initial management should focus on aggressive fluid resuscitation to stabilize the patient before initiating insulin therapy. This approach not only addresses the immediate life-threatening condition but also prepares the body for further metabolic correction.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/DKA/Chapter 404

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Taking CT scan of the patient

 

Taking CT scan of the patient: Incorrect. This is not part of the primary survey. After the primary survey, if the patient is stabilized, a secondary survey is conducted which is a more thorough examination and may involve advanced imaging like CT scans to further delineate injuries.

 

Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

 

Primary survey consists of five components, remembered by the mnemonic "ABCDE":

 

  1. Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection: The first step is to ensure the patient has a patent (open) airway, and to protect the cervical spine in case of potential injury.
  2. Breathing and ventilation: This step includes assessing the patient's breathing and ventilation. This can involve checking for symmetric chest rise, listening for breath sounds, and looking for any signs of respiratory distress or chest injury.
  3. Circulation with haemorrhage control: This involves assessing the patient's circulation and looking for signs of active bleeding. Measures such as fluid resuscitation may be initiated during this step if the patient is in shock.
  4. Disability: This involves a quick evaluation of the patient's neurological status, often using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS).
  5. Exposure/Environmental control: The patient should be fully undressed to allow a complete examination. However, care should be taken to prevent hypothermia, which can worsen outcomes in trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measuring blood pressure: This is a part of assessing Circulation.

 

Option B. Removing clothes to inspect for wounds: This is a part of Exposure/Environmental control. It's crucial to remove clothing so that injuries aren't missed. However, while ensuring exposure, care should also be taken to maintain the patient's body temperature and prevent hypothermia.

 

Option D. Checking airway patency: This is part of Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection. Ensuring a clear airway is a top priority. Airway obstruction takes least time to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary survey in trauma care includes Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure/Environmental control. Advanced imaging studies like CT scans are part of the secondary survey, conducted after initial stabilization.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condyloma accuminata

 

  • Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).
  • The main causative agent is HPV-6 and 11.
  • Lesions: Typically, they grow in clusters along a narrow stalk giving it a cauliflower appearance but at times the stalk may be broad and thick
  • Treatment: Cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision or topical use of 5-fluorouracil, trichloro-acetic acid or intralesional interferon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum:

 

  • Caused by a pox virus transmitted by body contact or towels or clothing.
  • It is commonly seen in immunodeficient subject or with HIV infections.
  • The lesions vary in size up to 1 cm, dome shaped, pearly-white in colour and often umbilicated.
  • They are usually multiple and can occur anywhere in the skin and genitalia.
  • Microscopic appearance reveals numerous inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies) in the cytoplasm of the cells with Giemsa stain.
  • Treatment: 
    • Evacuation of caseous material from the nodule under local anaesthetic is done.
    • The floor of the nodule is then treated chemically with ferric sub-sulphate or trichloroacetic acid (85%) solution.
    • Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is applied until a halo of ice is formed around the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Chancroid:

 

  • Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by infection with Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may be accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy. 

 

 

Option D. Herpes:

 

  • The causative organism is herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 and 2.
  • It is usually transmitted sexually by an infected partner/ oro-genital contact.
  • The incubation period is 2–14 days.
  • Clinical Features: 
    • Initially, red painful inflammatory areas appear commonly on the clitoris, labia, vestibule, vagina, perineum, and cervix.
    • Multiple vesicles appear which progress into multiple shallow ulcers and ultimately heal up spontaneously by crusting.
    • It takes about 3 weeks to complete the process.
    • Inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs.
    • Constitutional symptoms include fever, malaise, and headache.
    •  There may be vulvar burning, pruritus, dysuria, or retention of urine.
  • Treatment: Acyclovir

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) are characterized by multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, caused by HPV-6 and 11, and treated with cryotherapy, electrocautery, laser therapy, surgical excision, or topical agents.

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the base of the thumb. When the thumb is extended, this depression becomes more pronounced. The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. When you extend and abduct the thumb, you can typically feel these tendons, especially the abductor pollicis longus, become taut along the lateral border of the wrist, outlining the snuffbox.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. It extends the thumb's distal phalanx. The abductor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence and doesn't directly contribute to the boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox. Its tendon is not found in this region; instead, it inserts into the base of the thumb's proximal phalanx.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: As already mentioned, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. The extensor pollicis brevis, in conjunction with the abductor pollicis longus, forms the lateral boundary. However, they don't together form just one boundary of the snuffbox.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary of the snuffbox, as mentioned above. The abductor pollicis brevis, on the other hand, doesn't form any part of the snuffbox boundaries.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the most likely diagnosis in view of the following points
    • Age
    • Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea
    • Adnexal mass with ascites

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancy may present with weight loss, ascites and a pelvic mass. But a young age and amenorrhea do not go in favor of ovarian malignancy

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy will be an acute presentation and will not present with fever/ weight loss

 

Option D. Submucous fibroid: Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia/ inter-menstrual bleeding and the uterus will be uniformly enlarged. There will not be any pelvic mass. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis with a tubo-ovarian mass is suspected in young patients presenting with low-grade fever, weight loss, amenorrhea, and a pelvic mass with signs of ascites.

 

Ref: Page no 141, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

 

Explanation

 

Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.

 

This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.

 

  • 24 Hours After Delivery: Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours after ovulation: Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.

 

Option C. NREM Sleep: Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.

 

Option D. After running for 1 hour: Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:

 

During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.

 

Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.

 

Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.

 

Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.

 

Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.

 

Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.

 

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spontaneous respiratory effort

 

  • The capnograph shows a characteristic pattern known as the curare notch or curare cleft.
  • This pattern indicates spontaneous inspiratory effort by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • This occurs when the patient attempts to breathe against the ventilator cycle, causing a dip in the capnograph waveform.
  • The appropriate next step would be to paralyze the patient again by administering an additional dose of muscle relaxant to ensure proper synchronization with the ventilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal intubation: In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected. The waveform would be almost flat.

 

 

Option B. Inspiration with cardiac oscillations: Cardiac oscillations can appear on the capnograph as small oscillations or ripples on the expiratory plateau due to the beating of the heart causing minor fluctuations in airway pressure. This is not characterized by a distinct cleft or notch.

 

 

Option C. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm causes a "shark fin" appearance on the capnograph due to obstructed airflow and prolonged expiration. The waveform would show a slanted, rather than a squared-off, expiratory plateau.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A curare notch or cleft on a capnograph indicates spontaneous respiratory effort in a patient who is supposed to be fully ventilated under muscle relaxants, requiring re-administration of the muscle relaxant to ensure proper mechanical ventilation.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1311

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

 

The saccule develops from pars inferior.

 

Development of internal ear:

 

  • Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week. Ectoderm in the region of hindbrain thickens to form an auditory placode, which is invaginated to form auditory vesicles or the otocyst. The latter then differentiates into the endolymphatic duct and sac; the utricle, the semicircular ducts; and saccule and the cochlea. Development of the phylogenetically older part of labyrinth—pars superior (semicircular canals and utricle) takes place earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea).

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Saculus anterior - Not a term typically associated with the development of the ear's structures.

 

Option B. Saculus posterior - Similarly, this is not a recognized term in the developmental anatomy of the ear.

 

Option C. Pars superior - Incorrect, as this part contributes to the development of the semicircular canals and utricle, not the saccule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The developmental origins of the inner ear structures, such as the saccule from the pars inferior, is crucial for comprehending various auditory and vestibular functions, as well as pathologies associated with these areas.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 13

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

 

Explanation

 

This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.

 

Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.

 

Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.

 

Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) For tubal ligation

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument shown is not used for ligating the uterine artery. Instead, instruments like clamps or ligature carriers are typically used for this purpose during a hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument is not used for ovarian cystectomy, which involves the removal of cysts from the ovary. Instruments like scissors, graspers, and cautery devices are commonly used in ovarian cystectomy procedures.

 

Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: This is incorrect. While laparoscopic instruments are used in the surgical management of ectopic pregnancy, the specific instrument shown (laparoscopic ring applicator) is not used for this purpose. Instruments used for ectopic pregnancy surgery include laparoscopic graspers, scissors, and suction devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The laparoscopic ring applicator (laparocator) is used for applying Falope rings during tubal ligation procedures.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Satellite lesion

 

Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

 

The signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reverse hypopyon:  "Reverse hypopyon" can form when emulsified silicone oil used during vitreoretinal surgery enters the anterior chamber of the eye. The silicone oil floats in the aqueous to look like a layered hypopyon in the upper portion of the anterior chamber. Silicone Oil in anterior chamber is called hyperoleon.

 

 

Inverted or reverse hypopyon as a result of emulsification into the anterior chamber. Migration of silicon oil into the anterior chamber displaces aqueous inferiorly and results in a density gradient demarcation line.

 

Option B. Dendritic ulcer on fluorescein dye: Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

 

Pseudodendritic ulcer is caused by acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Ring abscess: Can be seen in recurrent stromal herpes keratitis or acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Satellite lesions around the main ulcer are characteristic of fungal corneal ulcers, along with irregular margins, immune rings, and potentially immobile hypopyon.

choices.text: Lead poisoning
Iron deficiency anemia
Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic alcoholism

 

The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:

 

  • Folate accumulation in the liver
  • Excessive urinary loss
  • Impaired folate metabolism
  • Chronic alcoholics frequently have insufficient dietary intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead poisoning: Lead poisoning typically causes microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. Peripheral smear findings in lead poisoning include basophilic stippling of RBCs, not macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, which contrasts with the macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia generally presents with normocytic or slightly macrocytic RBCs, but not to the extent seen in megaloblastic anemia. Additionally, hyper-segmented neutrophils are not a typical feature of hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrocytic anemia with hyper-segmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, often due to folate deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to impaired folate metabolism and poor dietary intake.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

 

The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

 

 

 

Metaplasia of normal columnar (left) to squamous epithelium (right) in a bronchus

 

  • Another example of metaplasia: BARRETTs esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal development or growth of cells, tissues, or organs. It is characterized by changes in cell size, shape, and organization. Dysplasia can be a precursor to cancer but does not describe the replacement of one cell type by another.

 

Option B. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy is the increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the tissue or organ. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Option C. Atrophy: Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of cells, tissues, or organs, often due to decreased use, insufficient nutrition, or aging. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Equal to dead space

 

Explanation

 

VA/Q= infinity suggests that Q is 0 which implies that there is no exchange of 02 & CO2, and no gaseous exchange occurs in dead space.

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus: Incorrect, as this condition would lead to an area with no ventilation (blocked by the foreign body) potentially resulting in a low V/Q ratio in the affected area rather than an infinite V/Q ratio.

 

Option C. When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal: Incorrect, as this does not directly relate to the ventilation-perfusion ratio concept. This option is more a reflection of gas exchange effectiveness rather than a description of V/Q mismatches.

 

Option D. The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg: Incorrect, these values are typical for normal alveolar air and do not indicate a V/Q mismatch situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VA /Q ratio is infinite in the following scenarios -

 

  1. Ventilation is normal but there is no perfusion.
  2. No gaseous exchange through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  3. The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  4. Partial pressures of the 02 and CO, are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

choices.text: Tissue factor

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Factor 2

 

Explanation

 

Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.

 

Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.

 

This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Factor 11: Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.

 

Option C. Tissue factor: Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.

 

Option D. Factor 5: Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the image below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Herpes labialis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Herpes labialis, also known as a cold sore, is characterized by clusters of numerous grouped vesicles around the lips.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are very common & are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) commonly and type 2 (HSV-2) rarely are responsible for its occurrence

 

Treatment: Foscarnet or cidofovir if acyclovir resistance develops in a patient with recurrent Herpes labialis. They act on viral DNA polymerases thus blocking DNA replication.

  • Oral acyclovir 200 mg and 5% topical acyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis:

 

  • It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Causative agent: Coxsackie virus. 

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: Pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules seen due to infection by Pox virus.
