Option C. Impetigo: It is of 2 types:

 

  • Bullous – S. aureus
  • Non-bullous – S. aureus and Streptococcus. Golden-yellow or honey coloured crust seen.
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes labialis is identified as condition characterized by recurrent clusters of vesicles on the lips, caused by the herpes simplex virus, and distinguish it from other vesicular or pustular lesions such as herpangina, molluscum contagiosum, and impetigo.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25 Page no 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th edition Page no 2721

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. According to King's College Criteria for predicting mortality in Acute Liver Failure (ALF), which of the following is not included?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

 

Explanation: 

 

King's College Criteria are widely used to predict mortality in patients with acute liver failure and identify those who may require urgent liver transplantation.

 

Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy: According to the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol causes, a duration of jaundice before the onset of encephalopathy greater than 7 days (not less than 7 days) is one of the parameters that might indicate the need for liver transplantation. If the encephalopathy develops rapidly after the onset of jaundice (i.e., within 7 days), it suggests a more acute and potentially reversible cause, such as acute viral hepatitis, which might recover without transplantation.

 

Given the information, the incorrect parameter in the King's College criteria for transplantation, would be "Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy" (Option D).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age <10 years: Age is a factor in the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure. Children aged less than 10 years are considered at higher risk and this age group may be included in the criteria for transplantation.

 

Option B. PT >100s: Prothrombin time (PT) reflects the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors. A greatly prolonged PT (>100 seconds) is an indication of severe liver dysfunction and is one of the King's College Criteria for both paracetamol and non-paracetamol-induced liver failure as a potential requirement for liver transplantation.

 

Option C. Bilirubin >300 µmol/L: An elevated bilirubin level indicates significant liver dysfunction. A bilirubin level greater than 300 µmol/L is one of the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure and suggests that liver transplantation may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

King's College Criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure include specific parameters such as prolonged PT, elevated bilirubin, and specific age groups. The duration of jaundice before the development of encephalopathy is significant if it exceeds 7 days. Jaundice for less than 7 days is not a parameter for transplantation.

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is characterized by development of morphologically similar lesions along the lines of trauma:  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isomorphic phenomenon

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

 

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Gottron's papule seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D: Meyerson phenomenon is a melanocytic nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon) as the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 123.2

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Elastic cartilage

 

  • This image displays a type of cartilage called elastic cartilage.
  • These elastic fibers give the cartilage its unique properties of flexibility and resilience, allowing it to easily return to its original shape after being bent or compressed.
  • On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of:
    • Chondrocytes within lacunae
    • Elastic fibres in the matrix
    • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer
  • Function: Maintains the shape of certain structures while allowing great flexibility.
  • Locations: Found in the ear (auricle or pinna), epiglottis, and eustachian tubes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyaline Cartilage: This is the most common type of cartilage. It appears glassy and smooth under the microscope. The extracellular matrix contains a large amount of type II collagen and is filled with chondrocytes, the cells responsible for cartilage synthesis.

 

  • Function: Provides smooth surfaces for movement at joints, flexibility, and support.
  • Locations: Found on joint surfaces, the rib tips, sternum, nose, trachea, and larynx.

 

Option C. Articular Cartilage: A type of hyaline cartilage that covers the surfaces of bones at synovial joints. It has a smooth, slippery surface that decreases friction.

 

  • Function: Enables bones of a synovial joint to slide over each other with minimal friction, distributes load in the joint, and allows for shock absorption.
  • Locations: Covers the ends of bones in all movable joints.

 

Option D. Fibrocartilage: This is a tough, dense, and fibrous material that contains a mix of hyaline cartilage and dense collagen fibers.

 

  • Function: Provides rigidity and shock absorption where it's needed, such as in areas of frequent pressure and pulling.
  • Locations: Found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and the points where tendons attach to bones.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: Which nerve innervates the muscle marked in the given image? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dorsal scapular nerve

 

The above image shows the levator scapulae muscle, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

 

Dorsal scapular nerve arises from the brachial plexus, usually from the cervical nerve root C5. Muscles Supplied are Rhomboid major, Rhomboid minor and Levator scapulae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suprascapular nerve: It is derived from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the union of the C5 and C6 nerve roots. Muscles Supplied are Supraspinatus and Infraspinatus.

 

Option C. From the dorsal rami of C1: It is a spinal nerve root. Muscles Supplied are Suboccipital muscles (rectus capitis posterior major, rectus capitis posterior minor, obliquus capitis superior, and obliquus capitis inferior).

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: It Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and contains fibers from C5 and C6. Muscles Supplied are Subscapularis and teres major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include: Superficial (appendicular) group of back muscles

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

 

KAWASAKI DISEASE MNEMONIC

 

CRASH & Burn

 

  • Conjunctivitis (non-purulent)
  • Rash
  • Adenopathy (cervical and commonly unilateral)
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Hands (palmar erythema/ swelling)
  • Burn (fever lasting at least 5 days or more)

 

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction.

 

Rx: Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Option D. Henoch-Schönlein purpura is an acute, systemic, immune complex-mediated, leukocytoclastic vasculitis. It is characterized by a clinical triad of palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), abdominal pain, and arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is characterized by a persistent fever, erythematous and polymorphous rash, edema of hands and feet, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It primarily affects children under 4 years old and can lead to serious coronary artery complications if not treated appropriately.

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores

 

This is the most likely cause. Folate and vitamin B12 (cobalamin) are interconnected in various metabolic pathways. Folate supplementation can correct the hematologic manifestations of a B12 deficiency, but it does not address the neurologic manifestations. In some cases, folate therapy can "mask" the anemia associated with B12 deficiency, potentially aggravating the neurologic symptoms. The correct approach is to identify and treat the underlying B12 deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malabsorption of folate: Malabsorption of folate could lead to a deficiency, but in this case, the patient was given folate (B9) supplementation, and the blood picture improved. This suggests that the issue is not with the absorption of folate but with its utilization.

 

Option B. Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency: While this is a consideration, especially in cases of neuropathy, the patient's symptoms worsening after folate supplementation suggest another mechanism.

 

Option C. Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS: This is not a recognized mechanism. Folate reductase is an enzyme that converts folate to its active form, and CNS deficiency of this enzyme is not a common cause of neurologic manifestations in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage.

 

The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.

 

Administration of folic acid for patients with macrocytic anemia can partially reverse the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

 

Explanation:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis: This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry: This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.

 

Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic liver disease is experiencing recurrent urinary tract infections. His healthcare team is considering various antibiotics, including fluoroquinolones, to treat the infection. Which of the following fluoroquinolones is not recommended for use in patients with liver disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pefloxacin

 

  • Pefloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is primarily eliminated by the liver. In patients with liver disease, pefloxacin can accumulate in the body and cause hepatotoxicity. Therefore, it is not recommended for use in patients with liver disease or hepatic impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is eliminated by both the liver and the kidneys. It can be used with caution in patients with liver disease, provided the dosage is adjusted according to hepatic function.

 

Option B. Levofloxacin: Levofloxacin is another fluoroquinolone that is eliminated by both the liver and kidneys. It is generally considered safe for use in patients with liver disease, with appropriate dose adjustments based on hepatic function.

 

Option D. Lomefloxacin: Lomefloxacin is also eliminated by both the liver and kidneys and can be used in patients with liver disease, provided that dosage adjustments are made.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones that are safe in renal failure, avoided in liver failure and not effective in UTI include:

 

  • P: Pefloxacin
  • M: Moxifloxacin
  • T: Trovafloxacin

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signaling? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

Insulin uses the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling to exert its functions.

 

Insulin receptor is a tetramer, formed by four glycoprotein subunits (two α-subunits and two β-subunits). The α-subunits protrude out of the cell and the β-subunits protrude inside the cell. The α and β subunits are linked to each other by disulfide bonds. Intracellular surfaces of α-subunits have the enzyme activity – protein kinase (tyrosine kinase) activity.

 

When insulin binds with α-subunits of the receptor protein, the tyrosine kinase at the β-subunit (that protrudes into the cell) is activated by means of autophosphorylation.

 

Activated tyrosine kinase acts on many intracellular enzymes by phosphorylating or dephosphorylating them so that some of the enzymes are activated while others are inactivated

 

Other hormones acting in a similar fashion includes

 

  • Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
  • hormones acting via cytokine receptor - Prolactin, Growth hormone

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. TSH acts through a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), not a receptor tyrosine kinase. It stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones by activating the adenylyl cyclase signaling pathway.

 

Option C. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): Incorrect. TRH also utilizes G protein-coupled receptors and primarily influences the pituitary gland to release TSH, using intracellular signaling mechanisms involving phospholipase C.

 

Option D. MSH (Melanocyte-Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. MSH binds to melanocortin receptors, which are GPCRs, and is involved in a variety of functions including skin pigmentation and appetite regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin uniquely uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling among the options listed, activating complex pathways that are essential for regulating glucose metabolism and other metabolic processes in the body.

choices.text: Lyophylised Amphotericin B

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Voriconazole

 

Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium.

 

The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: While effective against Aspergillus species, itraconazole is generally considered less effective than voriconazole for invasive cases due to its variable bioavailability and slower onset of action.

 

Option C. Lyophylised Amphotericin B: Often used as a second-line treatment or in patients who cannot tolerate azole antifungals. It has a broader spectrum but is also associated with more severe side effects, particularly nephrotoxicity.

 

Option D. Posaconazole: This is another alternative, especially for prophylaxis against Aspergillus in high-risk patients, but it is generally used when voriconazole is contraindicated or not tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Voriconazole's effectiveness, broad spectrum of activity, and favorable pharmacokinetic profile make it the first-line treatment for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, offering significant benefits in terms of efficacy and patient outcomes in severe fungal infections.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sickle cell anemia

 

History is suggestive of dactylitis precipitated by playing causing microvascular obstruction. Shrunken spleen suggestive of auto splenectomy with recurrent episodes of dactylitis suggests sickle cell anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria: Typically presents with cyclical fever, chills, and splenomegaly rather than a shrunken spleen. The history of recurrent hand swelling isn't typical for malaria.

 

Option C. Pancreatitis: Main symptoms include severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, unrelated to the symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Measles: Characterized by a rash, fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots, none of which relate to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

In a child presenting with fever and recurrent hand swelling following physical activity, alongside a history of a shrunken spleen, sickle cell anemia should be considered a primary diagnosis. This highlights the importance of considering hemoglobinopathies in patients with peculiar skeletal pains and organ findings suggestive of chronic hemolytic processes.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis
Mutation in dynein arms
Antibodies against type-IV collagen

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency 

 

The gross specimen shown above has emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus, indicating panacinar emphysema. It is caused by a lack of alpha-1-antitrypsin.

 

The acini in this type are uniformly enlarged from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. The prefix "pan" denotes the entire acinus but not the entire lung. Panacinar emphysema, as opposed to centriacinar emphysema, is more common in the lower zones and anterior margins of the lung, and it is usually most severe at the bases. This type of emphysema is linked to a lack of alpha 1-antitrypsin (AT).

 

 

 

A, Centriacinar emphysema. Central areas show marked emphysematous damage (E), surrounded by relatively spared alveolar spaces. B, Panacinar emphysema involving the entire pulmonary lobule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis:

 

  • Pathology: Cystic fibrosis is characterized by thick, sticky mucus production leading to recurrent lung infections and bronchiectasis, not emphysema.
  • Etiology: Caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to defective chloride channels.

 

Option C. Mutation in dynein arms:

 

Pathology: Dynein arm mutations are associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), which leads to impaired mucociliary clearance and recurrent respiratory infections, but not typically emphysema.

 

Option D. Antibodies against type-IV collagen:

 

Pathology: Associated with Goodpasture syndrome, which causes pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis, not emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder leading to a lack of AAT, which protects the lung tissue from elastase. The deficiency causes panacinar emphysema, characterized by uniform enlargement of acini, particularly in the lower lobes of the lung, and presents with chronic respiratory symptoms.

questions.text: Which of these methods relies on behavioral sciences? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Management by objective

 

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

 

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making:  This can rely on both behavioral sciences and quantitative methods, but in the context of management and organizational processes, it often involves analytical and quantitative approaches.

 

Option B. Systems analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to understand and analyze complex systems and processes, often involving mathematical models and simulations.

 

Option C. Network analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to plan and control complex projects, involving techniques like PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hypochlorous acid

 

The primary reason for the disinfectant ability of bleaching powder stems from the activity of hypochlorous acid, which is responsible for its effectiveness. It surpasses hypochlorite ions in effectiveness by a factor of 70-80.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochlorite Ion (OCl⁻): While it does have disinfectant properties, it is much less effective compared to hypochlorous acid.

 

Option B. Hydrochloric Acid (HCl): This is a byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and water but does not contribute significantly to the disinfectant quality.

 

Option D. Chloride Ion (Cl⁻): This is also a byproduct of the disinfection process and does not play a direct role in the disinfectant action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleaching powder (CaOCl2)

 

  • 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • CHLORINE + IMPURITIES à DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl2 [free residual Cl2]
  • Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]

 

H2O + Cl → HCI + HOCI HOCI → H + OCI

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluent aphasia

 

The posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus is where Wernicke's area is located, which is crucial for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to Wernicke's aphasia, which is a type of fluent aphasia. Patients with this type of aphasia exhibit fluent but often meaningless speech and have significant difficulties in understanding spoken language. Their speech is typically characterized by normal flow and articulation but includes nonsensical phrases and incorrect word substitutions (neologisms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-fluent aphasia: This type of aphasia, typically associated with damage to Broca’s area in the frontal lobe, results in slow, labored speech and struggle in forming words, though comprehension often remains intact.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: In anomic aphasia, the person can speak fluently and understand speech but has difficulty naming objects and words, typically not linked to damage in the superior temporal gyrus.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This arises from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the brain structure that connects Wernicke's area to Broca’s area. It is characterized by fluent speech with frequent errors, good comprehension, but poor repetition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Reference - KV Krishna Das textbook of Medicine 5th edition

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TLD badge

 

Explanation:

 

Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

 

 

  • Given to radiation personnel for its usage.
  • Personnel dosimeter.
  • Thermoluminescent
  • 3 monthly [sent for measurement in India]
  • Made up of CaSO4: Dysprosium [LiF can also be used]
  • Worn below the lead apron at the level of the chest

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collimators: Used in radiographic devices to narrow the beam of radiation to limit exposure and improve image quality, but not for monitoring radiation exposure.

 

Option C. Linear accelerator: A device primarily used in cancer treatment to deliver high-energy x-rays or electrons to the region of the patient's tumor. It is not a monitoring device.

 

Option D. Grid: Used in radiographic imaging to improve image contrast by absorbing scattered radiation, not for measuring radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A TLD badge is a critical tool for radiation safety, allowing for accurate monitoring and measurement of radiation exposure over time to ensure that radiation workers do not exceed safe exposure limits. This is crucial in maintaining occupational health standards in radiologically active environments.

questions.text: Synovial fluid of low viscosity is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteoarthritis

 

Option C)

 

SYNOVIAL FLUIDS VISCOSITY

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gout, Option B. Septic arthritis, and Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis are characterized by decreased viscosity of the synovial fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low viscosity of synovial fluid is seen in Rheumatic fever, Rheumatic arthritis, gout, Pyogenic arthritis, Tubercular arthritis.
  • Osteoarthritis is normal synovial fluid viscosity.

choices.text: Candida albicans
Candida tropicalis

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucormycosis

 

  • Voriconazole is an antifungal medication that is used for the treatment of a variety of fungal infections, including aspergillosis, candidiasis, and some types of cryptococcosis. However, it is not effective against mucormycosis, which is caused by fungi in the order Mucorales.
  • For the treatment of mucormycosis, alternative antifungal medications such as amphotericin B or posaconazole are usually used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Voriconazole is effective against Candida albicans, a common cause of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Candida tropicalis: Voriconazole is also effective against Candida tropicalis, another species of Candida that can cause infections.

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Voriconazole is highly effective against Aspergillus species, making it a first-line treatment for aspergillosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. For the treatment of mucormycosis, alternative antifungal medications such as amphotericin B or posaconazole are usually used.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) was started on tolvaptan therapy. A few weeks later, he presents with symptoms of dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely mechanism behind these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased free water clearance

 

Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist used in the management of ADPKD. By blocking the action of vasopressin at the V2 receptor, tolvaptan inhibits water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts, leading to increased free water clearance (aquaresis). This can result in symptoms like dry mouth and increased thirst due to increased urine output and dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. V2 receptor agonism: Tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, not an agonist. Its mechanism of action is to block the V2 receptor, thereby increasing water excretion.

 

Option C. Increased renal cAMP levels: Vasopressin usually acts on the V2 receptor to increase cAMP levels, which in turn promotes water reabsorption in the collecting duct. Since tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, it would be expected to decrease cAMP levels in the kidney, not increase them.

 

Option D. Increase in urine osmolality: Tolvaptan's action leads to increased water excretion without a significant change in solute excretion, resulting in a decrease in urine osmolality, not an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolvaptan causes increased free water clearance by blocking V2 receptors, leading to symptoms of dehydration such as dry mouth and increased thirst. This is a direct result of its mechanism as a V2 receptor antagonist, which inhibits water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child has presented with progressive muscle weakness. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duchenne muscular dystrophy

 

The dystrophin gene mutation in this child suggests a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). DMD is an X-linked recessive disorder that typically presents in early childhood with muscle weakness that progressively worsens. This is the most common form of muscular dystrophy in children. The absence or severe deficiency of the dystrophin protein, which is essential for muscle fiber stability, leads to muscle damage over time. Children usually present with difficulty in activities such as running, jumping, and climbing stairs, and the disease often progresses to the point where the child becomes wheelchair-dependent during their teenage years.

 

Recent advancements in treatment include FDA-approved drugs such as Viltolarsen, an antisense oligonucleotide for patients with confirmed dystrophin gene mutations. Another treatment, Casimersen, has also been approved for patients with a dystrophin mutation that is amenable to exon 45 skipping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD): BMD is a milder form of dystrophinopathy, also caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, but it presents later in life, usually during adolescence or early adulthood. Unlike DMD, patients with BMD produce some functional dystrophin, leading to slower disease progression. This child’s early onset of muscle weakness makes Duchenne muscular dystrophy more likely.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: Myotonic dystrophy is caused by a genetic mutation involving CTG repeat expansions in the DMPK gene. This condition results in muscle weakness and myotonia, as well as multisystem involvement, including cardiac and endocrine abnormalities. However, it is unrelated to dystrophin gene mutations and typically presents later in life, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis (MG): Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that affects the neuromuscular junction. In MG, antibodies attack acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue that worsens with activity. MG typically involves fluctuating weakness, especially in the muscles controlling the eyes, face, and swallowing. It is not related to dystrophin mutations, making this diagnosis unlikely in the given scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading to the absence of the dystrophin protein and progressive muscle weakness, typically beginning in early childhood.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient presented with a mole that initially appeared 10 years ago and has progressively increased in size. The image of the mole is provided below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lentigo maligna melanoma

 

Lentigo maligna melanoma (also referred to as Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle) is a subtype of malignant melanoma. It predominantly occurs in areas that are chronically exposed to the sun, such as the face, neck, and forearms. It tends to develop in elderly females more often than in males. The mole in question began 10 years ago, and its slow, progressive increase in size is characteristic of lentigo maligna melanoma. It typically starts as a flat, dark, irregularly pigmented lesion with uneven borders, similar to what is seen in the image.

 

Lentigo maligna melanomas progress very slowly, often taking years to enter the vertical growth phase, which involves deeper invasion into the skin layers. These lesions have a relatively lower malignant potential compared to other forms of melanoma due to their prolonged horizontal growth phase before becoming invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular melanoma: Nodular melanoma is one of the most aggressive forms of melanoma. Unlike lentigo maligna melanoma, which grows slowly, nodular melanomas develop rapidly. They often appear as elevated, dome-shaped, or polypoid lesions and are more common in men. Nodular melanomas lack a horizontal growth phase and can invade deeper skin layers early on, leading to a poorer prognosis. They typically occur on the trunk, head, or neck, and not necessarily on sun-exposed areas like lentigo maligna melanoma.

 

 

Option C. Superficial spreading melanoma: Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common subtype of melanoma. It usually arises from pre-existing nevi (moles) that undergo changes in color and border over time. These lesions are more often found on the trunk and proximal extremities. They can exhibit a mixture of colors—brown, black, red, or even depigmented areas—and can rapidly transition to a vertical growth phase, leading to nodule formation, which may ulcerate or bleed. In contrast, lentigo maligna melanoma tends to grow more slowly and predominantly in sun-exposed areas.

 

 

Option D. Acral lentiginous melanoma: Acral lentiginous melanoma is the most common melanoma seen in individuals with darker skin tones. It typically affects areas such as the palms, soles, and subungual regions (under the nails). This variant of melanoma often appears as a flat, irregular macule, sometimes described as resembling a "dirty stain." Although it can occur in older individuals, it is typically found in non-sun-exposed areas, unlike the lesion in this case, which is on a sun-exposed area of the skin.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lentigo maligna melanoma, a subtype of melanoma, primarily occurs in sun-exposed areas in elderly individuals and is characterized by a slow, horizontal growth phase, resulting in a lower malignant potential compared to other melanomas.

questions.text: A woman comes to the clinic two weeks postpartum, reporting a complete perineal tear sustained during her home delivery. When is the best time to repair this tear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 months

 

A complete perineal tear refers to a severe laceration involving the perineum and surrounding structures that extends to the anal sphincter. In cases where the tear was not repaired within the first 24 hours, it is generally recommended to repair the tear between 3 to 6 months after delivery. This time frame allows for any local infection or inflammation to subside, improving the patient’s general health and allowing the body time to heal.

 

By 3 months, most infections or complications from the tear would have resolved, and scar tissue would still be manageable for surgical repair. If the tear is left untreated beyond 6 months, dense scar tissue may form, making the surgery more challenging and potentially leading to long-term complications.

 

In this case, the patient presented two weeks after delivery, which is beyond the immediate window for repair. Therefore, the best approach would be to wait until approximately 3 months postpartum before proceeding with the surgical repair.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete perineal tears that are not repaired immediately after delivery should generally be repaired between 3 to 6 months postpartum to allow for optimal healing and to reduce the risk of complications from dense scar tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause disease after being introduced into the skin through a traumatic injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that primarily exists in soil and on plants, such as grasses, trees, and rose bushes. When traumatic inoculation occurs, such as through a thorn prick or scratch, the fungus enters the skin and causes sporotrichosis. This is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by skin lesions that can spread along the draining lymphatic pathways.

 

The organism is particularly associated with gardeners or people who handle vegetation. The infection typically presents as nodules or ulcers that can appear at the site of injury and follow a pattern of lymphatic spread, often forming subcutaneous nodules along lymph channels.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis, a systemic fungal infection usually acquired by inhalation of spores from soil or decaying organic material. Although skin lesions may develop secondarily in disseminated blastomycosis, traumatic inoculation of this fungus into the skin is not the primary route of infection.

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis is the causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, a respiratory disease primarily acquired by inhaling airborne arthroconidia from disturbed soil. It does not typically cause infection through skin trauma but can result in skin manifestations as part of disseminated disease.

 

Option D. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection endemic to parts of Latin America. Similar to Blastomyces dermatitidis, the infection is generally acquired via inhalation rather than skin inoculation. It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other organs, including the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes infection primarily after traumatic inoculation into the skin, leading to sporotrichosis, a disease commonly associated with individuals handling vegetation.

choices.text: Surgery is performed in all patients regardless of symptoms
A sternal incision is always required for the operation
It receives its blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most retrosternal goiters can be removed via a neck incision

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding retrosternal goiter?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Most retrosternal goiters can be removed via a neck incision

 

A retrosternal goiter is defined as a thyroid enlargement where more than 50% of the mass extends below the suprasternal notch. These goiters can be classified into two types:

 

  • Primary retrosternal goiter: This is a rare type that originates from ectopic thyroid tissue located within the chest (mediastinum). It is not connected to the thyroid gland in the neck and receives its blood supply from vessels within the chest cavity.
  • Secondary retrosternal goiter: This is the more common form, where the thyroid gland in the neck enlarges and extends downwards into the chest. It is usually associated with nodular goiters and receives its blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries.

 

Most patients with retrosternal goiters are asymptomatic; however, if the goiter grows large enough, it can compress nearby structures, leading to symptoms such as difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), shortness of breath (dyspnea), and compression of the trachea. Some patients may exhibit a positive Pemberton sign, where raising the arms above the head causes facial flushing and visible swelling of neck veins due to pressure on the thoracic inlet.

 

In more than 95% of cases, retrosternal goiters can be surgically removed via a neck incision (also known as a transcervical approach), especially when the goiter is an extension of a thyroid enlargement in the neck. This less invasive approach avoids the need for a sternal incision.

 

The preferred imaging study for assessing retrosternal goiters is a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan of the neck and chest. This helps in understanding the size of the goiter, its location, and any potential involvement of nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms: Not all retrosternal goiters require surgery. Surgery is typically reserved for patients with significant airway compression or those with symptoms such as dysphagia or dyspnea. In asymptomatic patients, surgery is not always necessary unless there is a risk of complications.

 

Option B. Sternal incision is always required to operate: A sternal incision (median sternotomy) is only required in rare cases where the goiter is completely within the chest, is particularly large, or if the goiter has recurred in the mediastinum. This is most common in cases of primary mediastinal goiters, malignant goiters, or in instances of recurrence in the chest after a previous surgery.

 

Option C. It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery: Retrosternal goiters, whether primary or secondary, receive their blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries, not the thoracodorsal artery. The thoracodorsal artery is a branch of the subscapular artery and is unrelated to the thyroid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most retrosternal goiters can be removed via a transcervical neck incision. A sternal incision is only required in rare cases when the goiter is completely within the chest or is of significant size.

questions.text: A forensic examiner is evaluating a body several days postmortem. The skin shows a typical pattern. What is the name of this postmortem phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Marbling

 

The phenomenon described in the image is marbling, a postmortem change that appears when hemoglobin in the decomposing blood breaks down within the superficial veins, creating a prominent greenish-black, web-like pattern on the skin. This process occurs as part of the body's natural decomposition and is typically observed several days after death. Marbling is one of the recognizable features during the decomposition phase, especially in bodies exposed to warmer environments, which accelerate the breakdown of tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adipocere: Adipocere is a waxy substance that forms during the decomposition of a body, particularly in moist environments. It occurs when body fat undergoes a chemical transformation, turning into a solid, soap-like material. Unlike marbling, adipocere takes weeks to form and is not associated with the vascular system.

 

Option B. Postmortem lividity: Postmortem lividity (or livor mortis) is the pooling of blood in the lowest parts of the body after the heart has stopped. This results in a purplish discoloration of the skin and usually starts within a few hours after death. Unlike marbling, lividity is a relatively early postmortem change and does not involve blood vessel decomposition.

 

Option C. Petechial hemorrhage: Petechial hemorrhages are tiny red or purple spots caused by the rupture of small blood vessels (capillaries). These can result from trauma, asphyxiation, or other pressure-related injuries. Petechial hemorrhages are often seen in forensic contexts but are unrelated to decomposition or marbling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling is a postmortem phenomenon characterized by the breakdown of blood in the veins, creating a marble-like appearance on the skin several days after death as decomposition progresses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a severe sore throat and difficulty swallowing. The examination reveals a swollen area near the tonsil, as shown in the image below. What type of speech is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hot potato voice

 

 

 

The hot potato voice is a characteristic speech pattern seen in patients with peritonsillar abscess (quinsy), which presents as a muffled, thickened speech. The term is used because the voice sounds like the person is holding a hot object in their mouth, causing them to articulate poorly.

 

A peritonsillar abscess occurs when pus accumulates between the tonsillar capsule and the pharyngeal muscles. It typically develops as a complication of untreated or inadequately treated tonsillitis. Symptoms include severe unilateral sore throat, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), and trismus (inability to open the mouth fully). Other clinical features often include:

 

  • Fever
  • Drooling
  • Referred ear pain
  • Swollen, displaced tonsils with a visible collection of pus, as seen in the image.

 

Immediate treatment usually involves antibiotics and surgical drainage (either needle aspiration or incision and drainage), followed by a tonsillectomy several weeks later (known as interval tonsillectomy) to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staccato voice: A staccato voice refers to speech with abrupt, short syllables, often associated with certain neurological disorders or speech defects. This is not typically linked to peritonsillar abscess.

 

Option B. Rhinolalia aperta: Rhinolalia aperta is a condition where speech is overly nasal due to a failure of the soft palate to close properly. This is unrelated to peritonsillar abscess and is more commonly associated with conditions like cleft palate or soft palate dysfunction.

 

Option D. Rhinolalia clausa: Rhinolalia clausa refers to a nasal quality of speech due to obstruction in the nasal passages, often caused by nasal congestion or polyps. This type of speech is also not associated with peritonsillar abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hot potato voice is a classic sign of peritonsillar abscess, characterized by muffled speech due to the swelling and obstruction in the oropharyngeal space.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of fever and chills. Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) shows multiple areas of intrahepatic beading, as seen in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

 

The MRCP image in the question shows intrahepatic beading, a typical finding in primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Over time, this leads to progressive bile duct strictures and cholestasis, which eventually cause liver cirrhosis.

 

PSC commonly presents with symptoms like fever, chills, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. It is often associated with ulcerative colitis and affects individuals between the ages of 30 and 45, with men being more commonly affected.

 

MRCP or ERCP typically reveals multifocal strictures and dilations of the bile ducts, giving a "beading" or "chain of lakes" appearance. While MRCP is diagnostic, ERCP may be used to treat dominant strictures. The progression of PSC often leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis, and up to 10-20% of patients develop cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Treatment options are limited, and there is no definitive medical therapy to reverse the condition. Liver transplantation is the only curative option for patients with advanced liver disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caroli disease: Caroli disease is a congenital disorder that causes irregular dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts but spares the extrahepatic bile ducts. Patients typically present before the age of 30 with abdominal pain, cholangitis, or liver disease. MRCP shows large, cystic dilations of the bile ducts, distinct from the beading seen in PSC.

 

Option C. Oriental cholangitis (Recurrent pyogenic cholangitis): This condition is characterized by recurrent infections, biliary stone formation, and cholangitis. It is caused by infections with liver flukes or bacteria such as E. coli and Klebsiella. Unlike PSC, MRCP in oriental cholangitis shows biliary stones and strictures, not the diffuse beading pattern.

 

Option D. Primary biliary carcinoma (Cholangiocarcinoma): Cholangiocarcinoma typically affects individuals over 60 and presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and obstructive jaundice. On MRCP, cholangiocarcinoma shows irregular narrowing of the bile ducts with upstream dilation. It is more localized than the multifocal strictures of PSC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an autoimmune condition associated with intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile duct strictures, presenting with recurrent fever, chills, and MRCP findings of intrahepatic beading.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap, or the difference between birth rates and death rates, begin to increase significantly?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early expanding

 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between the birth rate and the death rate in a population, which significantly impacts population size and age structure. The gap begins to increase during the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

 

In this stage, the death rate starts to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and food supply, while the birth rate remains high. This leads to rapid population growth, as the number of births far exceeds the number of deaths, widening the demographic gap. The gap continues to expand until it reaches a maximum during this stage.

 

The demographic cycle includes the following stages:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The early expanding stage of the demographic cycle is where the demographic gap—the difference between birth rates and death rates—begins to significantly increase due to a drop in the death rate while the birth rate remains high.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G2P1, presents in labor. The partograph, as shown below, indicates a prolonged labor with fetal distress. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

The partograph provided shows a case of obstructed labor. The key findings include a secondary arrest of cervical dilation (dilation has been stagnant for more than two hours) and an arrest of fetal descent for more than one hour, despite adequate uterine contractions. Additionally, the presence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid and a decreasing fetal heart rate suggests that the fetus is in distress.

 

The appropriate management in this scenario is an urgent cesarean section to prevent further fetal compromise. Fetal distress, combined with the lack of progress in labor, indicates that the fetus may not tolerate the delay of a prolonged vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: In cases of obstructed labor with fetal distress, waiting is not a viable option. The fetal heart rate is already dropping, and further delays could result in severe fetal compromise or even fetal death.

 

Option B. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin is used to stimulate or augment uterine contractions, but in this case, uterine contractions are already adequate. The problem lies with the lack of cervical progress and fetal descent, indicating a mechanical obstruction rather than insufficient contractions.

 

Option C. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery is an option only when the cervix is fully dilated and the fetal head is low enough in the birth canal. In this case, the cervix is not fully dilated, and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of obstructed labor with signs of fetal distress, the most appropriate management is an immediate cesarean section to prevent further complications for both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces a superantigen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

Superantigens are a class of protein toxins that can cause massive activation of T-cells by binding directly to the MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and the T-cell receptor (TCR) outside of the conventional antigen-binding site. This non-specific activation leads to a large, uncontrolled release of cytokines, causing systemic effects such as toxic shock syndrome.

 

Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (SPEs), which function as superantigens. These exotoxins are implicated in conditions such as scarlet fever, streptococcal toxic shock syndrome, and necrotizing fasciitis. The widespread T-cell activation caused by these superantigens can lead to severe inflammatory responses and tissue damage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus epidermidis: While Staphylococcus aureus (not Staphylococcus epidermidis) is known to produce superantigens such as toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1) and staphylococcal enterotoxins, Staphylococcus epidermidis does not produce superantigens. It is typically associated with less virulent infections, often related to implanted medical devices or prosthetics.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Clostridium perfringens produces a variety of toxins, including alpha toxin, which is responsible for gas gangrene (myonecrosis), but it does not produce superantigens.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholerae: Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which increases cyclic AMP levels, leading to severe watery diarrhea (cholera). However, this toxin is not a superantigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus pyogenes produces superantigens, specifically streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (SPEs), which cause widespread T-cell activation and can result in conditions like streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.

choices.text: Made up of cell debris, mucus, and dust
It is a late post-mortem change
Sign of increased venous pressure before death

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the post-mortem change shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Made up of cell debris, mucus, and dust

 

The image shows tache noire, a post-mortem change characterized by a blackish discoloration of the eye, specifically on the sclera. This is a result of the drying of the sclera in areas exposed to air, where cell debris, mucus, and dust accumulate. Tache noire is considered a non-specific, early post-mortem change that usually appears 3 to 4 hours after death when the eyes remain open.

 

Initially, yellowish triangles appear on either side of the cornea, with their apex pointing towards the canthus. Over time, these triangles darken to brown or black as the drying progresses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indicates death by asphyxiation: Tache noire is not a specific indicator of the cause of death, such as asphyxiation. It results simply from post-mortem exposure of the sclera to air.

 

Option C. It is a late post-mortem change: Tache noire is an early post-mortem change, typically occurring within a few hours of death, rather than a late change.

 

Option D. Sign of increased venous pressure before death: Tache noire does not indicate increased venous pressure before death. It is unrelated to the cardiovascular state of the deceased and results purely from post-mortem drying of the sclera.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tache noire is an early post-mortem change caused by the accumulation of cell debris, mucus, and dust on the exposed sclera, leading to a blackish discoloration, usually seen in individuals whose eyes remain open after death.

questions.text: Which of the following tests helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fecal calprotectin

 

Fecal calprotectin is a biomarker that helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). In IBD, which includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, fecal calprotectin is elevated due to the presence of active intestinal inflammation. It is a protein released by neutrophils and is a reliable marker for gut inflammation. By contrast, in IBS, which is a functional disorder without underlying structural or inflammatory causes, fecal calprotectin remains normal.

 

This makes fecal calprotectin a valuable non-invasive test to differentiate between the two conditions. It can also be used to monitor disease activity in IBD and assess for postoperative recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum albumin: Serum albumin can be low in severe inflammatory conditions, including IBD, due to malnutrition or protein loss. However, it is a non-specific marker and cannot be used to differentiate between IBD and IBS.

 

Option C. C-reactive protein (CRP): CRP is an acute-phase reactant that is elevated in systemic inflammatory conditions, including IBD. While it is helpful for assessing inflammation, it is not specific for intestinal diseases and cannot reliably distinguish IBD from IBS on its own.

 

Option D. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR): ESR is another marker of inflammation that may be elevated in IBD. However, like CRP, it is not specific enough to differentiate IBD from IBS, as it reflects general inflammation rather than intestinal-specific pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal calprotectin is the most specific test for distinguishing inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), as it is elevated in IBD due to gut inflammation but remains normal in IBS.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves produces the extraocular movement as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oculomotor nerve

 

The image shows elevation of the eye in adduction, which is primarily caused by the action of the inferior oblique muscle. The oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III) innervates this muscle. The oculomotor nerve is responsible for innervating most of the extraocular muscles, including:

 

  • Superior rectus
  • Inferior rectus
  • Medial rectus
  • Inferior oblique

 

In this case, the inferior oblique muscle assists with the elevation of the eye when it is adducted (moved toward the midline). The superior rectus also contributes to eye elevation but is more effective when the eye is abducted (moved away from the midline).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which depresses and internally rotates the eye when it is adducted. This action does not correspond to the movement seen in the image.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it outward). This movement is also unrelated to the eye movement seen in the image.

 

Option D. Optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II): The optic nerve is responsible for vision and does not control eye movement. Therefore, it does not contribute to the extraocular movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III) is responsible for producing the elevation of the eye in adduction through its innervation of the inferior oblique muscle.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with an intensely itchy lesion for three days, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea corporis

 

The image depicts a ring-shaped lesion with central clearing, which is characteristic of tinea corporis, also known as ringworm. Tinea corporis is a fungal infection of the skin caused by dermatophytes, most commonly Trichophyton rubrum. The infection affects the stratum corneum and is often found on the trunk and limbs.

 

The typical presentation includes:

 

  • Circular or ring-shaped lesions
  • Sharply defined edges with a raised border
  • Central clearing as the infection spreads outward
  • Scaling, which may or may not be present

 

These features help distinguish tinea corporis from other dermatologic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Granuloma annulare: Granuloma annulare also presents with circular lesions but usually lacks the scaling and well-defined margins seen in tinea corporis. It consists of grouped papules that are skin-colored to violaceous in appearance and typically occur on the distal extremities. It is more common in children and women under 30.

 

Option C. Ichthyosis vulgaris: Ichthyosis vulgaris presents with dry, scaly skin rather than the ring-shaped, erythematous lesions seen in tinea corporis. It is most common in infants and affects areas such as the lower legs and skin near joints like the elbows and knees.

 

Option D. Pyoderma gangrenosum: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a chronic, painful skin condition that presents as ulcerative lesions with violaceous borders, often associated with conditions like inflammatory bowel disease. It typically occurs on the lower limbs and lacks the ring-like, scaling pattern seen in tinea corporis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea corporis is characterized by a ring-shaped lesion with central clearing and raised margins, caused by dermatophyte infections, most commonly Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with indurated scaly lesions over the ears and face, as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus

 

The image shows discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE), a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-defined scaly patches that tend to occur on sun-exposed areas such as the face, ears, and scalp. The lesions typically heal with scarring, atrophy, and pigmentary changes. In this case, the scaly plaques on the ear are characteristic of DLE.

 

DLE is a cutaneous form of lupus that does not usually involve systemic symptoms. The skin lesions are inflammatory, and over time they can cause permanent scarring and discoloration. A skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis by showing histopathological changes specific to lupus erythematosus.

 

 

Treatment of DLE often starts with topical corticosteroids (e.g., 0.1% betamethasone or fluocinolone). For more extensive or severe cases, oral corticosteroids or other systemic therapies may be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lupus vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that presents with reddish-brown papules and plaques, often with a slow-growing nature. These plaques tend to develop elevated borders and central atrophy. The condition is seen in individuals with prior TB sensitization, and apple jelly nodules may be seen on diascopy.

 

 

Option C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): SLE is an autoimmune condition that often presents with a characteristic butterfly-shaped malar rash. This rash is erythematous and affects the malar eminences, but it typically spares the nasolabial folds. SLE is associated with systemic involvement, including joints, kidneys, and other organs.

 

 

Option D. Acne rosacea: Acne rosacea presents with erythema, pustules, and telangiectasia, predominantly affecting the convexities of the face. It does not typically cause scarring or crusting as seen in DLE. Acne rosacea is triggered by factors such as sunlight exposure, stress, and alcohol consumption.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) presents with scaly, well-defined lesions that tend to occur on the face, scalp, and ears, leading to scarring and atrophy over time. It is a cutaneous form of lupus that does not usually involve systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, he feels lethargic and tired. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, and there is no sign of bleeding. What could be the likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Addisonian crisis

 

The clinical scenario of hypotension without bleeding following bilateral adrenalectomy suggests an Addisonian crisis (acute adrenal insufficiency). After the removal of both adrenal glands, the body no longer produces adequate cortisol and aldosterone, leading to a life-threatening situation that requires prompt recognition and treatment.

 

Addisonian crisis is often triggered by surgery, infection, trauma, or other stressors that unmask the adrenal insufficiency. Patients present with symptoms such as:

 

  • Lethargy
  • Hypotension (low blood pressure)
  • Electrolyte imbalances (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia)
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Abdominal pain

 

Immediate intervention is crucial, involving fluid resuscitation (saline infusion) and glucocorticoid replacement therapy (e.g., intravenous hydrocortisone). Delay in treatment can lead to shock and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone): SIADH is characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to hyponatremia and water retention. It typically presents with normal or elevated blood pressure rather than the hypotension seen in this case. SIADH would not explain the symptoms following adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Diabetes insipidus results from either a deficiency in ADH (central DI) or insensitivity of the kidneys to ADH (nephrogenic DI), leading to excessive urination and dehydration. However, it is not associated with the removal of the adrenal glands and would present with polyuria and polydipsia rather than hypotension.

 

Option D. Cerebral salt-wasting disease: Cerebral salt-wasting disease is a condition that occurs mainly after neurological injury and involves hyponatremia due to excessive sodium excretion. It does not occur following adrenalectomy and would not lead to the specific presentation of Addisonian crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After bilateral adrenalectomy, the body lacks adrenal hormones, leading to an Addisonian crisis with hypotension, fatigue, and electrolyte imbalances. This requires immediate fluid resuscitation and glucocorticoid replacement therapy.

choices.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
Micturating cystourethrogram with bulbar stricture
Micturating cystourethrogram with prostatic urethra stricture

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture

 

The image depicts a retrograde cystourethrogram (RCUG), a radiological investigation in which contrast material is introduced into the anterior urethra through a catheter, allowing visualization of the urethral lumen and its abnormalities. The image shows a narrowing in the penile urethra, which is characteristic of a penile urethral stricture.

 

Penile urethral strictures occur when there is narrowing of the urethra in the penile section, which can cause difficulty with urination, incomplete voiding, or other obstructive symptoms. Strictures can result from trauma, infections, or inflammation of the urethra.

 

In a retrograde cystourethrogram (RCUG), the contrast is injected into the anterior urethra to evaluate anterior urethral abnormalities. This technique is particularly effective in diagnosing penile and bulbar urethral strictures, where the urethra becomes narrowed, reducing urine flow.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture: This option is incorrect because the membranous urethra is part of the posterior urethra and would typically be assessed using a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or micturating cystourethrogram (MCU). In the provided image, the narrowing is localized in the penile urethra, which is part of the anterior urethra. Thus, the stricture is not in the membranous urethra.

 

Option C. Micturating cystourethrogram with bulbar stricture: A micturating cystourethrogram (MCU), also known as voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), visualizes the posterior urethra (membranous and prostatic urethra) during the act of micturition (urination). The bulbar urethra is part of the anterior urethra, and while a bulbar stricture could theoretically occur, the investigation used in the image is RCUG, which specifically visualizes the anterior urethra, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Micturating cystourethrogram with prostatic urethra stricture: The prostatic urethra is part of the posterior urethra, and as mentioned, a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is used to assess posterior urethral abnormalities. The stricture in the provided image, however, is in the penile urethra, which is part of the anterior urethra. This makes the diagnosis of a prostatic urethral stricture incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retrograde cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice for identifying anterior urethral strictures, particularly in the penile and bulbar urethra.
